abstract: BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- Arr. barks Fury, Messina; Essex, Key West; brig Edwin, New-Orleans. The brig Demarara, from Portland for Cardenas, capsized during the gale of Feb. 22, on South Shoal. She was fallen in with on the 24th, and her crew were taken off by the brig M.B. Stetson, and have arrived here.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- Arr. barks Fury, Messina; Essex, Key West; brig Edwin, New-Orleans. The brig Demarara, from Portland for Cardenas, capsized during the gale of Feb. 22, on South Shoal. She was fallen in with on the 24th, and her crew were taken off by the brig M.B. Stetson, and have arrived here.

abstract: We have advices from Port Royal to the 25th of February, by the arrival at this port of the steamship Arago. Preparations for the grand movement were still in progress. All the iron-clads, excepting two, had arrived. The misunderstanding between the officers of Gen. HUNTER's and
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Port Royal to the 25th of February, by the arrival at this port of the steamship Arago. Preparations for the grand movement were still in progress. All the iron-clads, excepting two, had arrived. The misunderstanding between the officers of Gen. HUNTER's and Gen. FOSTER's forces respectively, had been amically arranged, through the interposition of Adjutant-Gen. TOWNSEND, who, it is stated, was sent on with power to adjudicate all differences. His announcement that the forces from North Carolina were not to be permanently disconnected from that Department, had created a better state of feeling among them. Gen. STEVENSON and Quartermaster SLAGHT, it was understood, would soon both be honorably released. Gen. HUNTER had held a grand review of all the troops from Gen. FOSTER's command. The health and spirits of the troops were good.

abstract: -- We noticed the fact, the other day, that the Territorial Government of New-Mexico had applied to Congress for compensation for 600 Indians who are there held in bondage, and who are liberated by the act abolishing Slavery in the Territories. We observe now that Kansas has applied to Congress to pay her Territorial debt, and that Minnesota has applied for compensation for damages inflicted by the Indians, and for pensions for those of her citizens who were wounded in the Sioux rebellion. Perhaps these latter claims are in themselves intrinsically just; but we could wish those States would not press them on the Treasury just at present. The Territorial debt of Kansas is a heavy one, and embraces compensation for the losses suffered by both parties in the Border-Ruffian war seven years ago. The claim will probably amount to a million dollars. The demands of the Minnesotians, if they were granted, would not fall short of another million.

abstract: -- We are glad to hear from Gen. HOOKER's headquarters that measures have been taken to prevent correspondents making developments injurious to the army and damaging to military plans. There has long been some system needed in this matter, and the Press has labored hard, but unsuccessfully, to obtain it. If the military authorities had at first instituted a plan, any reasonable plan whatever, for the guidance of army correspondents, it would have been loyally sustained by the whole Press. But in this matter, as in so many others, everything has been allowed to hang at loose ends, and, though just and feasible plans have been proposed, the Government has refused all along to adopt any one of them. Here correspondents have been flattered; there buffeted. Now an incompetent General, in order to conceal his imbecility, has expelled them all from his lines; and now another, equally incompetent, in order to show his genius, has unfolded to them his whole plan of campaign; while a third has seized and opened their letters, and, finding them too true, has destroyed them. In one department they have been allowed to publish movements in advance, while in another they have been prevented chronicling them after being executed. At one time facts have been disclosed which have aided the enemy; at another, facts have been suppressed which would have cheered and strengthened the nation. All this might have been remedied by a simple system for the guidance of correspondents and the Press in publishing military news.
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to hear from Gen. All this might have been remedied by a simple system for the guidance of correspondents and the Press in publishing military news.

abstract: Constitutionalism and the War; Benefits and Lessons of the War
snippet: Constitutionalism and the War; Benefits and Lessons of the War
lead_paragraph: When President LINCOLN declared that there was no line, crooked or straight, which could form a boundary between the conflicting States, he gave utterance to a truth so important, that it should never be lost sight of in thinking of our position, and so evident, that one has but to study the geography of the country to see its force. There is a great deal of talk about peace, about the impossibility of subduing the rebels, about the difficulty of getting recruits, the financial ruin of the country, &c., and this talk is calculated to demoralize both the people and the army; it is raising up false issues, and can result in nothing but a ruinous extension of the war.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship  Africa, wer have received advices from Europe to the 15th inst., two days later. The news is not specially important. Nothing newrelating to the American question had been developed.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Africa, wer have received advices from Europe to the 15th inst., two days later. The news is not specially important. Nothing newrelating to the American question had been developed. The address prepared by the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, in response to the contributions for the relief of the distress, received by the ship George Griswo[???]d, from New-York, was to be publicly presented to the Commander of that vessel, in the Concert Room of St. George's Hall, on the 16th of February. Some of the leading men of Liverpool were expected to take part in the proceedings, and a gratifying demonstration was looked for. The Liverpool mass meeting for the adoption of an address in support of President's LINCOLN's emancipation policy was to be held at the Amphitheatre in that town on the 19th of February. The Polish insurrection appears to be assuming more and more formidable proportions. A band of 2,000 insurgents had occupied Dibienka, upon the frontier of Dublin. The statement that the insurgents under LANGEWEIZ had suffered considerable losses proved exaggerated. His chief force, consisting of 5,000 men, was posted in the mountains of Krzyz. The Austrian Government had prohibited the exportation and carriage of arms and warlike stores across the frontier to Prussia. The Russian and Prussian Government showed great irritation against the Austrian Press on account of the sympathy it was manifesting for the Poles. It is stated that the Poles have intercepted letters to the Russian Ambassador at Berlin and Paris, accusing Austria of encouraging the Poles in their insurrection. It is also stated that the Poles have intercepted letters from the Grand Duke CONSTANTINE, stating his intention to pursue the same course of action he has hitherto pursued in the government of Poland. A Convention between Prussia and Russia, in reference to the Polish insurrection, was signed on the 8th inst. In the Liverpool Cotton market prices were without change. There was very little business doing in Breadstuffs, and Provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 92 1/8@93.

abstract: --A correspondent of the Boston Traveler writes from New-Orleans under date of Feb. 12:  "The troubles which I alluded to in one of my recent letters, between the negro regiment and our soldiers, at Baton Rouge, have not yet subsided, and among both officers and min. A large numbe of resignations have been sent in to headquarters on
lead_paragraph: --A correspondent of the Boston Traveler writes from New-Orleans under date of Feb. 12: "The troubles which I alluded to in one of my recent letters, between the negro regiment and our soldiers, at Baton Rouge, have not yet subsided, and among both officers and min. A large numbe of resignations have been sent in to headquarters on account of the presence of the Third Louisiana Native Guard, colored regiment, at Baton Rouge, and a spirit of insubordination prevails among nearly all the troops. This feeling of prejudice and bitter hatred extends to all the regiments, and is shared by the majority of the commissioned officers, who assert they will not participate in any engagement where negroes are placed in command as commissioned officers. Some of these officers have threatened to kill the first colored officer that offers to assume, in any way, military authority in their presence. I understand that Maj.-Gen. AUGUR and Brig.-Gen. GROVER, the latter now in command at Baton Rouge, do not approve of commissioning colored officers. Col. STAFFORD, of the First Louisia a colored regiment, and Col. J.A. NELSON, of the Third Louisiana Native Guard Regiment, are here in town to-day for the purpose of having an interview with Gen. BANKS on this important matter. The non-commissioned officers refuse to acknowledge the authority of their colored superiors, and our privates are extremely bitter in their avowals of hatred, and are determined to mutiny if these colored officers are not dismissed. I cannot understand why Government will persist in intruding upon our soldiers a measure so repulsive to their feelings, and one which is causing a great amount of demoralization and disaffection among our troops. It is understood that the Commander-in-Chief has already declined to appoint colored officers to the fourth negro regiment, now being raised in this city.

On the person of the prisoner were found name [???] burglar's tools, some of them of a [???] [???] and superior kind; also a note, of which the following is a copy. It is believed by those who are the best judges of the lands in which rogues do their business, that this note is an agreement made by one burglar with another.

abstract: -- The green-house at Mount Vernon was accidentally destroyed by fire on Wednesday morning. Fortunately, the building was one which in itself had no association with Gen. WASHINGTON, having been built by Judge WASHINGTON in 1817. The original green-house was burned about 1837. The plants were, unfortunately, nearly all destroyed, or very much injured. It is hoped, however, that the three old plants, the only ones valuable for their associations, may survive. There was no wind at the time, and the atmosphere was foggy -- consequently the fire did no further damage. -- Washington S[???], [???]27.

abstract: It is a remarkable fact, now well established and exceedingly gratifying, that, though the war has for two years seriously curtailed several important branches of trade and manufactures, and made, seemingly, heavy drafts upon the resources of this City and the cities upon either side of it, there has been less suffering from want of food and shelter among us during the present Winter than during any other Winter for several years before the war began. Who can have forgotten the long lines of unemployed hungry men who used to parade the streets, in the inclement seasons, during the occupancy of the Mayoralty Chair by FERNANDO WOOD, carrying banners upon which the inscription was, "Give us work or bread, or ourselves and our families must starve?" And who, with the public exhibitions of want made at that time fresh in their memories, can fail to compare the condition of those commonly called the poor this Winter, with the rebellion still unsubdued, favorably with their avowed condition then? But it is not alone with those who were wont to make their necessities publicly known that the change is marked and proportionately gratifying. The established institutions of charities have not had an increased demand upon their appropriations; our benevolent societies are in a prosperous condition, attending promptly and liberally to all the meritorious cases which come within their several particular spheres; private charities have not been drawn upon to the usual extent, and even those accustomed to solicit aline in stores and offices have decreased in number. In fact, a very large proportion of the time and money usually given in aid of the needy of the City during the Winter months, have, this Winter, been spent in providing clothing, food and needed delicacies for sick and wounded soldiers [???] he seat of war; and still the poor at home have, as we have said, been better fed and sheltered than as usual at this season of the year.

abstract: Regnart vs. Bredt.--This was a motion for a preliminary injunction. abstract: The letter from India, which we give in another column, throws a damper on the sanguine speculations of the British Press in regard to their expected supplies of colonial cotton. The opinion of the writer is clear
lead_paragraph: The letter from India, which we give in another column, throws a damper on the sanguine speculations of the British Press in regard to their expected supplies of colonial cotton. The opinion of the writer is clear and positive that India never will afford a supply of cotton to English manufactures. No sufficient reasons are assigned for this opinion, but undoubtedly the reasons are manifest enough to the writer, for he dwells in one of the best cotton-growing districts of India, and is fully acquainted with the process of culture in that country, and the unsuccessful efforts of the Government to improve and stimulate it.

abstract: Proclamation of the Provisional Governor
snippet: Proclamation of the Provisional Governor
lead_paragraph: The vile usurping Government, maddened by the opposition of the victims of its oppression, has resolved to give them a final blow--to seize many thousands of their bravest and most ardent defenders, to cloth them in the hated Muscovite uniform, and to send them thousands of miles away to lasting misery and destruction. Poland is neither able nor willing to submit unresistingly to this crushing outrage, and an energetic opposition to it is alone consonant with her duty to posterity. Bands of brave and self-sacrificing youths, penetrated with an ardent love for their country, an unbending faith in the justice and aid of Heaven, have sworn to cast off the accursed yoke or die. Let the whole Polish nation follow them.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted asking information of the Secretary of the Navy as to whether any officer of the Government has liberated prisoners captured by any naval officer, and restored captured property, on payment of money or other valuable consideration. A bill was introduced to pay for arming loyal citizen-troops organized in insurrectionary districts. The bill to enable the people of Colorado to form a State Government was postponed. The Conscription bill, as it came from the House, was then considered. During the proceedings Mr. SHERMAN, from the Committee of Conference on the Ways and Means bill, made a report relative to the Bank tax, which was concurred in. It provides for a tax of one per cent. on all circulation below the scale proposed by the House, two per cent. on all above, and one-fourth of one per cent. on deposits. A report was made from the Committee on Foreign Relations, regarding the question of foreign mediation. The report was unanimous, and deprecates any interference whatever, by any foreign nation, in our national difficulties. A bill was introduced for the purchase of the Stevens Battery. The report of the Committee of Conference on the Postal Reform bill was agreed to. The debate on the Conscription bill was continued at great length.

abstract: Address on Political, Civil and Physical Geography
snippet: Address on Political, Civil and Physical Geography
lead_paragraph: Prof. GUYOT, by special request, delivered an address before the teachers of New-York, on Friday evening, in the hall of the Board of Education, on his favorite topic -- not as a formal lecture, but with a view to give some of the results of his twenty-five years' experience as a public teacher. In allusion to the difficulties of teaching the science of geography, he criticised the general detect in geographical textbooks, in that they are so much filled with geology, minerology, and natural history. The science of geography is not accurately defined. True, we cannot fully apprehend the globe, and its geography, without in eluding all collateral sciences; for all science is a unit. There is but one great science. But in all special studies we must [???] ourselves to their central or main idea. We subdivide this study with descriptive geography, mathematical geography, physical geography, and civil or political geography. The particular study of the earth as one of the planets belongs to the astronomer. The mapping out of the earth, or physical geography, requires instrumental or mathematical knowledge.

abstract: -- Some time since, the females employed in the Government printing-office as press feeders, made a demand for an increase of their weekly salary. They were receiving, as we are informed, $5 per week, and demanded $1 per day. Their request for an advance not being complied with, yesterday morning these females, to the number of nearly twenty-five, refused to go to work, and appeared ready to oust out of the building any person who should dare to attempt to take their places. It is said considerable inconvenience was occasioned by the failure to print a bill for the Finance Committee of the Senate. During the day the girls were informed that their wages should be increased as much as demanded. This satisfied them, and they went to work as usual. -- Washington Chronicle, Feb. 19.

abstract: The cargoes of the prize schooners Maria, Belle, and W.H. Northrup were sold at auction yesterday, at the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn, by Mr. J.H. DRATER. Six barrels of copper as brought $3 25 a barrel; some damaged coffee brought thirty-three cents per pound; oil vitriol, $2 75 a carboy; muriatic acid, $4 25 a carboy, and nitric acid, $7 25 a carboy. Several barrels of tanners' oil was sold for ninety five cents per gallon. Small quantities of salt and cigars were also included in the sold cargoes.

abstract: This Commission met in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen, at 11 o'clock A.M. yesterday, for the purpose of organization. There were present Mayor OPDYKE, Comptroller BRENNAN, Aldermen BOOLE, OTTIWELL, HARDY and MITCHELL, and Councilmen HAYES, BRICE, REPPER and HAUGHTALIN. Absent: Aldermen HENRY and Councilman JONES, DAVID T. VALENTINE, Esq., the venerable Clerk of the Common Council, called to order; Mayor OPDYKE was elected President, Comptroller BRENNAN was elected Vice-President, and Alderman HARDY was elected Secretary. Messrs. BOOLE, OTTIWELL, JONES and BRICE were appointed a Committee to draft bye-laws and report them at the next meeting.

abstract: American Policy of England
snippet: American Policy of England
lead_paragraph: The recent debates in the British Parliament show a continued and persistent animosity toward us on the part of the Government and governing classes of England. In neither the "Queen's speech," nor any of the speeches on the address was a word uttered indicative of good will toward the Union. Her Majesty, indeed, is made to express the "deepest concern" because of the continuance of the desolating conflict still raging in America, but this "deepest concern" of the royal heart is evidently not on our account. Friendless as was the tone of the "royal speech," that of the speeches of noble lords and right-honorable gentlemen in the two houses, was still more so -- nay, positively hostile in most cases. All prophesied evil as the fate of the Republic, or were unmeasured in calumniating the conduct of our Government. Not a voice was raised to refute the slanderers -- no friendly advocate appeared to defend the sacred cause for which these States are battling.
headline: {'main': 'The American Policy of England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The American Policy of England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Address on Assuming Governorship; Rebel prospects in
snippet: Address on Assuming Governorship; Rebel prospects in
lead_paragraph: History furnishes few more despicable sights than those of rulers driven from the countries which they have oppressed, and seeking at hostile Courts for aid to enable them to regain the power they have forfeited. And there are not to be found more lamentable plaints than some which have come from these exiles. They are apt to be so full of malignity -- all the more contemptible for its impotence -- and of such assumptions of right and of power, that the exhibition is not very creditable to humanity.

abstract: Speech at Indianapolis Union Mass Meeting
snippet: Speech at Indianapolis Union Mass Meeting
lead_paragraph: In the Cincinnati papers, of Friday morning, we find reports of the great Union meeting held in Indianapolis on the previous day. It was a great success. Train after train swelled the vast assemblage, which filled the State House yard and overflowed into the streets. From 40,000 to 50,000 were upon the ground. Three stands were erected, and even these were insufficient to bring the masses within hearing distance of the speakers. The organization on the main stand was perfected by choosing Hon. JOSEPH A. WRIGHT, President. Hon. Caleb B. Smith, Gens. Dumont and Hascall, Cols. Carrington, Spooner, Harrison, Hines, Mullen and Spicely, and Hons. John A. Watson, Henry Secrist, Chas. W. Cat[???]cart, T.C. Slaughter and Judge Huff were among the Vice-Presidents.

abstract: During this month there will be two Criminal Courts in session -- the Sessions and the Oyer and Terminer -- both commencing to-day. Judge BARNARD will preside in the Oyer and Terminer and Judge MCCUNN in the Sessions. The trial of Dr. E.M. BROWN, of the Eighth-avenue abortion case, will take place in the Oyer and Terminer, commencing, probably, this week.

abstract: In the Senate on Saturday, petitions were presented for the improvement of the navigation of the Hudson. A bill was introduced providing payment of interest on canal drafts issued since 1860, and another to extend contracts for canal repairs. A bill was also introduced to repeal the New-York School Library act. Bills were then considered in Committee of the Whole until the adjournment.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, a resolution was adopted asking information of the Secretary of the Navy as to whether any officer of the Government has liberated prisoners captured by any naval officer, and restored captured property, on payment of money or other valuable consideration. A bill was introduced to pay for arming loyal citizen-troops organized in insurrectionary districts. The bill to enable the people of Colorado to form a State Government was postponed. The Conscription bill, as it came from the House, was then considered. During the proceedings Mr. SHERMAN, from the Committee of Conference on the Ways and Means bill, made a report relative to the Bank tax, which was concurred in. It provides for a tax of one per cent. on all circulation below the scale proposed by the House, two per cent. on all above, and one-fourth of one per cent. on deposits. A report was made from the Committee on Foreign Relations, regarding the question of foreign mediation. The report was unanimous, and deprecates any interference whatever, by any foreign nation, in our national difficulties. A bill was introduced for the purchase of the Stevens Battery. The report of the Committee of Conference on the Postal Reform bill was agreed to. The debate on the Conscription bill was continued at great length. The amendments of the House were finally agreed to, and the Senate, at 12 1/2 o'clock, adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, on Saturday, a resolution was adopted asking information of the Secretary of the Navy as to whether any officer of the Government has liberated prisoners captured by any naval officer, and restored captured property, on payment of money or other valuable consideration. abstract: Serenade to and Speech in New-York
snippet: Serenade to and Speech in New-York
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. SIGEL, who has been resting in this City for the past few days, was the recipient, on Saturday night, of a characteristic compliment at the hands of his fellow-countrymen. He has been repeatedly urged to accept of civic hospitalities, dinners, and all that sort of thing, since his arrival here, all of which he has studiously declined. On Saturday night he was induced by some friends to visit where was gathered a host of Teutonic citizens, male and female, who had been made aware of the honor which awaited them. Upon the General's entrance, accompanied by his Aids, Capts. KONHEIM, LYONS and DUTON, he was instantly recognized, when a scene of the wildest enthusiasm took place. Cheers succeeded cheers, in deafening chorus, and it was with difficulty that he could be gotten to the stage at the end of the Hall. In the meantime the news had spread with lightning rapidity through the neighborhood, and soon the vast Hall was crowded to excess. After a renewal of the congratulatory process of cheering, the General intimated a desire to say a few words to his old friends, and quiet being restored, spoke as follows:

abstract: Cincinnati Mass Meeting Against Copperhead Peace
snippet: Cincinnati Mass Meeting Against Copperhead Peace
lead_paragraph: A series of mass meetings has commenced in the different Western States, designed to evoke the popular sentiment on the recent protests of the soldiers against the peace movements of the Copperheads. The first was held in Cincinnati last week, on the WASHINGTON birthday anniversary. If this be, indeed, as is said, a real index of the Western feeling, there need no longer be a single apprehension that the West will in any extremity fail the Government. It was a splendid demonstration. The crowd was immense; the speakers such men as Governor MORTON and Ex-Governor WRIGHT, of Indiana, and Governor TOD and Ex-Governor DENNISON, of Ohio; the resolutions of the most uncompromising character; and the enthusiasm such as showed the popular heart to be all aglow with patriotic fire.

abstract: Its Correspondent "Truth and Courage" on the Mediation Correspondence
snippet: Its Correspondent "Truth and Courage" on the Mediation Correspondence
lead_paragraph: The Tribune notes, in a tone of complaint, that we have "made no effort, so far as appears, to ascertain the truth of the story told by its correspondent" about the secret and mysterious interview between the President and the French Minister, at which the former repudiated all responsibility for the language of Mr. SEWARD's recent dispatch to Mr. DAYTON. That's so. The story seemed to us so utterly preposterous, as to make inquiry ridiculous. The Tribune itself, in our opinion, don't believe a word of it. Besides, as Mr. SEWARD says expressly, with the President's concurrence, that "every word of the recent correspondence between his Department and Mr. DAYTON was read to or by the President, before it was sent," there is no necessity for any such inquiry.

abstract: Letters to Gens. Bragg and Johnston on Treatment of Prisoners

lead_paragraph: We present official correspondence from the Department of the Cumberland, showing the perfidy of the rebel authorities touching the violation of the flag of truce by Gen. BRAGG, in front of Nashville, in November last; the violation of the rights of war by the rebels, under Maj.-Gen. WHEELER, on the Cumberland River a few weeks ago, when Chaplain GADDIS was captured and also concerning the plunder of Federal prisoners, by the rebels, at the battle of Stones River.

abstract: The Surgeon-General would remind the Medical profession that some months since a medical officer was detailed by the Department to prepare the surgical history of the rebellion. It is intended that this history shall embrace, among other topics, the collected results of the gunshot injuries of the war, and of the operations performed for their relief.

abstract: The Demands of the
snippet: The Demands of the
lead_paragraph: One of the axioms of statecraft, in the seventeenth century, was that national unity was not possible without uniformity of religious belief; that a people who worshipped at different altars could not possibly form a strong and lasting political organization. It was this hallucination, even more than the promptings of bigotry, that led Louis XIV to crusade against the Huguenots; and one French historian, of our time has boldly maintained that the motto under which the Camisards were hunted down -- une foi, une loi, un roi -- is a sound political maxim as well as a touching royalist rallying cry.

abstract: We have advices from Port Royal to the 25th of February, by the arrival at this port of the steamship Arago. Preparations for the movement against the enemy were still in progress. All the iron-clads, excepting two, had arrived. The misunderstanding relative to Gen. FOSTER's forces had been arranged, and no more difficulty was apprehended. The troops taken into the Department of Gen. FOSTER were to be under Gen. HUNTER's command. Our correspondent gives an account of the arrest of a dangerous rebel spy at Port Royal, who went there from New-York in the Arago on her last trip.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Africa, we have received advices from Europe to the 15th inst., two days later. The news is not specially important. Nothing new relating to the American question had been developed. The address prepared by the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, in response to the contributions for the relief of the distress, received by the ship George Griswold, from New-York, was to be publicly presented to the Commander of that vessel, in the Concert Room of St. George's Hall, on the 16th of February. Some of the leading men of Liverpool were expected to take part in the proceedings, and a gratifying demonstration was looked for. The Liverpool mass meeting for the adoption of an address in support of President's LINCOLN's emancipation policy was to be held at the Amphitheatre in that town on the 19th of February. The Polish insurrection appears to be assuming more and more formidable proportions. A band of 2,000 insurgents had occupied Dibienka, upon the frontier of Dublin. The statement that the insurgents under LANGEWEIZ had suffered considerable losses proved exaggerated. His chief force, consisting of 5,000 men, was posted in the mountains of Krzyz. The Austrian Government had prohibited the exportation and carriage of arms and warlike stores across the frontier to Prussia. The Russian and Prussian Government showed great irritation against the Austrian Press on account of the sympathy it was manifesting for the Poles. It is stated that the Poles have intercepted letters to the Russian Ambassador at Berlin and Paris, accusing Austria of encouraging the Poles in their insurrection. It is also stated that the Poles have intercepted letters from the Grand Duke CONSTANTINE, stating his intention to pursue the same course of action he has hitherto pursued in the government of Poland. A Convention between Prussia and Russia, in reference to the Polish insurrection, was signed on the 8th inst. In the Liverpool Cotton market prices were without change. There was very little business doing in Breadstuffs, and Provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 92 7/8@93.

abstract: The topic of conversation in circles that are usually stirred by the announcements of managers is, of course, the approaching operatic season, at the Academy of Music, under Mr. MAX MARETZEK. The impression is general that it will be one of unusual brilliancy, and so far as the public is concerned there can hardly be a doubt that it will more than fulfill the expectations that have been formed of it. The artists are entirely new -- some of them preeminent la their profession -- all of them vouched for by Mr. MARETZEK, who is never mistaken when the question is one of voice merely. With a repertoire that includes three new operas, and the whole range of old ones, and a well-informed musician to attend to their production, it will be strange, indeed, if success does not await an effort so bold and praise worthy. The Academy will, undoubtedly, be well attended on every fine night of the season, but will the slight surplus obtained on these occasions be sufficient to protect the manager from loss when the weather is bad? We fear not. The ordinary prices are much too low for a complete company like Mr. MARETZEK's, especially at the present time, when artists expect to be paid in specie, and even then demand increased salaries. Mr. MARETZEK, who is always hopeful, and at the commencement of a season fond of indulging in balmy visions of crowded houses, has resolved not to make any addition to the usual prices of admission, and there, of course, the matter ends. Nothing but the weather will, we are sure, interfere with his prosperity, but in the Spring there is always much to be apprehended on tha: score. We cannot help regretting that a small addition was not made to the ordinary rates, so as to insure the maintenance of a good company and an able direction.

abstract: Congress; the Close of; the Hour of Action Come
snippet: Congress; the Close of; the Hour of Action Come
lead_paragraph: Without meaning to speak with the slightest disrespect of Congress, whose sessions will close day after to-morrow, we do, nevertheless, congratulate the country that its labors are about ended, and that Washington will soon be freed from the presence of law-makers. It is not because of anything that Congress has done or left undone that we have this feeling in regard to its adjournment. We will assume that our representatives have acted with fidelity and discretion, and that the country will hold them in respectful remembrance. But there is a time for all things, according to the preacher. There is a time to make laws and a time to enforce them.

He left New-York for the Capital yesterday.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock P.M., yesterday, and spent two hours in considering the City Appropriation bill for 1863, which was acted upon by sections, and adopted entire when completed.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock P.M., yesterday, and spent two hours in considering the City Appropriation bill for 1863, which was acted upon by sections, and adopted entire when completed. Various increased reductions were made. The item of $12,500 for constructing two new parks over the Harlem Railroad tunnel, between Thirty-second and Forty-second streets, and the item of $20,000 for continuing the work of laying-out the City north of One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street, were altogether stricken out. The items for station-houses and telegraph for the Police, and the item to pay the expenses of the Police Sanitary Squad, were also stricken out, but were incorporated under the head of "Public buildings, construction and repairs." As finally sent in to the Councilmen, the budget footed up $6,400,173 98. A message from the Mayor, vetoing the Fitz John Porter resolutions, was on the table, but it was not reached. It will be found in full in another column. The Mayor's main objections are that the condemnation of the verdict against the late Gen. Porter is revolutionary in character and disrespectful to the constituted authorities. The Board adjourned till 1 o'clock P.M., on next Monday.

abstract: night Miss CARLOTTA PATTI, assisted by an array of really eminent talent, will give a grand farewell concert at the Brooklyn Athenaeum. Miss PATTI is one of Brooklyn's prime favorites, and her appearance at the Philharmonic Concerts invariably adds several hundreds to the already overcrowded audience. She will shortly depart hence for Europe, and, as this will be the only opportunity afforded Brooklynites to hear the wonders of her voice, we bespeak for her a generous farewell.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented for the use of steam on the Brooklyn Central Railroad. A bill to authorize the construction of a railroad in Broadway and other avenues and streets of New-York, was introduced by Mr. CONNOLLY.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented for the use of steam on the Brooklyn Central Railroad. A bill to authorize the construction of a railroad in Broadway and other avenues and streets of New-York, was introduced by Mr. CONNOLLY. It is very comprehensive in its provisions. The bill relative to the Judges of the Court of Appeal's, and to amend the Divorce laws, were reported adversely. A number of bills were reported favorably -- among them one to authorize the Courts of Oyer and Terminer and General Sessions to grant new trials. The concurrent resolutions to amend the Constitution relative to the Court of Appeals were lost for want of a majority vote of all the Senators elected.

abstract: Blockade--The English Press on Futile Attempt to Break it
snippet: Blockade--The English Press on Futile Attempt to Break it
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that the English Ministerial Press takes such a sensible view of the great fiasco of INGRAHAM and BEAUREGARD in Charleston harbor on the 31st of January. The flaming news, which so greatly excited some folks here for a few hours, cooled down considerably in its passage across the sea; and John Bull cannot see that the unsuccessful attempt of a couple of rebel rams to capture a prize which lay almost within reach of their noses, constitutes a raising of the blockade of a port. The London Post says that "the suspension of the blockade for a few hours [it was never suspended for an instant] did not terminate it, nor did it impose upon the blockading power the necessity of giving fresh notice to neutral States of an intention to blockade;" and it adds, probably by authority, that the British Government will not require such notice. The Times takes the same view, but, better informed, says that "there was not even an intermission of the blockade."

abstract: Indianapolis, the Union Demonstration at
snippet: Indianapolis, the Union Demonstration at
lead_paragraph: The outpouring of the masses at the capital of Indiana, last Thursday, was marked with precisely the same enthusiastic and determined loyalty as gave such significance to the demonstration in Cincinnati three days previous. The speeches of Gov. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, and of Gov. WRIGHT, glowed with the intensest devotion. The resolutions had a ring in them no Copperhead could mistake. The whole demonstration chorded grandly with the response of Ohio; and we may rely upon it that the sky of every other Northwestern State is full of just such thunder.

abstract: of naval intelligence this morning -- one of them the destruction, by the rebel privateer Florida, of the fine ship Jacob Bell, from China to this port, with a cargo of tea valued at a million and a half of dollars; and the other the sinking by rebel rams of the Western Monitor Indianola on the Mississippi River. Both misfortunes are serious; the first on account of the great value of the ship's cargo and the additional discredit cast upon our Navy; and the other from the disturbance to the progress of military and naval operations on the Western waters that will be caused by the loss of the river Monitor.

abstract: a Word to Congress
snippet: a Word to Congress
lead_paragraph: An important bill in relation to prize property is reported to have passed the Senate yesterday. We presume it is the measure introduced by Senator (GRIMES on Saturday, an abstract of the provisions of which is in our telegraphic columns. Unless it has been altered, it will prove, we suspect, to be one of those monstrosities of legislation, of which the last hours of a session are apt to be so fruitful.

abstract: Art Association has attained its third season, and made itself an institution both desirable and permanent in the City of Churches. Its receptions, like those of this City, are noted for the choice collection of pictures, by native artists, which are tastefully arranged for the convenience of the visitors, and the elegance of the assemblages which, attracted by the exhibition of meritorious works, invariably throng the rooms. The Committee for the season 1862-'63 are Messrs. REGIS, GIGNOUX, JOUN WILLIAMSON and CHARLES CONGDON, artists, and gentlemen of recognized talent and taste, to whose good judgment and invariable industry the art-lovers of Brooklyn are already deeply indebted. The second reception of the season will be given to-night, at the Academy of Music.

abstract: Mr. Sumner's Resolution; Secretary Seward's Dispatches
snippet: Mr. Sumner's Resolution; Secretary Seward's Dispatches
lead_paragraph: The resolutions reported in the Senate by Mr. SUMNER, on the subject of Foreign Intervention in our affairs, are admirable. They leave nothing to be desired. They put the whole case clearly and strongly, and yet without the slightest passion, before the world, and give conclusive reasons why we cannot permit the interference, in any form, of any foreign nation, in the adjustment of our controversy with this rebellion. They admit the propriety of intervention where one nation is at war with another, and do full justice to the motives which lead foreign Powers to seek the termination of a war which inflicts such serious evils upon all mankind as that now raging between our Government and the rebel States: -- but they also declare the supreme necessity of crushing the rebellion, and that "any proposition from a foreign Power, whatever form it may take, having for its object the arrest of these efforts, is, just in proportion to its influence, an encouragement to the rebellion and to its declared principles, and on this account is calculated to prolong and embitter the conflict, to cause increased expenditures of blood and treasure, and to postpone the much desired day of peace;" and they sum up the whole matter by announcing that "Congress will be obliged to look upon any further attempt in the same direction as an unfriendly act, which it earnestly deprecates, to the end that nothing may occur abroad to strengthen the rebellion, or to weaken those relations of good will with foreign Powers which the United States are happy to cultivate."
headline: {'main': 'Foreign Intervention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Foreign Intervention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Evening Post on our Trade with; Evening Post on our Trade with California
snippet: Evening Post on our Trade with; Evening Post on our Trade with California
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post favors the transfer of the trade between New-York and California, now carried on in American vessels, to ships owned in England and sailing under the British flag. "We can go much cheaper," says the Post, "at the present time, in vessels of other countries than in our own, and with no risk of capture and detention" by rebel privateers: -- why, then, should we not do it? Why, we ask in turn, does the Post confine its reasoning to that particular route? Why not hand over all our commerce to foreign nations? Why have American vessels on the ocean at all, when British ships stand ready to take their place and relieve them from all risk of capture by rebel privateers? If the argument is good for the San Francisco route, it is just as good for the trade to Liverpool, to Havre, to Hamburg, to Canton, and to every other port on the surface of the globe. Every American ship that floats is exposed to peril; but must we surrender our commerce, the very life and soul of our national greatness, and crave the protection of a foreign flag, lest a vessel now and then should be destroyed?
headline: {'main': 'Our Trade with California.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Trade with California.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An adjourned meeting of this Society was held at Windust's Hotel, corner of Ann-street and Park-row, on Saturday evening, and was very largely attended by the members. This Society is organized on a national, social and intellectual basis, for the annual...
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of this Society was held at Windust's Hotel, corner of Ann-street and Park-row, on Saturday evening, and was very largely attended by the members. This Society is organized on a national, social and intellectual basis, for the annual celebration of the birthday of St. Patrick, and numbers some of the most respectable and influential Irish-American citizens of New-York and Brooklyn. Among those present at the meeting, on Saturday evening, were Capt. WM.F. LYONS, Capt. JOHN BUTLER, Mr. JOHN MCAULIFFE, Dr. JOHN F. FITZPATRICK, Mr. THOS. DUNPHY, Mr. THOS. B. CONNERY, Counselor HARTNETT, Alderman TIERNAN, of Brooklyn, and several other equally well-known gentlemen. The Society made most of the arrangements for the celebration of St. Patrick's Day, by a grand supper at one of the City hotels, and elected the following gentlemen as permanent officers: President -- Capt. JOHN M. BUTLER. Vice Presidents -- Thomas Dunphy and John McAuliffe. Secretary -- Capt. Wm.F. Lyons. Treasurer -- John McCracken. A constitution was also reported and adopted, together with a set of by-laws for the governance of the Society.

abstract: The funeral of the late Col. D.D. TOMPKINS took place at noon yesterday, at the residence of his family, No. 374 Henry-street, Brooklyn. The attendance was very large, in consequence of which many persons were unable to gain admittance. The street, for a distance of two blocks, was filled with people and carriages, and the stoops and windows of the dwellings opposite the house of mourning were crowded with spectators. The ceremonies were conducted by Rev. T.S. DROWNE, of St. Paul'sChurch, Brooklyn. The Episcopal service was observed. All present appeared deeply affected at the solemnity of the occasion, and many were moved to tears. The coffin was placed in the back parlor, and those who desired viewed the remains by passing in at one door of the apartment and going out at another. The coffin was of rosewood, with heavy silver plates, and bore an appropriate inscription. Prior to its being conveyed to the hearse it was dressed with the American colors, and upon the lid were laid the sword, belt and cap of the deceased. A wreath of delicate white flowers was also placed upon the top. The following military gentlemen were the pall-bearers: Gen. H. Brown, Col. S. Loomis, Col. A.B. Eaton, Maj. Van Vleet, Capt. Morgan, Capt. Stimson, Capt. Hodges and Dr. Campbell. The escort consisted of one company of infantry from Governor's Island, two companies of the Twelfth Infantry from Fort Hamilton, and one company of marines from the Navy-yard, the whole under command of Maj. PRINCE, of the Third Infantry. The procession was formed in the following order:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition, numerously signed, in favor of Mr. CONNOLLY'S Broadway Railroad bill, was presented. The bill to provide for the payment of interest on Canal drafts, protested for non-payment, was favorably reported; ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition, numerously signed, in favor of Mr. CONNOLLY'S Broadway Railroad bill, was presented. The bill to provide for the payment of interest on Canal drafts, protested for non-payment, was favorably reported; also, the bill to authorize the Canal Board to hear and determine the claims of contractors for damages. The bill amending the Assessment law was made a special order for to-day. A preamble and resolutions, offered by Mr. CONNOLLY, looking to a check on speculations in gold, were referred to a select Committee of Three. The Volunteer Bounty Tax bill was passed. The Chenango Canal Extension bill was then debated in Committee of the Whole until the adjournment.

abstract: And the Administration; the Mediation Dispatches
snippet: And the Administration; the Mediation Dispatches
lead_paragraph: The Tribune, speaking of the question whether the Secretary of State submits his dispatches for the President's approval, before they are sent, says: "We leave the TIMES to settle the question of veracity it has raised, or to get out of it as it best can by maintaining either one of its three propositions." This is cool -- even for the Tribune. It increases our respect for that excellent journal. We were not aware that we had raised any "question of veracity" -- or that any was pending. Will not the Tribune complete its information by making it more specific? What is the question thus raised? and who are the parties whose "veracity" is at issue?

abstract: -- We generally get our first news from the country stretching from a point a short distance below Memphis down to New-Orleans, through rebel sources. The rebels have taken advantage of this, from time to time, to send us news of disasters, which has subsequently been disproven, though it generally, for a time, found believers in the North. For four or five weeks past, we have had news, every now and then, of a repulse of Gen. BANKS' army at Port Hudson; but we know that, up to a late date, there had been no attack upon that point, and could have been no repulse.

abstract: Penal System in England
snippet: Penal System in England
lead_paragraph: England is in great trouble just now about her rogues. She has a large perennial crop of burglars, forgers, thieves, etc., and is puzzled to know what to do with them. Heretofore in her history, the way of disposing of such rascals was easy enough. There were many dark spots on the globe reached by English ships, to which they could be banished. The Bermudas, the American Colonies, Botany Bay, Van Dieman's Land, and numerous other benighted regions, have in turn served the purpose of punitive and penitential colonies, and by the horrors suffered there, the crimes of the worst of England's rogues have been atoned for.
headline: {'main': 'The English Penal System.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The English Penal System.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. MARETZEK'S season at this establishment will not commence until Friday next--the delay being necessitated by the nonarrival of Signor BELLINI.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK's season at this establishment will not commence until Friday next--the delay being necessitated by the nonarrival of Signor BELLINI. In the meantime, it is pleasant to hear that Mr. MARETZEK has fully completed his arrangements in the very important particulars of orchestra and chorus. It may not be generally known that there is a great scarcity of instrumental players and of chorus singers; and that this scarcity, in the case of Mr. MARETZEK, has been aggravated by the machinations of a previous empressario. Mr. MARETZEK has fortunately surmounted both difficulties, and is now prepared to give opera to the public in a way that it has not been given since he left the conductor's rostrum. VERDI's opera of "Il Trovatore" is selected for the opening night -- all the leading parts being sustained by artists who are ertirely new to our public.

abstract: Gen. Hooker's order
snippet: Gen. Hooker's order
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to hear of the success of the system inaugurated by Gen. HOOKER for supplying his army regularly with fresh bread. If we may judge of the style of ovens used by the pictures of them given in the illustrated papers they are simple and well contrived, and ought to turn out a good loaf or biscuit. There are professional bakers enough in every brigade of the army to work the matter, as well as the dough, properly. As each soldier is entitled to a pound loaf every other day, we suppose between sixty and seventy thousand loaves will be consumed per diem by the infantry, artillery and horse-marines under command of Gen. JOE HOOKER.

abstract: The session of the Senate on Monday night was continued until 4 o'clock, and ended in the adoption of the report of the Committee of Conference on the Indemnification bill, much to the surprise of the Copperheads, who were evidently "caught napping."
lead_paragraph: The session of the Senate on Monday night was continued until 4 o'clock, and ended in the adoption of the report of the Committee of Conference on the Indemnification bill, much to the surprise of the Copperheads, who were evidently "caught napping." When the Senate assembled again yesterday, an effort was made to have the journal corrected, the Copperheads insisting that the vote had not been fairly taken, but it was proved conclusively that the proceedings in the matter were perfectly correct, and the motion was not pushed. To make the matter certain, however, a test vote was taken on the question of recalling the bill from the House, and it was decided in the negative, 25 to 13. The bill to modify the existing laws for the collection of duties on imports was passed without amendment. The concurrent resolutions from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on mediation and intervention, were adopted after some debate, with only five dissenting votes -- Messrs. CARLILE of Virginia, LATHAM of California, POWELL of Kentucky, SAULSBURY of Delaware, and WALL of New-Jersey. The bill to establish a branch mint in Nevado Territory was passed. A Committee of Conference was appointed on the Internal Revenue bill. The Senate refused to take up the resolution to investigate the conduct of Col. GILBERT in dispersing the Copperhead Convention in Kentucky. The bill to incoporate the National Academy of Sciences was passed. A resolution was adopted requesting the President to appoint a day of national fasting and prayer. The bill to establish Provisional Governments in certain cases was called up. A motion by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, to lay it on the table was lost. It was, however, postponed. The bill for the admission of Nevada was passed. The bill to establish a Territorial Government for Montano, changing the name to Idaho, was also passed.

abstract: Meetings, lectures, , in favor of President LINCOLN'S emancipation policy, were of daily occurrence in variou parts of England, and an imposing demonstration was expected at the Amphitheatre at Liverpool, the day the Hibernian sailed. The resolutions and addresses to President LINCOLN, which are ...
lead_paragraph: Meetings, lectures, , in favor of President LINCOLN'S emancipation policy, were of daily occurrence in variou parts of England, and an imposing demonstration was expected at the Amphitheatre at Liverpool, the day the Hibernian sailed. The resolutions and addresses to President LINCOLN, which are to be proposed, emphatically approve of his Anti-Slavery policy. A crowded meeting on the subject was held at St. James Hall, London, on the 18th. The speakers indulged in bitter invectives against the Lord Mayor and Mr. MASON, for the late affair at the Mansion House banquet, and a resolution condemning the Lord Mayor was unanimously carried.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday morning, the bill to admit Nebraska as a State was taken up, but was not acted upon. An Executive Session was held from 2  to 4  o'clock, when a recess was taken until 10. On reassembling, the bill to provide for the election of members of Congress in Tennessee and Louisiana, was taken up, but the Copperheads ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday morning, the bill to admit Nebraska as a State was taken up, but was not acted upon. An Executive Session was held from 2 1/2 to 4 1/2 o'clock, when a recess was taken until 10. On reassembling, the bill to provide for the election of members of Congress in Tennessee and Louisiana, was taken up, but the Copperheads fillibustered to prevent action on it, and succeeded. No business, in fact, was done. At 12 o'clock, the President having notified the Senate that he had no further communications to make was declared adjourned sine die.

abstract: the case of and false charges against
snippet: the case of and false charges against
lead_paragraph: We have so often had occasion of late to call attention to the shortcomings and misconduct of military men, and to lament over the unprecedented leniency with which offences, dangerous both to the army and the country, have been treated, that it is even more than pleasant to have to chronicle the satisfactory result of the inquiry to which Gen. MCDOWELL voluntarily submitted his military career since the war began. The Court has acquitted him in the fullest manner of every charge that has been whispered against him, that in the least affected his honor or loyalty. They find him guilty of one trifling indiscretion, which an accident converted into an error, but acknowledge it to have been committed rather through an excess than a lack of zeal. They, however, bear ample and emphatic testimony to his possession of that spirit of strict subordination, and to that faithfulness in obeying his orders, which is the highest of all military virtues, but the one, unfortunately, to which too many of our officers and a very large portion of the public seem to attach least importance.
headline: {'main': 'The Case of Gen. McDowell.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Case of Gen. McDowell.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Richmond papers of the 2d inst., received in Washington, contain a telegram from Charleston, dated the day previous, announcing that the rebel steamer Nashville had run aground near Fort McAllister, in the Ogecehee River, and had been destroyed by our iron-clads. No particulars of the affair are given, but the Nashville was probably making an attempt to run the blockade. The dispatch asserts that the fort has not been captured, so the report of its capture, published in some papers, is probably untrue.

abstract: A large and very enthusiastic mass meeting of all different nationalities represented in this City, was held last evening at the Steuben House. The object of the meeting was to protest against the intervention of European monarchies in any of the American republics, to reaffirm the principles of the Monroe Doctrine, and to insist on their rigorous application by the Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: A large and very enthusiastic mass meeting of all different nationalities represented in this City, was held last evening at the Steuben House. The object of the meeting was to protest against the intervention of European monarchies in any of the American republics, to reaffirm the principles of the Monroe Doctrine, and to insist on their rigorous application by the Government of the United States. At an early hour the hall was crowded to overflowing by representatives from the four quarters of the heavens, and to ears unaccustomed to the confused din that speedily ensued, it must have seemed as if the days of Babel had returned. But it was gratifying to observe that the whole assembly, though speaking with many tongues, was of one heart and one mind.

abstract: Capt. P.H. WHITEBERRY, of the bark Golden Rule, which was captured and burnt by the rebel pirate Alabama off Hayti, arrived here yesterday in the brig Ocean Belle, Capt. PETTINGILL, from St. Domingo.
lead_paragraph: Capt. P.H. WHITEBERRY, of the bark Golden Rule, which was captured and burnt by the rebel pirate Alabama off Hayti, arrived here yesterday in the brig Ocean Belle, Capt. PETTINGILL, from St. Domingo. The Golden Rule belonged to the Panama Railroad Company, and left here for Panama with an assorted cargo, on the 17th of January. On the 26th, when about 40 miles south-southwest from Cape Taburone, Capt. WHITEBERRY discovered, at about 12 M., a steamer, which afterward proved to be the Alabama. She had the American ensign floating from her mizzengaff, and immediately steered toward the bark. When within half a mile she fired a blank shot, hauled down the American ensign and raised the rebel colors. She then sent a boat to the Golden Rule, with an order for Capt. WHITEBERRY to go on board the Alabama. The Captain complied with the order, and on reaching the pirate was invited into the cabin by Capt. SEMMES, where he was questioned about his vessel -- her destination, cargo, &c. SEMMES informed the Captain that he would be obliged to burn the bark, and gave permission to the crew to take each a bag of clothing with him on leaving the bark. The crew were all brought on board the Alabama and put in irons. Capt. WHITEBERRY, however, was allowed the liberty of the vessel. Before burning the Golden Rule, which was done at 9 P.M. the same day, the pirate took from her twelve or fifteen boat-loads of provisions, such as the Alabama stood in need of at the time. Capt. WHITEBERRY and his crew were landed in the city of San Domingo on the evening of the 28th of January. He gives the same account of his good treatment by the pirates, while on board their craft, as has often been given by other captives. With regard to the Alabama, Capt. WHITEBERRY does not think she is capable of that extraordinary speed for which she has got credit. The Captain desires to return his thanks to Capt. PETTINGILL, of the Ocean Belle, for kindness extended to him in his misfortunes.
headline: {'main': 'Capture of the Golden Rule by the Pirate; Alabama. STATEMENT OF CAPT. WHITEBERRY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Capture of the Golden Rule by the Pirate; Alabama. STATEMENT OF CAPT. WHITEBERRY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Friday (to-morrow) evening there is to be a meeting of the unconditional Loyalists of our City--of the men who are for sustaining the Government and preserving the Union against every attempt that may be made for their destruction, and at whatever sacrifice of property and of life may be required. The recent demonstrations of traitors in the midst ...
lead_paragraph: On Friday (to-morrow) evening there is to be a meeting of the unconditional Loyalists of our City -- of the men who are for sustaining the Government and preserving the Union against every attempt that may be made for their destruction, and at whatever sacrifice of property and of life may be required. The recent demonstrations of traitors in the midst of us -- their open proclamation of sympathy with rebels who seek the overthrow of the Government, and their undisguised hostility to the attempts of the Administration to protect and defend it -- render such a demonstration eminently proper and timely. Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT has consented to preside, and it is expected that JOSEPH HOLT, JOHN VAN BUREN, JAMES T. BRADY and other distinguished gentlemen will speak in support of the most vigorous prosecution of the war, and of every just and necessary measure that may be required to bring it to a triumphant close.

abstract: By the arrival of the New-York at this port, from Southampton on the 19th ult., and the Hibernian at Portland, from Liverpool on the 19th and Londonderry on the 20th, we have advices from Europe four days later than were received by the Kedar. British Parliamentary proceedings had been without much importance. Notice had been given in the British Parliament of intention to call for the correspondence between Mr. MASON, the rebel Commissioner, and the Government, relative to the recognition of the Confederate States. Mr. BENTINCK had asked for information regarding the alleged raising of the Charleston blockade, but Lord PALMERSTON had stated that he knew nothing not already published in the newspapers. It is asserted that the rebel authorities had already negotiated a portion of the loan offered them in Paris. Money had been received in England from Mobile to pay the interest on the Alabama State debt. Great emancipation demonstrations were being held throughout England. The London Times complains that the "grand old cause" of the Anti-Slavery and the Anti-Slave-trade movement has degenerated into a mere cat's-paw to Mr. SEWARD, and alludes to the report that Lord BROUGHAM earnestly entreated the new Emancipationists not to dishonor the old cause by carrying their recent address to Mr. ADAMS, the American Minister. The insurrection in Poland continued to spread, and had reached dimensions truly formidable. It is intimated that the French Emperor is not unfriendly to the cause of the insurgents, and is disposed to prevent any interference in the affair by Prussia. The Liverpool Cotton market was flat, and prices had declined correspondingly. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. The latest quotation in Consols is 93 3/4 for Money.

abstract: Compensated emancipation bills for; The Free Labor System in; the Case of Missouri
snippet: Compensated emancipation bills for; The Free Labor System in; the Case of Missouri
lead_paragraph: While so much has been done by Congress to sustain the Administration in its measures of national policy, there will be a regret felt by many that the bills providing for compensated emancipation of slaves in the States of Maryland and Missouri failed to become laws. No part of the President's policy for conducting the present war to an issue consistent with the interests of freedom and humanity has had a more prominent place, or, in all his messages, a more extended and earnest advocacy, than this scheme for ridding the Border States of Slavery. And it is not to be denied that the Government has received more applause from abroad on account of these persistent efforts of the President for a peaceful and humane solution of the Slavery question than on any other account whatever. In the Border States also, but more especially in Missouri, the Government was immensely strengthened by the liberal overtures of the President and Congress on this subject; for it must not be forgotten that Congress, by an almost unanimous vote, at a former session, indorsed and promised to carry out the President's plans. It is not wrong to assume that the late revolution in Missouri, which so unexpectedly but so decidedly threw that State into the hands of the Emancipationists, was in a great measure brought about by the acceptability of the President's scheme for the removal of Slavery.

abstract: Congress; End of the 37th
snippet: Congress; End of the 37th
lead_paragraph: The Thirty-seventh Congress has ceased to exist. It rests from its labors, and its works will follow it. None of its predecessors had such vast responsibilities; and yet, take it all in all, it may be truly said, that not one of them fulfilled its appropriate duties more faithfully and honorably.

abstract: The Municipal Harbor Defence Commission held their third meeting yesterday, when the Bye-laws Committee presented a series of regulations for the Commission, which were received and adopted. They provide, among other things, for Standing Committees of four each on the subjects of "Water Defences," "Land Defences," "Ordnance," and "Conference and Correspondence." A discussion was had as to the best plan of action. Comptroller BRENNAN wished to give everybody a hearing who had ideas to express and plans to unfold in aid of their work. Councilman JONES wanted only the views of practical men, having a horror of the theories of inventors, who were already besieging him at his office. Alderman BOOLE wanted "the men of brains of the town "before them, who would afford them valuable views of the various methods of defence now in use. It was finally agreed that each member should invite one gentleman to lay his views before them at their next meeting. The Mayor named Admiral PAULDING, the Comptroller named Gen. MCCLELLAN, Mr. JONES named Chief-Engineer CRAVEN, of the Croton Department; Mr. HOUGHTALIN named Capt. ERICSSON, Mr. BOOLE named WM.H. WEBB, Esq., and Mr. HARDY named Col. RICHARD DELAFIELD. No others were named. Adjourned till 6 o'clock P.M., on next Monday.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to authorize the making of sidewalks and the planting of shade-trees along the highways of the State, was reported favorably; also, the bill authorizing the Courts of Oyer and Terminer and General Sessions to grant new trials; also, the bills legalizing acts of the Corporation of New-York relating to volunteers. The latter were immediately passed. A majority report was made in favor of allowing dummy engines on the Brooklyn Central Railroad. Notice was given that a minority report would be presented. Among the bills introduced was one to extend the time for the collection of taxes to the 1st of June, 1863.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to authorize the making of sidewalks and the planting of shade-trees along the highways of the State, was reported favorably; also, the bill authorizing the Courts of Oyer and Terminer and General Sessions to grant new trials; also, the bills legalizing acts of the Corporation of New-York relating to volunteers. The latter were immediately passed. A majority report was made in favor of allowing dummy engines on the Brooklyn Central Railroad. Notice was given that a minority report would be presented. Among the bills introduced was one to extend the time for the collection of taxes to the 1st of June, 1863.

abstract: Some additional particulars of the capture of the Indianola have been received. When she was attacked, the advantage was on the side of the rebel rams. The Indianola moved slowly, compared with them. They kept clear of her bow, where her best guns were, and butted the sides and stern.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI, Thursday, March 5.

abstract: THE DUMMY ENGINE. -- The citizens of East New-York -- being at the termination of Atlantic-avenue, upon which it is proposed to run the dummy engine, and against which the property-owners along the route protest -- held a meeting at the Howard House on Wednesday evening, over which Mr. C.R. MILLER presided. The discussion on the subject of the dummy was free to all sides, and views were expressed for and against. At the conclusion, a series of resolutions were adopted favorable to the dummy. The resolutions are to be sent to the members of the Legislature from Kings County and to the Aldermen of the City of Brooklyn.

abstract: Medical College Commencement
snippet: Medical College Commencement
lead_paragraph: The second Annual Commencement of Bellevue Hospital Medical College took place last evening at Irving Hall, in the presence of one of the most brilliant audiences ever assembled within the walls of that famous and favorite edifice. The platform was occupied by Messrs. DRAPER, NICHOLSON, GRINNELL and BILL, Commissioners of Charities and Correction; Rev. Archbishop HUGHES and other distinguished members of the Trustees; Dr. ISAAC E. TAYLOR and the members of the Faculty -- all of whom took their seats over half an hour after the time appointed for commencing the exercises.

LUNT.

abstract: And the Copperheads
snippet: And the Copperheads
lead_paragraph: The Copperheads, small in number, in both branches of Congress, refused to vote for the resolutions against foreign interference. They all went either plumply against them, or dodged. This thing should be noted. It is another illustration of the lack of national feeling which marks all this creeping, cold-blooded breed.

abstract: The enemy under VAN DORN advanced again toward Franklin yesterday. The Federal force also advanced six miles and drove the rebels back. Two men were wounded. The rebels lost 13 killed. The fight was renewed this morning. No particulars have been received.

abstract: Trade as a Union Agency
snippet: Trade as a Union Agency
lead_paragraph: An effort was made in the closing hours of Congress to obtain authority for the Secretary of the Treasury to seize, through his agents, cotton and such other products of the seceded States as might fall within the lines of our advancing armies. The property thus seized was to be held, in the name of the Government and sold for its benefit. Hereafter, if the owners of this properly should establish their character for loyalty to the United States, the value thereof was to be paid to them.

abstract: Garrison vs. Kelly, Sheriff; Wrongful Detention of Horse
snippet: Garrison vs. Kelly, Sheriff; Wrongful Detention of Horse
lead_paragraph: William Garrison vs. John Kelly, Sheriff, &c. -- was an action brought by the plaintiff against the late Sheriff for the alleged wrongful detention of a roan horse, of the value of $250, of which the plaintiff claims to be the owner, and which the Sheriff seized on an execution in an action brought in the Superior Court, by one James Brien against James Garrison and Andrew C. Garrison. Judgment was obtained in that action on or about the 12th day of May, 1855, in favor of said James Brien for the sum of $343, and execution was issued against the said James and Andrew C. Garrison, which was delivered to the defendant in this suit, and the sum of $343, with interest, being due upon said judgment, the defendant, to satisfy the judgment, seized upon the personal property of the judgment debtors.

abstract: Neutrality--Privateers and Arms Supplied the Rebels
snippet: Neutrality--Privateers and Arms Supplied the Rebels
lead_paragraph: There was some very strong talk at the Chamber of Commerce meeting, yesterday, concerning the British pirates who are now using the rebel flag to destroy American commerce on the waters of our own coast, as well as on every sea of the globe. The recent accounts we have published from London journals make it appear that the matter is likely soon to assume a far more formidable and flagitious character than it has at present. It would be impossible for the commercial marine of any nation to exist for three months in the face of the warlike naval force that is now being fitted up in English ports for the "Emperor of China," alias JEFF. DAVIS. The cotton bonds, and mortgages upon the Southern cotton crop, are the means used to pay for these ships, while the prospect of plunder and the love of lawless adventure will always be a sufficient inducement for British sailors to man them. We must primarily look for redress in this business, and for its prevention, to our own skill and resources; but our Government must not fail to persistently press upon the British authorities some regard for that neutrality of which they perfidiously boast. The British Government can no longer pretend that it does not officially know the facts; for our Minister to their Court has taken care that this prefence shall be no longer tenable. Mr. TAYLOR, member of Parliament from Leicester, truly said that if the Mexicans were to go to England to purchase vessels to prey upon French commerce, nobody doubted that the British Government would detect the fact, and very quickly put a stop to the negotiations or to the career of any such vessel that might attempt to get to sea. And they would be as careful in their dealings with us if they had the same wholesome respect of our power.

abstract: We trust that the Union meeting in this City to-night will, in its magnitude and in its spirit, be worthy to take rank with the recent magnificent popular demonstrations in Cincinnati, Indianapolis, and other cities of the Northwest.
lead_paragraph: We trust that the Union meeting in this City to-night will, in its magnitude and in its spirit, be worthy to take rank with the recent magnificent popular demonstrations in Cincinnati, Indianapolis, and other cities of the Northwest. That section of our common country, which some had accused of being weary of battling for the Union, and ready to strike hands with the traitors, has just shown anew that she still stands undaunted, defiant, determined, full of vitality and enthusiasm as at first, but with that enthusiasm grown twice sacred, and stern as death. The battle-scarred soldiers there have spoken, regiment by regiment, and they have spoken as they have always fought; the chief Generals have spoken, and their words "were half battles;" States and cities have spoken, and the voices from the peaceful fields have reechoed the loyal shouts from the field of war. The Copperheads have crept to their holes in dismay, and their hissing is now scarce heard.

abstract: A mass meeting of loyalists of all parties will be held to-night at the Cooper Institute, for the purpose of exhibiting to the country at large and all the rest of mankind the true sentiment of the people of this City, their love for their country, and their detestation of its copperheaded traitors. The venerable and patriotic WINFIELD SCOTT will preside, and from every party orators of the first grade will sound the trumpet-note of love for the nation and honor to its flag.

abstract: Tax Law Amendments
snippet: Tax Law Amendments
lead_paragraph: We present, in another portion of this morning's issue, a conveniently arranged table of the amended rates of internal duty. The law passed last Summer has been found defective in some particulars, and the rates of duty imposed by it disadvantageous to the Govermnent. The Act took effect on the first of last September and the six months of its operation which have since passed have served to suggest the modifications embodied in the amendatory act. A glance at the table will show the reader that the changes in the rates of taxation are quite numerous and important. In addition to the alterations there noted, some have been made in sections relating to the duties of the Government officers and of the persons taxed. One of the most important of the new provisions imposes a severe penalty on those who do not pay the license tax required of them by law. The section referred to reads as follows:

abstract: A SUGGESTON TO LANDLORDS--The approach of the 1st of May already begins to be heralded by the omnipresence of those disagreeable words "to let," which one sees on almost every other dwelling in this City and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A SUGGESTON TO LANDLORDS. -- The approach of the 1st of May already begins to be heralded by the omnipresence of those disagreeable words "to let," which one sees on almost every other dwelling in this City and Brooklyn. If landlords will only adopt the suggestion which has often been made but rarely followed, of stating upon their rent-bulletins the price which they ask instead of putting house-hunters to the trouble of traveling a mile to see some agent, or requiring the inmates to answer the doorbell fifty times a day, they will accommodate all parties concerned, and be quite as likely to dispose of their houses as by following the old custom.
