abstract: On Wednesday, Dr. MCDOUGALL, Medical Inspector of the Department of the East, accompanied by Dr. J.L. SMITH, of Bedloe's Island Hospital, and Drs. PURDY and CADY, of the hospital at Fort Schuyler, proceeded to David's Island, on the Government steamer Thomas P. Way, for the purpose of inspecting the army hospital at that place. The party were received by Dr. J. SIMMONS, the surgeon in charge, and by him conducted through the various buildings. An elaborate description of this institution, and the systematic manner in which the duties are performed, have already been published at length in the columns of the TIMES. Within the past three months, some important additions have been made, and numerous improvements introduced. A neat and commodious chapel has just been completed which goes far to enhance the attractive features of the premises. The chaplain, Mr. LOWRY, has won the esteem of all by his assiduous and well-timed efforts. A glee-club, composed of convalescents, has been formed since the first of the year. There is a skating pond on the Island, which was covered yesterday with hundreds of happy and joyous soldiers. It would be naturally supposed by the unacquainted that at such a place there could be little use for a fire-engine. But when he considers the numerous buildings and belongings to the Hospital, the necessity for such an apparatus will be perceived. There is now a regularly organized Fire Company, who have been provided by Government with an engine. Yesterday, the men appeared in red shirts and performed the evolutions of a drill, much to the amusement and satisfaction of the spectators. The Hospital is situated seven miles above Fort Schuyler on the East River, and has accommodations for 3,000 patients. The patients number, at present, 700. The larger proportion are sick -- a very few suffering from wounds. Each ward is provided with a kitchen, besides which, there are four volunteer kitchens, from which are dispensed on a surgeon's order, the delicacies and favorite dishes sent in by friends or the institution. There has not been a single death in the Hospital during the past six weeks. The patients are cheerful, contented and happy. Numerous wells have been [???]g on the island, by means of which a copious supply of water is furnished all the wards: Dr. SIMMONS is assisted by fourteen other surgeons, Dr. MCDOUGALL made a thorough examination of every portion of the institution, and was favorably impressed with the general management.

abstract: Yesterday Dr. MCDOUGALL extended his tour of hospital inspection to the institutions at Newark. The examination commenced with the large hospital in close proximity to the railroad depot. The building, formerly used as a tanning and currying establishment, was at first engaged for hospital purposes by the patriotic citizens of the place, but about seven months ago was taken off their hands by the Government. At one time last Summer it contained 700 patients, which is the full complement. The number of patients now within the institution is 120. They are nearly all convalescent, and in a short time will rejoin their regiments. The building contains three spacious wards comprising the upper stories, the first floor being used for offices and laboratories. The wards are well ventilated, which is a great consideration when so large a space is occupied, and are supplied with a sufficient quantity of water, which is forced into tanks on the upper floor by means of a steam engine.

abstract: The March term of this Court opened this morning. After the return of process, Judge BETTS announced to the Bar that the calendar would be culled to-morrow, peremptorily, ten cases being put upon the calendar for the day; that if any prize cases were prepared for hearing during the term, they would go on the calendar and be called in their order; that no engagement of counsel elsewhere would be taken as an excuse; that the members of the Bar would have an oppartunity to try every case on the calendar, but when the case was called, the Court would take no excuse, except sickness or some other overpowering reason, for the case going off.

abstract: Up or Down; Herald, N. Y., Financial Extremes of the
snippet: Up or Down; Herald, N. Y., Financial Extremes of the
lead_paragraph: Our neighbor, the Herald, whose financial and editorial columns labored, a few days since, to prove that the Government has created a paper expansion of thirteen hundred and odd millions, suddenly discovered yesterday, on the fall of five per cent, in Gold, that "the day of specie payments is not far distant." This transition is so sudden and extreme, that we shall not be surprised to read in the same journal this morning that on the further break down of ten per cent. in gold, the day for specie payments has actually arrived.

abstract: Gold has fallen--slightly. Yesterday was the day on which it fell, and to-day is the day on which it will continue to do so some more. Had Gen. WASHINGTON, or any other man twenty years deceased, been permitted to walk William-street yesterday, between the hours of 10 A.M. and 3 P.M., he
lead_paragraph: Gold has fallen -- slightly. Yesterday was the day on which it fell, and to-day is the day on which it will continue to do so some more. Had Gen. WASHINGTON, or any other man twenty years deceased, been permitted to walk William-street yesterday, between the hours of 10 A.M. and 3 P.M., he would have opened his eyes in astonishment, and shut them in despair. Such a people he would think never before existed, and such insanity was never yet seen outside of a mad-house.

abstract: The Government, our Washington correspondent says, is still without any authentic information from either Vicksburgh, Charleston or Savannah. There is probably, therefore, no truth in the reports which have been put in circulation, of important operations at these points.
lead_paragraph: The Government, our Washington correspondent says, is still without any authentic information from either Vicksburgh, Charleston or Savannah. There is probably, therefore, no truth in the reports which have been put in circulation, of important operations at these points. In the face of this, however, the Washington Star states positively that Maj.-Gen. DIX telegraphed the President on Tuesday evening, staling that rebel papers had been received at Fortress Monroe, containing the important intelligence that Fort McAllister had fallen into the hands of the Union forces. The Washington Republican is equally positive in its assertion that such a telegram was received by the President.

abstract: Quite an excitement was occasioned last Tuesday, among importers and brokers, by the refusal of the Cashier at the Custom-House to receive the postage currency in payment of small suins of duty. Since the first issue of the currency, it has been customary to receive it for all sums of duty under five dollars, in accordance with that provision of the law
lead_paragraph: Quite an excitement was occasioned last Tuesday, among importers and brokers, by the refusal of the Cashier at the Custom-House to receive the postage currency in payment of small suins of duty. Since the first issue of the currency, it has been customary to receive it for all sums of duty under five dollars, in accordance with that provision of the law authorizing its issue, which made them "receivable in payment of all dues to the United States less than five dollars." For some time past the premium on gold and Demand Notes has been so great, that merchants doing a large importing business have found it considerably to their advantage to avail of the privilege heretofore accorded them of using the postage currency in the payment of small sums. On every entry which passes the Custom-house, fees are to be paid which are in all cases under $5. In payment of these the notes have been very convenient. The Cashier does not refuse, however, to receive the notes in payment of these fees. His orders from the Collector were to "receive no more postage currency for duty." It often happens that the importer will be required to pay such a sum that it is necessary to use small coin or fractional notes to make the exact amount. Persons familiar with the law under which the postage currency was issued at first believed that the order against receiving it for duties only applied to large sums, when importers desired to pay a portion of that sum in currency. For instance: an importer wishes to pay duty amounting to $344 25. Until Tuesday he would pay $340 in gold or demand notes, and $4 25 in postage currency. It was believed that the order was issued merely to enforce the payment of the whole sum in gold or demand notes. The law makes the currency receivable in payment of all dues to the United States less than $5, and it was said in support of the supposed decision of the Collector, not to receive it in such a case as the above, that the total sum of duty could not be divided: that $344 25 was the amount to be paid, and certainly that was not less than $5. The decision of the Collector, however, was not confined to such a case as the above. If an imposter wishes to pay $4 25 as the entire duty on any single entry, he must now pay it in gold or silver, the Collector's decision be sustained.

abstract: United States vs. Florida, steamer; Prize
snippet: United States vs. Florida, steamer; Prize
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Florida. -- This vessel was captured by the Matthew Vassar, on Jan. 11, 1863, at sea, near Little River Inlet, off the coast of North Carolina. No one appeared to defend the suit. The vessel was a British vessel, with a register to H.R. Saunders, of Nassau. She had on board a clearance at Nassau for Beaufort. The master of the vessel testified that he had bought the vessel, he being a resident of North Carolina, and that the real voyage was from Nassau to any port of North Carolina he could get into.

abstract: The remarkable occurrences of the past two days in Wall-street, involving the decline of nearly twenty per cent, in the nominal value of gold, are of prodigious interest to the country.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable occurrences of the past two days in Wall-street, involving the decline of nearly twenty per cent, in the nominal value of gold, are of prodigious interest to the country. The effect of the decline on the habitues of Wall and William streets is of comparatively little moment. It will be disastrous to those who have sold to deliver gold that they never had; but it will be equally a godsend to those who have bought gold that they never had means to pay for. The settling of the differences will make one side poorer, but the other side by exactly an equal amount richer. There the matter ends. The country at large is neither richer nor poorer on account of the losses and gains by speculation at the Stock Board.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. MARETZEK'S season will commence to-night, the opera being "H. Trovatore." It is rather a prodigal work to open with, inasmuch as it introduces nearly all the new artists of the company, and in that respect vio lates a rule of the musical HOFLE, which says that trump cards should be played separately.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK's season will commence to-night, the opera being "H. Trovatore." It is rather a prodigal work to open with, inasmuch as it introduces nearly all the new artists of the company, and in that respect vio lates a rule of the musical HOFLE, which says that trump cards should be played separately. The cast is certainly one of the best we have ever had in this City, and from its absolute freshness must interest even those who are weary of the work itself. It may be added too that for the first time the whole of the opera will be played, without cuts and without interpolations.

abstract: A well-concocted scheme to swindle the public by means of counterfeit $5 notes, purporting to have been issued by "The Highland Bank, of Hudson City," New-Jersey, was discovered on Tuesday night last in the Eighth Ward. About thirty of these notes were passed off upon shopkeepers and various retail dealers, in the neighborhood of Greene, Spring, Prince and Broome streets, before the fraud was discovered. A well-dressed young man, who gives his name as GEORGE MCDOUGAL, very prepossessing in his appearance, and, from his conversational powers, a man of education, was taken into custody by officer SHERWOOD, of the Eighth Precinct, at a late hour on Tuesday night, charged with being the ringleader among the counterfeiters.

abstract: down in San Salvador. That country is in trouble with the neighboring State of Guatemala, and in one week has called into the field and equipped seven thousand troops to meet the enemy. No debt is to be incurred for the war; the people are to pay the taxes for its prosecution monthly, and the soldiers get their pay every day. Our correspondent writes that one of the Senators remarked to him, "we have no debating in the Legislature, because the question of sustaining the Government is one on which there is no difference of opinion." That is certainly a very charming financial, political and military state of affairs. Such unanimity, promptitude and happy dispatch is not likely ever to be reached in the United States. Our late Congress did well: our Secretary of the Treasury and our Secretary of War doubtless do their best; but they can each and all learn a lesson by studying the style and spirit of the patriotic San Salvadorians.

abstract: The meeting at Cooper Institute last night was a magnificent manifestation of the unconditional loyalty of the City of New-York. It was, in every respect, a splendid triumph of national sentiment over partisan feeling and ...
lead_paragraph: The meeting at Cooper Institute last night was a magnificent manifestation of the unconditional loyalty of the City of New-York. It was, in every respect, a splendid triumph of national sentiment over partisan feeling and personal differences on subordinate matters. The hall was packed to its utmost capacity at a very early hour, and a meeting quite as large was organized outside. The audience was mainly, as a matter of course, made up of the supporters of the Administration; but there were also present a very large number of those who have hitherto acted with the Democratic party. Gen. SCOTT was prevented from presiding, by sudden indisposition at the last moment.

abstract: THE EVER-CHANGING TOPOGRAPHY OF THE UNITED STATES. -- Dr. R.P. STEVENS read an interesting paper before the Geographical Society Thursday evening, in the Society's Rooms, Clinton Hall. The peculiarity of the subject attracted as large an audience as could be seated, and the manner in which it was treated made it the most curiously interesting lecture which has been delivered before the Society for a long time. The Doctor in stating the results of researches in which the facts had been obtained upon which he founded his speculations, did not confine himself to the United States. He noted topographical changes in many parts of the globe -- changes so great that where great bodies of water had once flowed, there are now vast plains, clothed with richest verdure, hills, &c., where once they were not, and many other changes equally marked; and then came to speculations upon the future of this continent, many portions of which, at a remote period, are to have an elevation of some six hundred feet, and consequently will be materially changed in surface and general characteristics. Many portions now separated by water are to be united; and among other important movements. New-York Bay is to be situated some 80 miles southeast of Sandy Hook. A vote of thanks was given to the Doctor, and after some appropriate remarks from Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, the meeting separated.
lead_paragraph: THE EVER-CHANGING TOPOGRAPHY OF THE UNITED STATES. -- Dr. R.P. Many portions now separated by water are to be united; and among other important movements. New-York Bay is to be situated some 80 miles southeast of Sandy Hook. abstract: The Polish Revolution
snippet: The Polish Revolution
lead_paragraph: movement now deserves that name -- appears to be rapidly growing in magnitude. There is evidently great fear of its spreading both among the Prussian and Austrian Poles; and the Convention which has been entered into between Prussia and Russia doubtless provides for the joint action of those Powers in the matter. Lord Palmerston said in Parliament that the only agreement between Russia and Prussia of which the British Government knew was one by which the troops of one party should be allowed to pursue insurgents into the territory of the other; but there are indications that the double-headed alliance has wider bearings than this. Earl RUSSELL said that Austria had declared her intention to be perfectly neutral -- which is likely to be the case as long as her own dominions are undisturbed. It appears very likely before the trouble is settled that it will pervade all the three Powers that hold Polish territory, and may involve complications between all the five great European Powers.

abstract: No one of the ancient Hebraic celebrities holds a more absolute sway in the affections of the Jews of this day than Esther, the beautiful and pious spouse of Ahasuerus. In comemoration of the signal service rendered by that estimable lady to her ...
lead_paragraph: No one of the ancient Hebraic celebrities holds a more absolute sway in the affections of the Jews of this day than Esther, the beautiful and pious spouse of Ahasuerus. In comemoration of the signal service rendered by that estimable lady to her nation, on the occasion of the timely elevation of Haman, the envious enemy of her uncle Mordecai, whose daily place of rest was in the neighborhood of the King's gate, the Jewish people yearly observe the Feast of Purim. In this City, the first grand ball of the Purim Association was given last year, with marked success, and the second was given on Thursday night, at the Academy of Music. The building was very elegantly and tastefully decorated and most brilliantly illuminated, the floor was laid for dancing, and the usual magnificence of the Academy incredibly enhanced.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Arabia at Halifax, yesterday, we have advices from Europe two days later than by the Hibernian. She left Liverpool on the 21st, and Queenstown on the 22d ult.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Arabia at Halifax, yesterday, we have advices from Europe two days later than by the Hibernian. She left Liverpool on the 21st, and Queenstown on the 22d ult. It was reported by the Captain of a vessel which had arrived at Gibraltar, that on the 9th ult. he passed a steamer which he supposed to be the Alabama, and that on the next day a naval battle took place within five miles of him, the cannonading being distinctly heard, and the flashes of the guns observed. It is supposed to have been an engagement between the Alabama and a United States vessel. The latitude and longitude are not given. The emancipation demonstrations continued in England, and were very fully attended. The feeling in favor of the North appeared to be strengthening every day. The story of the rebel loan having been negotiated is again reiterated by the London Times, but its correctness was doubted in some quarters. The Polish question was the leading political theme in Europe. France had sent a dispatch to Berlin, expressing great dissatisfaction with the intervention of Prussia in the affairs of Poland. In debate in the British House of Lords, Earl RUSSELL denounced the course of Russia in regard to conscriptions. It was rumored that M. FOULD had tendered his resignation as the French Minister of Finance. The Liverpool Cotton market closed dull on Saturday, at unchanged rates. The sales amounted to 2,000 bales. The advices per the Australasian were not received until after business hours. The Cotton market then became very excited, and closed 1d.@2d. higher, with large sales. Breadstuffs were very dull, but unchanged and steady. Provisions were also very dull. Consols closed at 92 3/8@92 1/2 for money.

abstract: The National, and the Nation's Expectations
snippet: The National, and the Nation's Expectations
lead_paragraph: Those who imagined that Gen. HOOKER was going to rush headlong to Richmond as soon as he took command of the army, have been disappointed. It is forty days since HOOKER succeeded BURNSIDE, and, excepting a few skirmishes and the change of base of a single army corps, all has been ceaselessly quiet on the Rappahannock. Neither are there any evidences, so far as is known, of any immediate attack on the rebel army, or movement against the rebel capital. On banks of the river, deep in mud and mire, lie the two great hostile forces, each quite ready to resist any offensive action of the other, but neither of them able to assume the aggressive.

abstract: -- They are apt and quick in giving characteristic nicknames out West. Gen. LOGAN, who with his Division is at work on the Lake Providence Cut-off, west of the Mississippi, took occasion of WASHINGTON's Birthday anniversary to deliver a speech to his men. He spoke in the strongest terms of denunciation of the peace-preachers, and characterized them as "Gophers," or the "Gopher party." The name is good, and is likely to become as popular in the West as Copperhead has been. The gopher is an undermining, burrowing, mischievous animal, with sharp curved claws. They are very injurious to vegetation, and their character and habits are not commendable. The naturalist SAY styles the common Western variety pseudostoma, or "false mouth." The undermining of public confidence, of faith in the army, in the Union, and the Government, is the characteristic work of the secesh gophers, while the "false mouth" is their universal characteristic.

abstract: The fighting spoken of in yesterday's TIMES as going on south of Franklin, Tenn., on Thursday. proves to have been between a brigade commanded by Col. COBURN, consisting of three regiments of infantry, about five hundred cavalry and one pattery, and the entire command of the rebel ...
lead_paragraph: The fighting spoken of in yesterday's TIMES as going on south of Franklin, Tenn., on Thursday. proves to have been between a brigade commanded by Col. COBURN, consisting of three regiments of infantry, about five hundred cavalry and one pattery, and the entire command of the rebel Gen. VAN DORN, reported to number some 18,000 men. Of course Col. COBURN's brigade could not long contend against such odds, and though his men fought desperately, until their ammunition was exhausted, alt his infantry were at last captured or killed. The cavalry and artillery escaped.

abstract: Mr. MAX MARETZEK resumed his old position at the Academy of Music last evening, and was greeted by a full and fashionable deputation from all classes of the music-loving community. There was probably not an unprofessional auditor in that immense audience that ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. MAX MARETZEK resumed his old position at the Academy of Music last evening, and was greeted by a full and fashionable deputation from all classes of the music-loving community. There was probably not an unprofessional auditor in that immense audience that did not feel a thrill of satisfaction at seeing a practical man once more at the head of the direction of the principal art establishment of the New World. The interests of the Academy, so far as Italian Opera is concerned, have not been well conserved in the absence of such a head. Various experiments of singular audacity and barren result have been made; such, for instance, as trying to give grand opera without grand artists, and mainly on the strength of a few pieces of "armour by GRANGER of Paris," -- a chivalric device that failed utterly; then came the epoch of diminished forces, when an orchestra of twenty-eight was considered sufficient, and a chorus of equal magnitude had to sentinel the stage, and make an imposing effect before the public. There are many small towns in Europe where economical contrivances of this sort are practiced, but the Academy sank even lower than these, for the operas played were not given entire as they are almost sure to be there. The absence of any musical head to the concern resulted naturally in a degree of license that was almost incredible. Everything that presented the slightest difficulty to the singers or the players was inexorably cut out; hence, we have had the rudiments of operas, not the works themselves.

abstract: Fetterline >amp; Co., Rodewald >amp; Co.; Drafts Drawn against Shipments
snippet: Fetterline >amp; Co., Rodewald >amp; Co.; Drafts Drawn against Shipments
lead_paragraph: Fetterline & Co. vs. Rodewald & Co., el al. -- This was an action to determine the rights of the various parties dependent to a fund of about $6,000, which had been deposited by the plaintiffs in the Trust Company, in an interpleader suit. The moneys were the proceeds off shipments of tobocco which had been made to the plaintiffs by Henry Rodewald & Co., of New-Orleans, in the Autumn and in December, 1859. It appeared to have been the custom of Rodewald & Co. to draw drafts and negotiate them in the New-Orleans market to about the amount which it was supposed would be realized on each consignment. On the 19th of December, 1859, the last shipment was made, and on the same day defendant, Oglesby, purchased Rodewald & Co.'s draft on plaintiffs for $1,500.

abstract: Mrs. Blandina Dudley died at her residence in this city this morning, at the advanced age of 80. She was the widow of Hon. Charles E. Dudley, who filled various offices at home and abroad, and was Martin Van Buren's successor in the United States Senate in 1829. Mrs. D. was a lady of high social qualities and of all womanly virtues. In her later years she has been profuse in the expenditure of her great wealth upon religious, scientific and benevolent objects. She leaves a monument in the Dudley Observatory, and a pleasant memory with all who knew [???]er. -- Albany Journal, 6th.

abstract: -- There were a great many humors in the city yesterday in regard to the fight which is said to have taken place at Winchester. The facts, as we learn them from an officer who arrived yesterday morning, are about as follows: On Wednesday last the rebel Gen. JONES drove in our pickets stationed out upon the Strasburgh road. Gen. MILROY sent out the Thirteenth Pennsylvania cavalry and two companies of the Lincoln cavalry (New-York.) This force met and routed the rebels who had alarmed the pickets, and captured some thirty of the number. Not being satisfied with this result they continued on in search of the enemy, when our force was led into an ambuscade and a severe fight took place. The Lincoln cavalry stood up manfully, but it is said the Thirteenth Pennsylvania acted badly. Our loss was about one hundred and sixty killed, wounded and missing, including Maj. BYRNE, of the Thirteenth Pennsylvania, who was mortally wounded. Our force was compelled to fall back, but before the troops could be reinforced from Winchester the rebels had escaped. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, March 3.

abstract: Constitutionalism in; Policy of the Deputies
snippet: Constitutionalism in; Policy of the Deputies
lead_paragraph: Constitutionalism in England, under Queen VICTORIA, and constitutionalism in Prussia, under King WILLIAM, are two very different things. In England, the Constitution, and Parliament as its exponent, are supreme; the Queen is but its highest subject. She never makes herself a party to the acts of her Ministers, nor opposes her opinion to the expressed will of Parliament, and she can always change her Government without detriment to her authority. She secures her prerogatives, maintains her sway, and gives stability to her throne, by rigid observance of the law, and rigid respect for the rights of the people's representatives. In Prussia just now the case is quite otherwise. There the sovereign tramples on the Constitution at his whim; contemns the Legislature, and regards his Ministers as but a species of upper servants, who are bound to carry out his caprices, and by whom, as long as they do so, be is obliged in honor to stand, no matter how offensive to the nation or antagonistic to law may be their doings. That this is WILLIAM's theory of constitutionalism is evident from his reply to the address of the Lower Chamber. In this document, his Serene Majesty reproves the Deputies for having presumed to censure the conduct of the Government, because, forsooth, he had sanctioned its acts. The three estates of the realm, not having been able to come to an agreement, it was, of course, the duty of the Landesvater to take care that the nation's interests should not suffer. The King warns the Deputies that he is determined to uphold the prerogatives of the Crown and the privileges of the Kerrenhaus, despite the attempts of the popular branch of the Diet to encroach on them; and he winds up with the expression of a hope that this manifestation of his conciliatory disposition will be met in a like spirit.

abstract: -- The period fixed for the redemption of stamps at the New-York Post-office, which began on the 15th of December, and expired on the 20th of January, being, exclusive of Sundays and holidays, thirty days. Notwithstanding the ample notice which had been given that no more stamps would be redeemed after that time, there have been quite a number of applications made since on the part of that unlucky portion of the public whom fate dooms to be always "just too late" for everything -- the same hapless mortals who may be daily seen, with carpet-bag in hand, gazing wistfully from the end of the pier, at the wake of the departing steamer, or rushing madly to the railroad depot, just in time to catch a glimpse of the rear car of the retreating train. No extension of the time could be granted, however; and the holders of the dubious-looking gum-backs have no remedy but to apply them to the prepayment of their postage.

abstract: -- In a car on a railroad which runs into New-York, a few mornings ago, a scene occurred which will not soon be forgotten by the witnesses of it. A person dressed as a gentleman, speaking to a friend across the car, said: "Well, I hope the war may last six months longer. If it does, I shall have made enough to retire from business. In the last six months I've made a hundred thousand dollars -- six months more and I shall have enough."

abstract: -- All the prize vessels and cargoes captured by the Blockading Squadron and other war vessels that have been brought to this port have been converted into money, with the following exceptions, viz.: Steamer Bermuda and schooner Emma Tuttle, and the cargoes of the J.C. Roker, Coquetle and Brilliant. The sum total of the money received for these sales is $1,618,404 11, exclusive of the amount realized by the sale of the cargo of the Princess Royal, a portion of which was sold on Saturday last. The expenses incident to the proper care and disposition of the vessels sold, including towage, wharfage, stevedores' hire, unloading cargoes, storage and custody of cargoes, insurance. &c., is estimated at $104,534, although the exact figures may vary a trifle from the amount stated. The United States Marshal's, United States District Attorney's and Clerk's costs are estimated at $79,000. The fees of office of the above officers are as follows: United States Marshal, maximum, $6,000; United States District Attorney, maximum, $6,000; and Clerk, maximum, $3,000. All overplus is returned to the United States Government. A portion of the cargo of the Princess Royal has been sold, and the vessel itself was sold for $112,000. -- Philadelphia Inquirer, March 3.

abstract: FIRE IN FURMAN-STREET.--Shortly after 7 o'clock Friday evening, a fire broke out in the upper story of No. 9 Furman-street, occupied by Mr. GODWIN as a steel wire tempering factory. The establishment runs through to No. 8, The buildings are four stories in height, of brick, and the different floors are occupied for various manufacturing purposes. The flames spead through
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN FURMAN-STREET. -- Shortly after 7 o'clock Friday evening, a fire broke out in the upper story of No. 9 Furman-street, occupied by Mr. GODWIN as a steel wire tempering factory. The establishment runs through to No. 8, The buildings are four stories in height, of brick, and the different floors are occupied for various manufacturing purposes. The flames spead through both buildings, and destroyed a large amount of property. Mr. MARRIOTT MCKENNY occupied the first floor of No. 9 as an iron railing manufactory, the second floor as a horse-shoe nail factory, the third was occupied by HARLEY & SON, Cabinet-makers, and as a bras furnishing establishment by Mr. FLETCHER. No. 8, first floor, was also occupied by Mr. MCKENNY; the second flour as an iron furnishing shop; the third, by BENJAMIN & DOREMUS, as a skirt-covering factory, and by DONAHUE & GUNHOUSE, boot-fitters. There was a large quantity of stock and material on hand, which, together with the machinery on the upper floors, was either destroyed or greatly damaged. It is not known how the fire originated, but supposed to have been the result of accident. The loss on buildings is about $6,000 on contents about $1[???],000; partially covered by insurance.

lead_paragraph: TWO MEN SERIOUSLY STABBED IN THE SEVENTEENTH WARD. -- At a late hour on Thursday night a serious affray occurred on the corner of Eleventhstreet and first-avenue, among a party of eight or ten men. During the affray, JAMES O'ROURKE and JAMES FLEMING were very badly wounded by knives. The latter received an extensive wound in the abdomen, from which his bowels protruded so much that it was feared he would die before he arrived at the Station-house. O'ROURKE had his face cut in several places. The wounded men were yesterday taken to Bellevue Hospital. It is believed that they cannot survive their injuries. The Police have arrested three men, who are charged with having inflicted the wounds upon FLEMING and O'ROURKE

abstract: Ambulance Corps for the Army
snippet: Ambulance Corps for the Army
lead_paragraph: The "Ambulance Corps" bill which was before Congress, failed of passage because the General-in-Chief thought the thing impracticable. The system which was last tried consisted in taking certain men from the regiments on the eve of battle to attend to the work of carrying off their comrades who might be wounded in the engagement. This plan was adopted by Gen. BURNSIDE at the battle of Fredericksburgh, and worked very well; but at all previous battles of the war, the wounded have been greatly neglected until the close of the engagement, and a vast amount of unnecessary suffering has been the consequence. When a soldier fell, the two nearest to him, if not too busily engaged, would carry him to the rear for the attention of the surgeons. But there being no regular plan of organization, and no special body of men set apart for the duty, a large part of the wounded had no attention at all. In no engagement that has yet occurred, have systematio and sufficient arrangements been made for taking care of those who should chance to fall. Thousands whom prompt assistance would have saved, have thus been allowed to linger through days of agony into untimely graves. There have been instances of men left in terrible anguish in the field for seven days, until exhaustion rendered mortal injuries which were in themselves but trifling. The ambulance trains have been left far in the rear; the drivers have frequently deserted or fled; the horses and mules have been run off by skulks and stragglers.

abstract: -- In a circular addressed from headquarters, by Adj.-Gen. SPRAGUE, to the various regiments in the field from this State, he requests that all regimental colors, worn out in service, and of consolidated regimen's, be forwarded to headquarters, as well as captured flags, banners, &c., "that they may be deposited in the archives of the State, in an appropriate manner, as a record of the valor and fortitude of her sons. A minute history of the flags is important, and a detailed statement of the services of the regiment will the appropriate." Some of the regimental flags have been presented by countries, or cities, or associations, or by individuals, and there will be doubtless some disposition felt to return them to the donors; but it is best that they should be gathered together at some central point, together with the trophies of the war, so as to constitute an embodied history of the great events now passing. The hall of the Capitol, the State Library, and the Geological Rooms, are the best places for the temporary exhibition of these memorials. At some future day, the State may provide more amply for this patriotic purpose.

abstract: -- Among the oddities of the present times is the fictitious value placed upon nickel cents. In a short time things will be changed; the rebels will receive their quietus, and the currency of the country will be restored to first principles. The nickels, which by speculators have been forced up to a premium rate, will then be as sore a drug as coals at Newcastle. The mint is now running its entire force upon nickels. The cost of making this insignificant coin is nearly as much as the cost of making double eagles. The only difference is that the latter coin is weighed and adjusted, piece by piece. The nickels are exempt from any such close manipulation. The labor daily done at the mint, if expended upon double eagles, would produce $40,000 per day. Upon nickels, as it is now expended, the results are but about $2,500 per day in nickel. When the currency question is regulated, and specie comes forth from its many hiding places, nickel cents will be like the locusts of Egypt. They will be so abundant as to constitute a nuisance. Except for convenience in doing retail business, they are of small value. In small sums each nickel represents the hundredth part of a dollar, yet is not intrinsically worth even that. Nickels cannot be used as legal tender, nor for exportation, yet a fictitious value is given to them by speculation that is really culpable. To produce them in sufficient quantities, the nickel-coining machinery of the United States Mint is running even into over hours. -- Phila. North American, March 5.

abstract: The House of Representatives to-day voted on the report of the Committee on Federal Relations. They rejected the report by a decided vote, but accepted the resolutions, thirteen in number.  The first, after stating that Kentucky is assailed by armed rebellion on one side, and unconstitutional usurpation on the other, recommends calmness and invokes the aid of patriotic men.

abstract: -- By  order of the United States District Court, Marshal MILWARD sold on Saturday, the prize steamer Princess Royal, recently captured off Charleston by the United States gunboat Unadilla. There was a large attendance, but very few bidders. The vessel was put up at $90,000, and knocked down to an agent of the Government at $113,000, the appraised value. It is understood that the Princess Royal will be hauled to the Navy-yard as soon as the sale is confirmed by the Court and the money paid over, and that she will be fitted up for a gunboat. Some persons have supposed that, being a fast steamer, she might be sent out in search of the Alabama, but they forget that she is not more than half the tonnage of the rebel steamer, and  besides, has an iron hull, which a solid shot would pass through almost as readily as it did through the hull of the Hatteras. Part of the cargo of the Princess Royal was also sold, by an order of the Court, on Saturday. The principal item in the catalogue, 400 bags of coffee, was disposed of first. One Purchaser took the entire lot, at 32 1/2 cents per pound, which was above the appraised value, and thought by dealers generally to be a high figure. Some choice packages of a lot of tea brought as high as $1 20, but the generality of it sold from 85 to 95 cents the package. The pepper, tin and sheet-iron all sold at high prices. Philadelphia Ledger, March 2.
lead_paragraph: -- By order of the United States District Court, Marshal MILWARD sold on Saturday, the prize steamer Princess Royal, recently captured off Charleston by the United States gunboat Unadilla. abstract: -- In the Prize Court, yesterday, Judge CADWALADER said that, though he was not prepared to give an opinion in respect to a part of the cargo of the prize steamer Bermuda, he did not think his opinion in respect to the vessel should be longer delayed. He had come to the conclusion to condemn the vessel, and his reasons therefor would be submitted in a short time. District-Attorney COFFEE asked in respect to that portion of the cargo which is clearly contraband. The Judge replied that he was ready when the application was formally made to order the transfer of the munitions of war to the Government at their appraised value. The District-Attorney asked also in reference to the transfer of the vessel to the Government at her appraised value, $120,000. The counsel for the claimants, who had notified the Judge of an intention to appeal the case to the Supreme Court, assented to the proposition of the District Attorney, and the steamer will therefore be at once handed over to the Government upon the payment of the money, which has been in this City for some time. The Bermuda is one of the finest vessels captured since the commencement of the war. She has an iron hull, is larger than the Princess Royal, and has very superior engines. She was built in 1861.

abstract: Speech in New-York on the War
snippet: Speech in New-York on the War
lead_paragraph: One of the best evidences that the right of free speech still exists in New-York, is the fact that Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, spoke before the Democratic Association, corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway, last evening. The call for the meeting invited "loyal citizens in favor of the suppression of the rebellion." The hall was not filled as early as usual. In spite of the inclement weather, however, every seat was filled, and as many as could be accommodated were present. The word "Union," which is formed of perforated gas-pipe over the speaker's desk, was not lighted -- neither were the hundreds of cigars, which have been wont on previous occasions to envelop the audience, and occasion laryngeal and epiglottic irritations not agreeable or beneficial to Democratic health. Indeed, the ventilation of the room is calculated to kill more Democrats in one night than can be converted in a dozen.

lead_paragraph: in a recent message to the Virginia Legislature, announced that he had confined at hard labor in the Penitentiary a considerable number of Union officers and soldiers, in retaliation for the imprisonment, by our authorities, of certain rebel bushwhackers who had been captured in Western Virginia. We have already urged upon our Government to look to this matter, and try to establish some principle with the Confederate military authorities for guidance in such cases.

abstract: SCHOONER RETRIBUTION. -- We are informed that Capt. LOCKE, of the pirate schooner Retribution, which has captured several United States vessels in the vicinity of the West India Islands within the past few weeks, including the schooner Hanover, of Boston, is an Englishman by birth, but was formerly a resident of Massachusetts, having been in the employ of ship-owners at this port. At one time he was in command of a swift bark, owned by a gentleman of this city, which made a very successful run to the Cape of Good Hope. On the return of Capt. LOCKE to this port, however, the owner did not seem well satisfied with the result of the voyage. Capt. LOCKE in reply remarked that there was one branch of the business in which such a swift craft could be successful. "What is that?" asked the owner. "The slave trade," remarked Capt. LOCKE; but when he observed that the suggestion was unpalatable, he turned it off as a joke. It was rumored at St. Thomas that the commander of the Retribution was a traitor to the Confederacy, as his orders were imperative to burn all his prizes. He, on the contrary, was attempting to sell the vessels which he captured, with their cargoes. -- Boston Traveler, March 5.

abstract: Loring-Field Correspondence on the War
snippet: Loring-Field Correspondence on the War
lead_paragraph: Mr. CHARLES G. LORING, of Boston, undertook toward the close of last year to convince one of his friends in England -- a brother lawyer, Mr. EDWIN FIELD, of London -- of the justice of the complaints of English speech and behavior touching the war, which at that time were in every man's mouth. Mr. FIELD refused to be convinced without a struggle, and the result was a long correspondence, which Mr. LORING has since been induced to publish. It now lies before us in a large pamphlet, and contains the main points of the controversy, as fully stated as is possible within the limits of letters which when written were private, and intended to remain so. We wish we could add that Mr. LORING was rewarded by witnessing Mr. FIELD's repentance and conversion as the result of his labors. But we regret to say that, after all was said that could be said, the Englishman appears to have remained firm as ever in his convictions that the war was foolish and unnecessary, and that the North was gone clean mad.

abstract: -- Our readers are not, perhaps, aware that there is now being built here an iron-clad battery of the Monitor pattern, intended for ocean service, and which, in point of strength, speed and effectiveness, promises to excel any vessel of the class afloat. The new battery has been named the Manayunk, and is being built on the south side of the Monongahela close by the end of the Monongahela Bridge. The contractors are Messrs. SNOWDON, MASON & CO., and if we are informed aright, the price to be paid is something over $[???]00,000. The vessel was commenced some three or four months ago, and has given employment ever since to some 150 hands. The model of the vessel is exceedingly sharp and graceful, and with engines of sufficient power, she will doubtless make fast time. Her length is 235 feet, and breadth of beam 40 feet. Like all the other Monitors, she will consist of two hulls, an upper and lower, but, unlike the original Monitor, they will be joined together in such a way as to entirely avoid the defects which resulted in the loss of the latter, the upper hull will be plated with six inches of iron, and the turret with ten inches. The pilot-house will be protected by eight inches of iron, and the chimney will be constructed of iron plates, each an inch thick. She will carry two guns, one 15 inch, capable of throwing a ball weighing 430 pounds, and the other 11 inches, and will, it is believed, be the most substantial and reliable vessel of the character ever built. The greater portion of the side of the lower hull are now in place, and a portion of the plating has been put on. The turret is also under way, and the engines are in an advanced state. It is expected that she will be ready for service by the latter part of next Summer or the beginning of Fall. -- Pittsburgh Chronicle, March 3.

abstract: --As a means of notifying the person sending of its safe arrival, the President requests us to say that on yesterday he received, by ADAMS & CO.'s Express, a package of "greenbacks," amounting to eight hundred and sixty-eight dollars, which sum the writer of an accompanying letter says, he obtained from the Government dishonestly, and which he therefore returns. The letter is dated Brooklyn, March 2, 1863, and signed Candido Securo. -- Washington Chronicle.

abstract: River; naval operations in the
snippet: River; naval operations in the
lead_paragraph: In the progress of so great a war as we are waging, the " good luck" cannot always be on one side. Each combatant is often forced to draw comfort on the happening of an untoward event by the reflection that it was not so bad as it might have been. We are compelled to accept this minor consolation in considering the loss of the iron-clad monitor Indianola, below Vicksburgh. At first it was not clear in what condition the enemy obtained this prize. It appeared that the struggle had been very brief -- that the Indianola had yielded to the assaults of two rams -- but beyond this nothing was certain. Some of the crew stated that she had been abandoned in a sinking condition, but other reports were current that the rebels had taken her below and anchored her under the guns of Port Hudson. The public mind, annoyed by the unwelcome news, was willing to accept this story, and fears were even entertained that with the Indianola and the Queen of the West the rebels would dash at once into the lower Mississippi, destroy Commodore FARRAGUT's wooden fleet, and recapture not only Baton Rouge, but even New-Orleans. And undoubtedly a raid of the Indianola down the river might have put in peril a very large Union fleet, and rendered doubtful our tenure of the Lower Mississippi. But happily we are relieved of apprehension on this score. We have the best authority -- that of the rebels themselves -- for stating that the Indianola will, if we perform our duty, never do service under the Confederate flag. Though lost to us, the vessel is equally lost to the enemy. "She is sunk on the Mississippi side, and her upper works removed." Such is the rebel report.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the enlargement of the locks of the Champlain Canal, was reported favorably; also, a bill to change the location of the Baldwinsville Canal and to enlarge the locks; also, the bill to facilitate the construction of the Lake Ontario, Auburn and New-York Railroad. A bill to authorize the use of dummy-engines on the Brooklyn Central Railroad was introduced. The New-York Warehousing bill was ordered to a third reading. The Senate agreed to hold a session on Tuesday evening for the consideration of general orders.

abstract: -- Capt. LIBBEY, of ship Kate Prince, at this port from Bermuda Feb. 19, states that the blockade-running steamer Cornubia came into that port on the 19th, from Charleston, with cotton; would load again for a Southern port. She is painted lead color, has two smokestacks, and is said to go 18 knots. Blockade runner Miriam was also loading for a Southern port, to sail in a week. She is just like the Princess Royal, and not much, if any, faster than that boat. Blockade runner Merminae is laying up; she will attempt the passage with the first fine weather of Spring. She is a bad sea boat, but fast in smooth water. The Phoebe has been sold, and was about leaving for Sydney, N.S.W. -- Boston Journal, March 2.

abstract: Mr. MARETZEK has given two performances of "H. Trovatore" at the Academy of Music--the second, on Saturday, being by far the best. The attendance on the last-mentioned occasion was, of course, miserably bad; sympathizing in that respect with the...
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK has given two performances of "H. Trovatore" at the Academy of Music--the second, on Saturday, being by far the best. The attendance on the last-mentioned occasion was, of course, miserably bad; sympathizing in that respect with the weather, which in a few hours ran through the entire gamut of wintry discomfort, and completely put a veto to locomotion. The audience, however, was a remarkable one, and numbered nearly all the leading musicians and critics in town -- classes who don't usually trouble themselves about morning performances. To these may be added an extremely noisy clique of Cubans, who recorded their satisfaction with the least meritorious parts of the performance by shouting and stamping and raging in a way that at the Bowery Theatre would have led to their instant ejection. It is possible that these persons were actuated by the since rest regard for art, but it would be well if they were also governed by a decent respect for the habits of the American public, who do not think it necessary to disturb their neighbors in the maniacal expression of individual approbation. Indeed, demonstrations of the kind that were noticeable on Friday evening, and to a less extent on Saturday, are always viewed with suspicion, and afford an easy sneer at the management, entirely unjust -- as we know -- in this case.

abstract: -- Since the microscopic wedding to which the dailies of this City surrendered columns much longer than the little couple are high, Gen. TOM THUMB and his pretty "little woman" have traveled from capital to capital in quiet guise, seeking retiracy from notoriety. As is the case with Gen. MCCLELLAN, who, wherever he goes, is nominated for the Presidency by the enthusiastic peace-men, and with Gen. FREMONT, who travels nowhere without being pulled and hauled by the people, whose claim for recognition is, that they voted for him in 1856; and with any other man who has attained, accidentally or by noted conduct, public fame, so it is with THUMB. He has been wined and dined in Philadelphia by the Brotherly Lovers: feted and joked at, dangled and danced in Washington by everybody who is anybody, from a high public functionary down to the hotel boys; received by 2,500 curious people in Bridgeport, and literally bothered beyond patience, and far out of the bounds of mental endurance, wherever he might go to spend the honeymoon with his wife. At last he has, we learn, been obliged, in defence of comfort and of health, to go upon the boards in Boston, and we doubt not he will soon give his New-York gazers another opportunity of beholding, upon the same stage with himself, his wife, Commodore NUTT and Miss MINNIE WARREN -- a social whist-party, whose combined length would not equal that of an average sized Kentuckian.
lead_paragraph: -- Since the microscopic wedding to which the dailies of this City surrendered columns much longer than the little couple are high, Gen. He has been wined and dined in Philadelphia by the Brotherly Lovers: feted and joked at, dangled and danced in Washington by everybody who is anybody, from a high public functionary down to the hotel boys; received by 2,500 curious people in Bridgeport, and literally bothered beyond patience, and far out of the bounds of mental endurance, wherever he might go to spend the honeymoon with his wife. At last he has, we learn, been obliged, in defence of comfort and of health, to go upon the boards in Boston, and we doubt not he will soon give his New-York gazers another opportunity of beholding, upon the same stage with himself, his wife, Commodore NUTT and Miss MINNIE WARREN -- a social whist-party, whose combined length would not equal that of an average sized Kentuckian.

abstract: DISPATCHES FROM RICHMOND.  A bearer of dispatches to the English and French Ministers arrived here this morning, having left Richmond on Saturday morning. He brought copies of the Richmond papers of Thursday, Friday and Saturday. They contain no news of importance. The dispatches and papers were delivered at once to the English and French Ministers.

abstract: Boston Commercial Bulletin on his Butter Speculation
snippet: Boston Commercial Bulletin on his Butter Speculation
lead_paragraph: -- Provision dealers were not a little astonished, the other day, to find an operator in the Butter market who made a clean sweep of every choice grade lot of that commodity offering, at the highest current rates. But they were still more surprised when they learned that this bold and persistent speculator was an agent of the dry goods house of STEWART, in New-York City, and that the butter thus bought up was to be shipped to Europe to pay for importations, in lieu of exchange. Our market has since been left nearly bare of good stocks of Vermont and New-York butter, and prices have materially advanced. This "cute" and characteristic operation rather beats the cotton goods monopoly. There is but one more chance for a "spec" left for STEWART in this quarter, and that is to go into the fish market. The cod and haddock have already taken the alarm, and struck out for deep water. -- Boston Commercial Bulletin, March 7.

abstract: The Richmond Dispatch and Enquirer of the 6th inst., which have been received, contain several items of interest. The Dispatch states that the gunboat Indianola, recently captured from the Yankees, was blown up last Tuesday night by the rebels, and her guns fell into the hands of the Federals. The Queen of the West left in such a hurry as to leave part of her crew on shore.

abstract: We have advices from Port Royal to the 3d inst., by the arrival at this port of the steamer Fah-Ku. The report of the destruction of the rebel steamer Nashville had reached Port Royal.

snippet: Boston Post on Cooper Institute Meeting and Unconstitutional Loyalty; Gen. Forey's proclamation; Steam Rams, how to build; Letter on the War; Canal National, Enlargement, Revival of
lead_paragraph: It will be seen that Maj.-Gen. WOOL, commanding the Department of the East, is making a tour of the various States under his jurisdiction. On Friday last he was at the capital of Rhode Island. He was received by Joint Committees of the General Assembly, welcomed by the Governor, and made a speech before the Legislature. He said he had come only to inspect the coast defences, and he very speedily set about his work. He took every occasion to address those he met, and sketches of his various addresses are given by our correspondent. The veteran General appeared as hale and vigorous as the young officers who accompanied him.

abstract: A PRISONER FOUND DEAD IN HIS CELL. -Three men, named MORRIS CLANCEY, PATRICK NESBITT and MICHAEL NEVIN, were arrested by Officer MCCORMICK, of the Third Precinct, about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, upon the charge of being grossly intoxicated in the street. They were all taken to the Station-house and temporarily committed. About 3 o'clock yesterday morning an officer visited CLANCEY's cell, when it was found that the latter was stretched upon the floor, dead. The Coroner was notified and will hold an inquest upon the body to-day.

abstract: The Thirty-seventh Congress closed its session this morning. There was nothing out of the regular routine in the hours immediately preceding its demise, nor in the manner of its dissolution. It passed away, indeed, with less excitement and Turmoil than has heretofore seemed to be a necessity of the dying spasms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 4. 1863.

abstract: Gen. Forey's Address to the Mexicans
snippet: Gen. Forey's Address to the Mexicans
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the Columbia we receive interesting details of Mexican news, carried to Cuba by the French dispatch steamer, which left Vera Cruz on the 17th of February. Several ships and lives had been lost in Sacrificios Bay and along the coast, by a violent storm that took place at the beginning of the past month of February. The following are the names of the ships wrecked: The American bark Sherwood, with a crew of nine men, three of whom were saved and the rest perished; the Mexican cutter Esperanza, with a crew of six men, two of whom were saved and four perished; the English bark Fayron, the whole of the crew saved; Mexican cutter Adalberto, all hands saved; a boat that was sent with five men in aid of the above-named vessels met with a similar fate. Of its crew two were saved and the rest lost their lives; two French transport vessels, an American bark and a Mexican cutter were also damaged.

abstract: CONVICTION FOR ABDUCTION. -- The Kings County Court of Sessions was engaged on Friday and Saturday in the trial of EDGAR J. TRIPP, on an indictment charging him with abducting a girl named RINO for the purpose of prostitution. The girl is under 14 years of age, which makes the offence the more serious. Defendant was a conductor on a Greenwood car, and he, in connection with another man, not vet tried, is charged with taking the girl off and violating her person. TRIPP was found guilty and sentenced to State Prison for the term of three years and six months.

abstract: The Police Commissioners, with their more immediate subordinates, are comfortably and conveniently settled in their new building, of which mention was made in the TIMES several months...
lead_paragraph: The Police Commissioners, with their more immediate subordinates, are comfortably and conveniently settled in their new building, of which mention was made in the TIMES several months since. The amount of routine business necessitated by the growing importance of the Police Department, has increased vastly during the past three years, and as the population of the city rolls on toward the million, the exigencies of office duty alone demanded accommodations largely advanced in space and modern conveniences beyond the narrow and greatly prescribed limits of the old headquarters. The working statue of the Metropolitan force was never more elevated than now, nor at any time within police recollections has a system of such absolute efficiency been in operation as the present. The Commissioners, by a habit of judicial impartiality, have impressed upon the corps, from the Superintendent to the patrolman, the absolute policy of good behavior, and unflagging interest in the performance of duty. Regular sessions are held by the Commissioners, at which all members of the force charged with dereliction of duty are arraigned and afforded a fair opportunity of explaining their action, and as yet we have to learn of dissatisfaction on the part of citizen or officer with the decision of the Court. Since the retirement of Gen. BOWEN, the Presidency of the Board has devolved upon Commissioner ACTON, who, with Commissioner BERGEN, constitute the Board. Superintendent KENNEDY has his office in the same building, and remains, despite the charges against him, all of which have been exploded in regular trial, at the head of the force. Ex-Chief JOHN S. FOLK, is in charge in Brooklyn, subordinate, of course, to the Metropolitan Headquarters. The force in Brooklyn is ridiculously small, and wholly inadequate to the proper performance of the required work. It is not right to leave a city of over 300,000 inhabitants to the custody of between 200 and 300 men. With the exception of occasional officiousness on the part of bilious or newly appointed officers, and a tendency to strain at gnats, while metaphorical camels are permitted unimpeded progress, the people of this City and of Brooklyn have slight cause of complaint against the force as now organized, while the Commissioners and their immediate subordinates may with propriety and justice claim for themselves the thanks of a well protected people.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Another fashionable and crowded house greeted Mr. MARETZEK last evening, when VERDI'S "Ballo in Maschera" was performed. The work is a favorite with our public, and has been so ever since its production, invariably attracting the best audiences of the season. Considering that we
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Another fashionable and crowded house greeted Mr. MARETZEK last evening, when VERDI'S "Ballo in Maschera" was performed. The work is a favorite with our public, and has been so ever since its production, invariably attracting the best audiences of the season. Considering that we have not always heard it under the most favorable of circumstances, this popularity augers well for Mr. MARETZEK, whose company gave it last night in a way that, in many respects, has never been equaled. The distribution included nearly all the leading artists of the troupe, with the exception of Signor BELLINI, who is still too much under the weather to sustain his role. An able and zealous substitute was found in Signor YPOLITO, who sang the aria in the first act with much energy, and in the fourth with artistic feeling, but lacked dramatic force for the situation of the third act. It would be difficult to say to whom the honors of the evening were due. Both Mad. MEDORI and Signor MAZZOLINI were in such superb voice that the house had barely recovered from one outburst of enthusiasm before it was plunged into a fresh one by one or other of these artists. The fine school of Mad. MEDORI, her large voice, and ample command of dramatic intensity and expression, are all superbly displayed in the effective role of Amelia, more particularly in the latter half of the opera where the tribulation of the heroine commence and end. It was apparent that this lady has yet another career before her. Her artistic resources are of the amplest kind, and although her voice is afflicted with a tremolo which indicates excessive use, it is yet commanding in power and admirable in quantity. As an actress, too, she is thoroughly good. We have no hesitation in saying, and without qualification, that the third and fourth acts have never been so well rendered in this City.

abstract: Bill The; Vallandigham and the Copperheads
snippet: Bill The; Vallandigham and the Copperheads
lead_paragraph: VALLANDIGHAM, in his speech before the Copperhead Association of this City, again threatened "resistance" to the conscription. The word resistance, in any connection, from the lips of such a notorious dastard, naturally produces contempt simply. Of course these factious speech-makers have no idea of committing themselves personally to an armed fight against the Government. There never yet, from Cleon down, was a creature of that sort whose bite was like his bark. Courage is a high quality, and it is never found associated with the base elements that make up the demagogue.

abstract: We have a few additional particulars regarding the recent unfortunate affair near Franklin, Tenn. It appears that our troops fought with the greatest valor until their ammunition gave out. Our
lead_paragraph: We have a few additional particulars regarding the recent unfortunate affair near Franklin, Tenn. It appears that our troops fought with the greatest valor until their ammunition gave out. Our loss in killed and wounded was about three hundred, and in prisoners about a thousand. The rebel loss in killed and wounded, according to their own admission, was double that of ours.

abstract: EXTENSION OF A HORSE RAILROAD.--The Hoboken and Weehawken Horse Railroad Company have recently entered into an agreement with the residents of Guttenberg, North Hoboken, Dallytown,
lead_paragraph: EXTENSION OF A HORSE RAILROAD. -- The Hoboken and Weehawken Horse Railroad Company have recently entered into an agreement with the residents of Guttenberg, North Hoboken, Dallytown, &c., to extend their railroad from the summit of Union Hill to Guttenberg. The proposed extension will cost about $30,000, and it is expected the track will be laid, and the cars running, in about three months. The Company will apply to the Legislature for an enactment allowing them to run dummy engines over the proposed new road.

abstract: On Union War Meetings
snippet: On Union War Meetings
lead_paragraph: The Courrier des Etat Unis is dissatisfied with the general import and tendency of the Union war meeting held last week at Cooper Institute. It affects to treat it as a Republican movement, and as designed to improve the waning fortunes of the Republican party, by masking its operations under the guise of loyalty. The Courrier can hardly deceive itself, and still less anybody else, by these ingenious devices. It is compelled to confess that there is nothing whatever in the resolutions of the meeting which warrants such a construction; but this it attributes to the skill of the gentleman who drew them. It will find great difficulty, however, in making even its own foreign readers believe that a meeting at which JAS. T. BRADY, Judge DALY and JOHN VAN BU[???]EN were the principal speakers, was in the interest of the Republican party.

abstract: Seal; "Cavalier" Device Proposed
snippet: Seal; "Cavalier" Device Proposed
lead_paragraph: In the rebel House of Representatives on the 6th, Mr. ARPERS0N, in denouncing the arbitrary system of impressments by the Confederate authorities, said that we were now living under a tyranny as complete as that which was exercised by the Lincoln Government, and it was owing solely to the noble patriotism of our people that they have submitted as they have. What right has a Confederate functionary to seize his property, without law, and to allow one-half its value for its compensation? There was no law that authorized the Confederate Government to take property, and so far as it withheld just compensation, it was robbery and oppression, and he, for one, was not willing to submit to it. If we were to have tyranny it mattered not whether we have it from one Government or from another; but no free people would submit to tyranny from any source.

abstract: -- This is the day on which the Prince of Wales is to wed the Princess ALEXANDRA, and, unless the reader rises early, the grand ceremony will probably have been performed before he reads his paper. The young bride was to arrive in London on Saturday last, and we suppose the period between her arrival and the hour of the consummation of her joy will furnish the happy and illustrious couple opportunities of affectionate intercourse. The occasion of the wedding will be one of the greatest rejoicings, festivities, illuminations, and bell-ringings all over the three Kingdoms. In every city and hamlet, in hall and hut, from Land's End to John o' Groat, the people will rejoice, while London has not for many a day seen such a day as this will be. We suppose the Prince himself never saw such a gala-day but once, and that was two years ago, when he rode up Broadway, New-York.
lead_paragraph: -- This is the day on which the Prince of Wales is to wed the Princess ALEXANDRA, and, unless the reader rises early, the grand ceremony will probably have been performed before he reads his paper. abstract: THE KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. -- The March term of the King's County Court of Oyer and Terminer was opened yesterday, before Judge SCRUGHAM and Justices EMMONS and HOYT. The list of Grand Jurors was called, and the following gentlemen were impanneled: Stedman Wright, foreman; Horatio Squires, Wm. Pratt, Julius Tower, C.D. Willets, C.F. Sanger, Aaron A. Claflin, Chester Bedel, J.W. Miller, H.W. Marsh, James Merrett, John C. Barnes, Simeon Nichols, James G. Reed, H. Plumber, Samuel Osman, J.D. Burdick. The case of THOS. MCLAUGHLIN and daughter, jointly indicted on the charge of causing the death of Mrs. CECELIA MCLAUGHLIN, some weeks since, will probably be brought up for trial next week. The trial of REDZKEY, indicted for the murder of FELLNER, the diamond merchant, will not take place this term, in consequence of the absence of material witnesses for the prosecution.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among the bills reported favorably was the one relative to the collection of taxes in New-York City. A bill was introduced requiring the Clerk of the Court of Appeals to account for moneys in his hands. A bill, introduced by Mr. BRADLEY, provides that the Charter election in this City shall be held at the same time as the election for State officers. A bill providing for the construction of a ferry across Jamaica Bay was introduced.

abstract: Legislature, reports a law against Unionism
snippet: Legislature, reports a law against Unionism
lead_paragraph: A resolution was agreed to in the Legislature of Virginia, on the 4th inst., inquiring into the "expediency of reporting a law making it a penal offence for any one to maintain, by speaking or writing, the propriety of reconstructing the Union of the former United States." Against whom is this proposed law aimed? Are not the people of Virginia, as of the whole South, a unit for secession? Have we not been told a thousand times, that both sexes, all ages, all sizes and every color, were opposed to the Union with all the faculties of their minds, all the passions of their hearts, all the members of their bodies, opposed to it totally and to the bitter end, even to the "last ditch?" It seems, however, that this is slightly if not considerably exaggerated; for why should a law be made to punish a crime that has no existence? Such a policy would directly contravene the wisdom of the ancient lawgiver, who, in his code, did not attach any penalty to a certain horrible crime, because he would not recognize the possibility of its commission. And surely the Virginia Solons would never outrage a precedent of classical antiquity.

abstract: are received by the arrival at this port of the steamship Roanoke. The news thus received direct, corroborates, in a measure, the reports which have reached us recently through the rebels, of an advance of the National forces against Port Hudson. It was expected that Gen. BANKS would commence his forward movement in two or three days after the departure of the Roanoke; and a Port Hudson dispatch, dated the 5th, published in the TIMES yesterday, says that all circumstances combined to make it certain that an immediate attack was to be made upon that place. Preliminary measures had been taken for the confiscation of the estates of JOHN SLIDELL, now acting as Rebel Commissioner in France. Mr. LAMONT, the Prosecuting Attorney, filed an "information" against SLIDELL in the Provisional Court, on the 27th ult About twenty persons had arrived at New-Orleans, who left the place only a few weeks ago, as registered enemies. They found such complete destitution that they were glad to return to save themselves from starvation. They were perfectly willing to take the oath of allegiance, and every one of them did so. They were suffering from actual hunger, and children were crying for food. Our correspondent gives currency to a report, brought from Texas by paroled prisoners, that Commander RENSHAW, said to have been killed by the explosion of the Westfield, was in Galveston, alive and well.

abstract: -- There is a bill now on the Assembly files at Albany providing for the establishment of a training school for primary teachers, and appropriating the small sum of three thousand dollars annually for its sustenance. It is proposed to establish the institution at Oswego, upon that city's complying with certain conditions. That such a training school is needed, we suppose no one conversant with the subject will dispute; that, if put on a proper basis, it will be of great practical benefit to the educational interests of the State, no one will deny; and that the bill will become a law, and the institution a fact, cannot be doubted.
lead_paragraph: -- There is a bill now on the Assembly files at Albany providing for the establishment of a training school for primary teachers, and appropriating the small sum of three thousand dollars annually for its sustenance. abstract: Dinner in New-York to Celebrate; Prince of Wales; Dinner in New-York to Celebrate his Wedding
snippet: Dinner in New-York to Celebrate; Prince of Wales; Dinner in New-York to Celebrate his Wedding
lead_paragraph: "His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales" was a familiar household word in this City nearly three years ago, when the Heir Apparent to the British Throne was feasting and dancing in all the principal cities of this Western Continent. Yesterday the announcement, in the TIMES, that it was the wedding-day of the young gentleman whose doings and sayings occupied so many columns of our journals in days gone by, recalled to the minds of thousands and thousands of our readers the magnificent reception given the Prince at Quebec, the humorous incidents attendant upon his knighting the speakers of the Upper and the Lower Houses, the grand Montreal illumination, the Orange riots at Toronto, the jokes of the youthful Guel[???]h at the expense of his more mature associates, his crossing to Detroit, his interview with Long JOHN WENWORTH, who gave him a pig of the "Prince Albert" breed; the visit to the St. Louis Fair, the trip, to the National Capital, the affecting incident at the grave of WASHINGTON, the insult at Richmond, the magnificent and never-equaled reception given him here, his trip up town with 100,000 hosts beside him, the Prnce's Ball, with all the fun thereof, and the subsequent platitudinous ovation at Boston -- all this and more was brought back to many of us when we saw the flag of Great Britain and the Prince's standard floating from so many hotels, houses, ships and public places.

abstract: State Legislature, the Work of
snippet: State Legislature, the Work of
lead_paragraph: -- By our letter from Albany to-day, it will be seen that the Legislature is now busily engaged upon a good deal of valuable and practical legislation. Measures establishing a training school for primary teachers -- providing for a uniform rate in the price of gas in Brooklyn, and also for certain new railroads -- for making the Board of Brokers a public body, and regulating the operations of street brokers in the vicinity of William-street and Exchange-place -- for creating a Bureau of Military Statistics -- for imposing a tax on factors, brokers and middlemen in the sale of goods, wares and merchandise -- for the construction of double locks on the Erie Canal where there are now single ones -- these and other important bills are up before the Legislature for action and discussion. We do not pretend to recommend or indorse all these measures, though several of them are of eminent utility.

abstract: -- We have advices from Mexico via New-Orleans, up to the 21st ult., being four days later than those previously received. This was the date the French forces were to take up their line of march for the City of Mexico. According to these last advices, however, the French army was in an entire state of inaction, and there was no appearance of a movement at present, except, perhaps, of the retrogressive style. It is said that the French officers have become disgusted with the expedition, and the invading army appears to be demoralized. This is the effect of a long year of discreditable inactivity, enlivened only with petty disasters. The climate thins their ranks, and the guerrillas capture their supplies as they attempt to pass into the interior. It would neither astonish nor grieve mankind to behold the compldte failure of the grand French attempt at the subjugation of Mexico.

abstract: The Committees of the Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen appointed to confer on the subject of the differences of those bodies on the various items of the City Appropriation bill for 1863, were in session over six hours yesterday. The Committees
lead_paragraph: The Committees of the Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen appointed to confer on the subject of the differences of those bodies on the various items of the City Appropriation bill for 1863, were in session over six hours yesterday. The Committees comprised Aldermen Hardy, Mitchell and McCool, and Councilmen Jones, Brice and Hayes. All were present. The budget was scrutinized very closely, and careful comparisons of the items with corresponding ones of previous years were made in the course of the lengthy session. The item for Belgian pavement was discussed at considerable length. The Aldermen were in favor of a large appropriation for the work, in order to carry out the ordinances for the improvement of the streets already ordered by the Common Council, believing also that it would afford an opportunity for the employment of laborers in a way that would benefit the City more than any other at this time.
