abstract: Copperheaded complaint of tyranny
snippet: Copperheaded complaint of tyranny
lead_paragraph: VALLANDIGHAM told the New-York Copperheads, in his recent speech, that "nothing was wanting to make this Government a complete and absolute despotism, as iron and inexorable in its character as the worst despotisms of the Old World, or the worst of modern times, even to BOMBA of Naples." His colleague, PENDLETON, in his harangue before the same set of rebel sympathizers, on Monday evening, substantially reiterated the assertion.

abstract: --The National Intelligencer reads the Press a very dignified lecture on the extreme impropriety of making remarks about Foreign Ministers, with special reference to the case of M. MERCIER. We presume its exhortations are very just and proper, though from the vagueness of terms in which they are couched, we find it somewhat difficult to catch their precise meaning. It bases its advice on the fact that "the allegations which were brought against him in the matter of some conceived complicity with Mr. GREELEY in a correspondence touching foreign intervention and the prospects of a peace, have subsided." What is meant by saying that an "allegation" has "subsided?" As the fact of the correspondence was admitted on both sides, the Intelligencer cannot mean to imply that it has been refuted. If it intends to vindicate the propriety of such a correspondence against the censures of a portion of the Press, it certainly has the right to do so, though we should differ from it in opinion on that point.

It bases its advice on the fact that "the allegations which were brought against him in the matter of some conceived complicity with Mr. GREELEY in a correspondence touching foreign intervention and the prospects of a peace, have subsided." What is meant by saying that an "allegation" has "subsided?" As the fact of the correspondence was admitted on both sides, the Intelligencer cannot mean to imply that it has been refuted. If it intends to vindicate the propriety of such a correspondence against the censures of a portion of the Press, it certainly has the right to do so, though we should differ from it in opinion on that point.

abstract: Schemper vs. Lynch; Sheriff's Liability for Levies
snippet: Schemper vs. Lynch; Sheriff's Liability for Levies
lead_paragraph: THE UNION LEAGUE OF NEWARK. -- The Union League of Newark is now fully organized, and yesterday public announcement was made that the League was ready to receive members. Loyal men of all parties are joining the League. A Committee sits nightly, this week, at No. 330 Broad-street, for the purpose of receiving signatures to the Constitution. A communication has been received from the Union men of Plainfield, asking for a copy of the Constitution, as a basis of organization for a similar League in that place. Monday evening has been selected as the night of meeting for the Newark League, and as soon as the proper accommodations can be secured, it is contemplated to open a headquarters and reading-room, to be open every night.

abstract: Speech at Stamford (Conn.) Democratic Meeting
snippet: Speech at Stamford (Conn.) Democratic Meeting
lead_paragraph: The Democrats of the quiet village of Stamford and its surroundings assembled last evening in Seeley Hall, pursuant to a call, in large numbers to hear their two great champions expound the law and Constitution. The meeting was enthusiastic, and at times boisterous, mingling hisses with cheers. E.P. WHITING, Esq., was made Chairman, and with a few remarks, thanking his friends for the honer conferred, introduced Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, who spoke nearly one hour in a rather subdued manner, by no means launching out as he did at the Broadway meeting of Copperheads a few evenings ago.

abstract: ALLEGED THEFT BY AN ARMY OFFICER.--FERDINAND M. MIAGLIA, a Lieutenant in one of the artillery regiments of this State, was taken into custody yesterday, upon the charge of having stolen a check for $568, drawn upon the Ocean Bank by JOHN S. MARTIN, of No. 165 Chambers-street. The check was
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED THEFT BY AN ARMY OFFICER. -- FERDINAND M. MIAGLIA, a Lieutenant in one of the artillery regiments of this State, was taken into custody yesterday, upon the charge of having stolen a check for $568, drawn upon the Ocean Bank by JOHN S. MARTIN, of No. 165 Chambers-street. The check was made payable to Messrs. RICHMOND & HOLMAN, whose residence is the Gramercy Park Hotel. It is alleged that the prisoner took the check, which was inclosed in an envelope and addressed to the payers, from the letter-box of the hotel above named. He forged an indorsement thereon, and presented it at the counter of Messrs. BALL & BLACK, in payment for a gold watch which he had purchased of them. The fraud was soon afterward discovered, and the offender taken into custody. He was held to await an examination at the Tombs Police Court.

abstract: THE COUNTY WAR DEBT.--The County of Kings has thus far expended $515,000 for bounties to volunteers, relief to families, , which amount the late County Treasurer, Mr. J.M. SEABURY, proposed to pay off with the money accruing from the collection of arrears of taxes. The treasurer estimates
lead_paragraph: THE COUNTY WAR DEBT. -- The County of Kings has thus far expended $515,000 for bounties to volunteers, relief to families, , which amount the late County Treasurer, Mr. J.M. SEABURY, proposed to pay off with the money accruing from the collection of arrears of taxes. The treasurer estimates that by the 1st of August next a sufficient amount will have been collected to pay off the entire war debt, and thus the County would be relieved of issuing bonds, bearing interest, and payable some years hence. The Board of Supervisors, at a meeting held last week, passed a resolution authorizing the payment of the war debt from the proceeds of the tax sales, but Mayor KALBFLEISCH, being of the opinion that as this surplus fund would. If not otherwise appropriated, be credited to the Wards and towns, and deducted from their taxes, it would be prejudicial to the interests of those Wards and towns which were in arrears of taxes, called a special meeting to reconsider the former action of the Board. The Board, however, refused to do so by a vote of 8 ayes to 14 nays, and the debt will therefore be liquidated as proposed by the County Treasurer.

abstract: -- The third performance of Mr. MARETZEK's brilliant season takes place to-night, when VERDI's great opera of "Ernani" will be given. The role of the hero is admirably adapted for displaying the best qualities of Signor MASSOLINI's voice, and supplies him also with an opportunity for much acting. Mme. MEDORI is the Elvira, and will, undoubtedly be thoroughly admirable in that part. The new basso, Signor BIACHI, of whom report speaks highly, makes his debut as Silva, and Signor BELLINI, having entirely recovered from his hoarseness, will also positively appear. The cast, it will be seen, is unusually strong.

abstract: Men; a few words to
snippet: Men; a few words to
lead_paragraph: Whatever we may think of the unreasonableness and wickedness of the Southern conspirators who, to accomplish the objects of a selfish ambition, have plunged this entire nation in woe, we cannot deny them credit for audaciousy breasting the responsibilities of their action. They have exhibited throughout an intense earnestness in their work, and a clear perception of the depth and blackness of the abyss they have leaped over, which separates their treason from other men's loyalty, that should have received closer attention than it has done from the masses in the loyal States. It would have saved much vacillation in policy and much needless division in popular sentiment regarding the war -- from which have resulted frequent discouragement and defeat.

abstract: -- Two years ago, Gov. PICKENS, of South Carolina, addressing the chivalry of that State, and urging the inauguration of war, cried out: "Be ready! Stand by your arms -- mark time to the tap of independence, and, at the word, march forward and onward to the Borders. Let tyrants know that there are men who can make them hear the ring and feel the weight of Southern steel. I shall endeavor not to expose our own State." "The Borders," to which Gov. PICKENS then urged the South Carolinians to march forward and onward, were not the borders of South Carolina, along which is soon to be heard the ring and felt the weight of Freedom's steel, but the borders of Pennsylvania, Ohio and Iowa. The crusaders were to march forward and onward, with their trumpets in their mouths and their swords by their sides, frightening and devouring as they went, till the North, on bended knees, should cry peccavi, and sue for mercy. They have been woefully disappointed. An army has been planted in the Palmetto State for a twelve-month, threatening its chief city, and now BEAUREGARD has warned the people to flee from the tempest of fire and iron that is about to fall upon it. That certainly is a very different programme from what Gov. PICKENS and the chivalry anticipated when, in the harbor of Charleston, they inaugurated war. How have the devices of fools come to naught,

abstract: The Massachusetts transport and supply steamer to the South Atlantic fleet sailed from this port yesterday, with an immense cargo of stores, provisions and ammunition and a large number of passengers. She took out a quantity of things that are to be used in a "big fight" soon to come off. It is believed in naval circles that this is the last trip which this ship will make to the present headquarters of DUPONT's squadron. She is armed with heavy guns, and can protect herself from the pirates.

abstract: Stoughton, Gen., the Capture of
snippet: Stoughton, Gen., the Capture of
lead_paragraph: The capture of Gen. STOUGHTON in his bed by a party of rebel cavalry at Fairfax Courthouse is another of those utterly disgraceful incidents with which this war has abounded. There have been within the last four months half a dozen surprises inflicted on our cavalry on the Potomac, which have been so inexcusable and stupid, that they lead us to doubt not simply the military ability of our cavalry officers, but their common sense. Cavalry is commonly supposed to furnish the eyes and ears of the army; but ours, so far as their performance of outpost duty is concerned, have helped to bring the enemy down on our infantry and baggage rather than to keep them off. Our outposts seem to serve the purpose not of warning STUART off, but of letting him know where to attack us.

lead_paragraph: The decision of the Supreme Court in the quicksilver case continues to excite unusual attention. It annihilates the title of the old Almaden Company, and makes that of the new company absolute and perfect. The members of the old company having derived a profit of about ten millions from working the mines, are said to be desi[???]ous of buying the stock of their adversaries to relieve themselves from liability for quicksilver had and received. ROBERT J. WALKER remarked, yesterday, with his habitual quiet, that his interest in the winning issue of the Almaden case was half a million dollars.

abstract: 123d New-York V. Letter on the duty of the people
snippet: 123d New-York V. Letter on the duty of the people
lead_paragraph: Hon. RALPH RICHARDS -- My Dear Sir: Seeing your name in one of the public prints to-day, put it in my mind to write you, the more especially as you are in some measure both the representative and manufacturer of public sentiment at home. I have been more and more impressed of late with a notion that the people at home do not stand up to that high mark of patriotism and of public virtue which the exigencies of this gigantic war demand, and which the sublime history and vast hopes of an heroic nation and a great and virtuous people entitle us to expect. The public Press and all the various modes for the expression of public sentiment indicate that a large portion of the Northern people, and, it is greatly to be feared, a majority of them, look with doubt upon the issue of this struggle, and are ready to abandon it upon any, even dishonorable terms. The prevalence of this idea in the army has weakened its courage and heroic fortitude, prepared it for weak and unmanly concessions, robbed it of the high and holy aims which sanctified its efforts, and has in a great measure reduced it from an army of patriots fighting for a great cause and conscious of the sublimity of their mission and the estimation which posterity will place upon their efforts, to an army of mercenaries, entering the service for the huge bounties offered, serving in it grudgingly and of necessity, and working with aching hearts for any mode by which they may possibly leave it.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "Ernani," last night, was so thoroughly excellent that a paragraph recording its success is almost all that need be said, without repeating general expressions of praise concerning each member of the company. It is seldom that such an admirable representation is enjoyed in New-York; and, to our recollection, the finale to the first act has never been so forcibly and dramatically rendered here. An ensemble involving such a grand combination of power and precision is not often heard in the grand opera houses of London and Paris, and certainly was worthy of the best establishment in any other city. Mme. MEDORI, as Elvira, gave a fine dramatic reading to the part, and her large voice, except in certain forced passages, where it scarcely reached the limits of just intonation -- was heard to immense advantage. Signor MAZZOLINI sang as heretofore, with ease, finish and great power. Signor BELLINI, the baritone, made his rentree as Carl, and although barely recovered from the indisposition that veiled his voice on the opening night, sang with spirit, and demonstrated amply that he has a voice of the first class, and is an artist who understands thoroughly the dramatic scope of his role. This latter characteristic, we may mention, is the peculiar feature of Mr. MARETZEK's company -- all the singers seem to be actors, and enter thoroughly into the spirit of the scene. Signor BIACHI, a new basso profondo, made his debut as Siloa, and by the combined powers of a good voice and a most excellent method, succeeded at once in winning the favor of the house.

This latter characteristic, we may mention, is the peculiar feature of Mr. MARETZEK's company -- all the singers seem to be actors, and enter thoroughly into the spirit of the scene. abstract: -- The Tribune has a "sensation" rumor to the effect that one of our Judges of the Supreme Court is about to decide against the constitutionality of the law of Congress making "greenbacks" a legal tender in the payment of debts contracted before the law took effect. When we get such a decision it will be quite time enough to discuss its merits. For the present it seems to us quite sufficient to say that Judges are not in the habit of announcing beforehand what their decisions will be, -- either to the public at large or to any special friends who might desire to profit by such knowledge. It is quite possible that such a decision may be given, for in these days of copperhead-ism and of a partisan judiciary, all things are possible in this direction. But it would amount to nothing whatever, beyond a fresh demonstration of the willingness of certain classes of men to embarrass and weaken the Government in every possible way at the present moment. It would certainly be reversed by the upper Courts.

abstract: the Result of
snippet: the Result of
lead_paragraph: -- The result of the election in New-Hampshire proves the hollowness of the predictions made by the Wood and Vallandigham school of Democrats, that the popular voice would be against the prosecution of the war. The people of that State are not willing to be misunderstood on this subject. They have elected a Republican member of Congress in every district, and a strong Republican majority in the Legislature, which insures the election of a Republican Governor. The result is one of great importance. It indicates on the part of the people of the State a firm and settled purpose to stand by the Administration in its prosecution of the war. It is for Connecticut to speak next. The Democrats are making strong efforts to carry the State, but unless we are greatly mistaken they will meet a disastrous defeat. If they succeed they will certainly be entitled to put down that State as against the war. The Copperhead wing of the Democracy understand perfectly that a victory in Connecticut now will be their triumph, and they are putting forth every effort to make it secure.

abstract: Prize Commissioners
snippet: Prize Commissioners
lead_paragraph: The comments which have been made in various quarters of late, upon the manner in which prize property has been disposed of at this port, indicate a good deal of misapprehension as to the powers and duties of the Prize Commissioners. It is not surprising that they should be but imperfectly understood, considering that we have, during the whole period of our national existence, been engaged in but two wars, both of short duration. The prize cases brought before our Courts in 1812 were few in number, and in the Mexican war we believe there were none at all, so that when the blockade was established last year, and Prize Commissioners appointed by the United States District Court, even the Bar was not very familiar with prize practice.

abstract: -- We had a story some days since that a rebel privateer had been fitted out at Melbourne for service in the Pacific. There is very little probability in the report, for lack of coaling facilities would alone prevent the rebels from carrying on their piratical operations in the Pacific with any prospect of success. But the Government may very wisely take precautions against such a contingency, and at the same time prepare for the possible danger of a foreign war. The California delegation have applied to the Secretary of the Navy for the construction of one or more iron-clads at San Francisco. If the requisite facilities exist for doing such work there, the request ought to be granted. In the event of a foreign war, San Francisco would be more exposed to hostile visitations than any other port in the country, and it is only just that preparations should be made for its defence. Beside this, there ought to be a more effective naval force in the Pacific than we have at present, for the protection of our whaling and other vessels in that region.
lead_paragraph: -- We had a story some days since that a rebel privateer had been fitted out at Melbourne for service in the Pacific. There is very little probability in the report, for lack of coaling facilities would alone prevent the rebels from carrying on their piratical operations in the Pacific with any prospect of success. But the Government may very wisely take precautions against such a contingency, and at the same time prepare for the possible danger of a foreign war. The California delegation have applied to the Secretary of the Navy for the construction of one or more iron-clads at San Francisco. If the requisite facilities exist for doing such work there, the request ought to be granted. In the event of a foreign war, San Francisco would be more exposed to hostile visitations than any other port in the country, and it is only just that preparations should be made for its defence. Beside this, there ought to be a more effective naval force in the Pacific than we have at present, for the protection of our whaling and other vessels in that region.

abstract: The, and the People
snippet: The, and the People
lead_paragraph: We publish an excellent and patriotic letter from a New-York Volunteer serving on the Rappahannock. It is full of expressions of fortitude and hope; but the writer has been led to the conclusion, from various indications, that a large portion, if not a majority, of the Northern people look with doubt upon the issue of, this struggle, and are ready to abandon it upon any, even dishonorable terms. He thinks that the prevalence of this idea in the army has weakened its courage and fortitude, robbed it of the holy aims which sanctified its early struggles, and prepared it for weak concessions. He says he is filled with rage and indignation that the grand efforts and sacrifices of the army should come to naught, and shipwreck come to the cause, through the cowardice, the weakness, the falsehood and the low ambition of our own people. He calls upon patriotic men to labor early and late to bring back the country once more to the high standard of virtue and confidence which has so often before swelled up like the ocean tides, and adds that a single manifestation of such an imperial and fast-fixed resolve to win would do more to secure the final triumph of our arms than a victory on the Rappahannock.

abstract: The Copperheads and the Courts
snippet: The Copperheads and the Courts
lead_paragraph: Among the many methods employed to embarrass and weaken the Government, appealing to the civil Courts has figured largely. It began at the very opening of the conflict, in the memorable applications to Chief Justice TANEY for the discharge of MERRIMAN and the other bridge-burners of Baltimore, summarily seized in the work of preventing the advance of the national troops to Washington. Gov. HICKS has recently averred in the Senate that the summary arrests of that period alone saved Maryland from going over to the Confederacy. The revolutionists of the State felt the pinch on the instant, and, like the precious champions of law that they were, flew to the Judges. They took nothing by the motion; but they and their allies all over the North have ever since continued their efforts to make something out of this judicial resort. Had they succeeded at first, they must have infallibly destroyed the Government. Now they can only hope, at best, to cripple it; but even that they consider well worth the trying.

abstract: on the Duty of Suppressing the Rebellion
snippet: on the Duty of Suppressing the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: We have received a copy of a most admirable speech by GERRITT SMITH, on the supreme duty of standing by the Government to put down the rebellion. It is marked by thorough patriotism, good judgment and common sense. He insists that "the rebellion must be put down, and that all hands must help put it down." Republicans, Democrats and Abolitionists, waiving all differences and giving up all party feeling on other points, must, on this point, "become one party." He admits that the Abolitionists, by their talking and writing, did much to annoy the South, but that neither this nor anything else justified the rebellion. The Democrats now have become the champions of free discussion. "They," says Mr. SMITH, "before whose frequent mobs I had, 20 or 30 years ago, to retreat and hide, have now become the loudest-mouthed defenders of free speech."

abstract: A DANGEROUS ALTERATION OF GREENBACKS. -Yesterday afternoon a book-keeper at Earle's Hotel, in Canal-street, appeared at the Detective Office, Police Headquarters, and made complaint that a well dressed young man, apparently about 23 years of age, had, a few hours previously, passed upon him a bill purporting to be a $50 Government greenback. An examination of the note was made, when it appeared very evident that it had been quite ingeniously altered from a $2 greenback. When compared with a genuine $50 note, the cheat is quite apparent. In the centre of each of the genuine bills -- i.e. the twos and fifties -- there is a fine steel engraving, alike in all respects. This fact has doubtless suggested the idea of altering the twos. In the genuine fifties, however, the head is immediately between the word "United" and the word "States," whereas in the "twos" the words are above the engraving. In addition to this, the $50 notes are covered over on the back with the number "50," which is not the case in the altered notes. Four or five cases of this nature have recently come to the notice of the Police officers. With one exception, however, the rogues have escaped detection. No person would be likely to be deceived by them a second time; but those who deal in "fifties" would do well to examine them carefully when offered by strangers.
lead_paragraph: A DANGEROUS ALTERATION OF GREENBACKS. -Yesterday afternoon a book-keeper at Earle's Hotel, in Canal-street, appeared at the Detective Office, Police Headquarters, and made complaint that a well dressed young man, apparently about 23 years of age, had, a few hours previously, passed upon him a bill purporting to be a $50 Government greenback. In the centre of each of the genuine bills -- i.e. the twos and fifties -- there is a fine steel engraving, alike in all respects. This fact has doubtless suggested the idea of altering the twos. In the genuine fifties, however, the head is immediately between the word "United" and the word "States," whereas in the "twos" the words are above the engraving. In addition to this, the $50 notes are covered over on the back with the number "50," which is not the case in the altered notes. Four or five cases of this nature have recently come to the notice of the Police officers. With one exception, however, the rogues have escaped detection. No person would be likely to be deceived by them a second time; but those who deal in "fifties" would do well to examine them carefully when offered by strangers.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of remonstrances against Mr. CONNOLLY's Broadway Railroad bill were presented. The bill authorizing a loan for the completion of the Kings County Court-house, was ordered to a third reading. Among the bills introduced was one authorizing the New-York Common Council to construct a slip in front of the Battery. The resolutions amendatory of the Constitution in reference to the Court of Appeals, were again brought before the Senate by a vote reconsidering the adverse vote already given, and they were laid on the table.

abstract: The trial of Dr. EDWARD M. BROWN, charged with manslaughter, in procuring an abortion upon, and thereby causing the death of, CLEMENTINA ANDERSON, in November last, was commenced in this Court yesterday morning. HENRY L. CLINTON, Ex-Judge STUART and JOHN D. TOWNSEND, Esqrs., appeared as Counsel for the prisoner, and the people were represented by the District Attorney in person. This case attracted so much attention, and was so extensively commented upon at the time it occurred, that it is found very difficult to get an unbiased jury. An extra panel of 50 jurors was summoned to Court yesterday, and out of 44 who were called to the stand, only 4 were found competent. Three peremptory challenges were interposed by the defence, and three by the prosecution; the remainder had already formed or expressed an opinion, or entertained such strong impressions about the case as to disqualify them to sit as jurors. The panel having been exhausted, the Court was compelled to adjourn till Monday morning next, previous to which time 250 extra jurors are to be summoned. Several jurors, who were summoned to appear yesterday, having failed to answer to their names, were fined $25 each, to be repeated daily during their non-attendance.

abstract: The rebels have offended Neptune--that is clear. They were never thorough sailors. They never even liked water. abstract: Charles L. Brown vs. Euclid Chadsey. -- This was an action brought by a Boston shipping merchant against the defendant. President of the Farmers' Bank of Wickford, R.I., to recover for false imprisonment. The plaintiff alleged that while on his way from Pier No. 2, North River, to the Brandreth House, in this City, he was arrested at the instance of the defendant on a charge of robbing a bank, but that when taken before a magistrate, no complainant appeared. The facts were somewhat aggravated, and the jury gave the plaintiff on a former trial $2,000. That verdict was set aside on the ground of excessive damages. The second trial now resulted in a verdict of $7,500 for the plaintiff.

abstract: Polish Rebellion, the, and France
snippet: Polish Rebellion, the, and France
lead_paragraph: The Polish insurrection is likely to change the face of European politics. It dashes into a thousand pieces all the arrangements that have been made among the crowned heads for dividing among themselves the power and wealth of the people, and compels every monarch to look out first and foremost for his own safety. The King of Prussia has already taken the side of Russia, while the Emperor of Austria, taught wisdom by experience, holds aloof.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, in addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: By the steamship Anglo-Saxon, which arrived at Portland yesterday afternoon, we have advices from Europe one day later than by the City of Baltimore. She left Londonderry on the 27th. The most important news by this arrival relates to the Polish revolution. An engagement is reported to have taken place between the Poles and the Russians near Kutnow, seventy miles west of Warsaw, lasting nearly eight hours, in which the Russians were defeated, routed, and forced to take refuge on Prussian territory. Another report is, that Cossacks pursuing Polish fugitives on Austrian soil, had been pelted with stones by the people, and compelled to pass back over the frontier. Austria was expected to demand satisfaction of Russia for this violation of her territory. The Paris Constitutionnel thinks there need be no fears of a European war, as the understanding between France, England and Austria, regarding the Prussian intervention, is a sure guarantee of the maintenance of peace. There is nothing specially important by this arrival relative to the American question. There had been another Spanish Ministerial crisis. A slight rise is noted in American Cotton, but other varieties were lower in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs and Provisions dull. Consols 92 3/8@92 1/2 for money.

abstract: The speculators in nickel have raised a storm among the noble army of crossing-sweepers, which promises to spread consternation throughout Wall-street, and its right-angular adjacents, and bring upon the daylight denizens of down-town an alarming increase in the cost of patent-leather and pantaloons. The number of juvenile crossing sweepers of both sexes and tender age, who adorn the public streets and clean the crossings during that large proportion of the year in which the presence of HACKLEY's contract renders their shovels and brooms necessary, is about equal to that of a full regiment. With these unclean cleaners times were moderately good while the nickel remained at par; when it became a drug in the market, peanuts and the Old Bowery were buoyant, and the barefooted knights of the broom were wallowing in metaphorcal clover. But darker days were in store for even these embryo contractors, they are upon them even now; for the plaintive cry for a penny is but seldom indulged in with success, and as for taking the pieces of presumptive printed pasteboard which presume to represent the payable penny of the past -- with which the pockets of their former patrons are plethorically packed -- they have not fallen so low yet, and they have determined to act, and act effectively. Seeing it in the papers that those engaged in other branches of honorable and productive employments are uniting for mutual protection, they have resolved to do likewise, and, in fact, have already made sufficient progress to afford ground for the gravest apprehensions on the part of those whom they incline to hold responsible for their calamities. Their meetings have not been open to the Press or the public generally, but enough is known to enable us to warn the holders of nickel to beware of the crossing-sweepers on muddy corners. They know most of you, and without apparently intending it, they will manipulate their brooms in such a manner as to bespatter your patent leathers and injuriously soil your glossy pantaloons. Shell out your nickel or -- beware.

abstract: Premium on Gold. -- The Subscriber, who cannot change his prices with the fluctuations of gold without incurring enormous expense in advertising the changes, is compelled to sell his Pens at old prices. Thinking his customers entitled to the benefit of the premium on gold, rather than the Wall-street debasers of the best currency this country ever had, he now offers to all remitting the amount of their orders in gold, the full premium in this City on the day when received. In this way he hopes to do the country and his customers some good without injuring himself, for the MORTON PEN cannot be made without gold. When Paper Money is sent. United States is preferred over any other. A. MORTON,

abstract: Card on His Statement that Armistice or Peace had been Proposed
snippet: Card on His Statement that Armistice or Peace had been Proposed
lead_paragraph: At a meeting held at Stamford, Conn., on Tuesday evening last, I said "that propositions for an armistice or peace had been submitted to the President on the 12th December last, which, had they been accepted, would have terminated this war by the first of April, upon a basis satisfactory to the people North and South."

abstract: On Advent of Mob Law
snippet: On Advent of Mob Law
lead_paragraph: and Argus affects great alarm at the prospective advent of mob-law. It denounces the "Republican-Abolition party," as it styles the supporters of the Admistration, as a "party of mob rule; of reckless disregard of law; of intemperance, bigotry and violence," and among its specifications designed to sustain this absurd and sweeping censure, it says that "the TIMES, a leading Republican organ, cites the story of the massacre of Royalists in the French Revolution, and impliedly urges the mob to break loose and murder all Democrats in the loyal States, before fighting the Southern rebels." One knows not which most to pity, the intellectual imbecility which is compelled to resort to such balderdash in place of argument, or the reckless disregard of truth which permits it. There has never been a syllable in the TIMES which could give any candid man a shadow of warrant for imputing to it such a sentiment. Nor is there the slightest ground for the affected apprehensions of the Argus lest free speech should be suppressed by mob-law. Since the days when Democratic mobs, under party leaders, used to suppress, by force, the utterance of Anti-Slavery sentiments, public sentiment on this subject has decidedly improved. And now that the Democrats have become themselves the champions of free speech, it may be considered out of danger.

abstract: SUICIDE BY HANGING AND SUICIDE BY SHOOTING. -- A woman named ELLEN MCLAUGHLIN, residing at No. 94 Columbia-street, committed suicide about noon yesterday, by hanging herself with a rope to the bedroom door. The deceased was discovered by her nephew, a boy 14 years of age, who resided with her. She had been subject to fits of despondency, and had frequently threatened to kill herself. From appearances she perpetrated the act in the most deliberate manner. The boy, her only companion in the house, was absent at school. She divested herself of most of her clothing, and after washing her body, placed a trunk near the door, and arranging the cord over the door, swung herself off. The deceased was 42 years of age. She leaves no family... The keeper of a lager-bier saloon in Grand-street, near Eleventh, Eastern District, named DEITCHER, committed suicide about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, by shooting himself with a pistol. Disappointment in business matters is said to have been the cause.

abstract: a War with the Saints
snippet: a War with the Saints
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Salt Lake City the other day made the announcement, unexpected by most people, that a collision between the military and the Mormon citizens or Utah was imminent -- that the Governor of the Territory had ordered the arrest of the Prophet, and that the Saints were in arms to prevent it. Our correspondence from Utah for some time past, has indicated that there was trouble brewing in that quarter. Gov. HARDING, during his brief term of office, has become very offensive, officially and personally, to the Mormons. His inaugural speech was directly in antagonism with their religions prejudices, social customs and political proclivities, and was especially severe upon polygamy. The Mormons were aroused. BRIGHAM YOUNG was wroth. The people convened at the Tabernacle, denounced the Gentile Governor, and demanded his removal, as well as that of the two Territorial Associate Justices. It is probable that latterly they have interfered with his exercise of his official functions, and he, being backed up by some regular troops, and by the regiment of California volunteers which recently defeated and exterminated the Hickup Indians in the battle on Bear River, thought proper to assert and maintain by force his legitimate authority. We suppose that thus far, nothing has come of the matter but a general row, for, though we have the telegraph to Salt Lake City, we have not had a dispatch since the beginning of the week. It is fortunate, indeed, that in such a crisis we have the Pacific telegraph -- for we can thus promptly render justice and make concession from Washington on the one hand, or, on the other, reinforce our Utah army from California, Nevada and Colorado, and prepare for war before the Mormons get the advantage of us.

abstract: Advices from Port Royal to the 8th inst., are received by the arrival of the steamship Ericsson at Baltimore, with mails and dispatches for the Government. The movements against Charleston had not yet commenced, but the important preliminary order issued by Gen. HUNTER, which we publish elsewhere, shows that it may be expected soon. The last bombardment of Fort McAllister lasted twenty hours, and neither of the three Monitors engaged was injured.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Port Royal to the 8th inst., are received by the arrival of the steamship Ericsson at Baltimore, with mails and dispatches for the Government. The movements against Charleston had not yet commenced, but the important preliminary order issued by Gen. HUNTER, which we publish elsewhere, shows that it may be expected soon. The last bombardment of Fort McAllister lasted twenty hours, and neither of the three Monitors engaged was injured. A 10-inch mortar shell fell on the deck of the Passaic, but did not go through. The boats could not get near enough to the Fort to dismantle it, on account of the obstructions in the river, -- so Commander DRAYTON, the senior officer, ordered a cessation of the attack, which will not at present be renewed. A rebel Lieutenant had been captured near Charleston, who stated that secret negotiations for peace had been progressing at Richmond for three weeks, but that the papers were not allowed to allude to the fact.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported favorably to class the crime of abortion as man slaughter in the second degree. The Flatbush-avenue, Bushwick-avenue and South Seventh-street (Brooklyn) improvement bills were also reported favorably; likewise the bill authorizing the School Commissioners of New-York to raise five instead of four dollars per pupil for the support of the Grammar Schools. Among the bills introduced was one exempting the property of widows and minors from execution to the amount of $250; the Kings County Court-house bill, and the New-York Warehousing Company bill.

abstract: MELANCHOLY SUICIDE OF A WIFE--A sad case of suicide was brought before Coroner NAUMANN for investigation, yesterday afternoon, at No. 457 Pearlstreet. The victim was Mrs. MINNIE CATOIR, wife of DANIEL CATOIR, a German, who keeps a wine and lager-bier saloon at the above number. The deceased
lead_paragraph: MELANCHOLY SUICIDE OF A WIFE--A sad case of suicide was brought before Coroner NAUMANN for investigation, yesterday afternoon, at No. 457 Pearlstreet. The victim was Mrs. MINNIE CATOIR, wife of DANIEL CATOIR, a German, who keeps a wine and lager-bier saloon at the above number. The deceased had been an invalid for several years past, having been afflicted with a disease which some of the first physicians in this City pronounced to be incurable. Her severe bo[???]ly sufferings, it is believed, so worked upon her mind as to render her at times very low spirited. No suspicion was entertained by her relatives, however, that she would attempt to take her the, and her well-known reputation for patient suffering, induced her friends to believe that she was quietly abiding the time such death should come, unsolicited, to end her earthly troubles. In this they were mistaken. At 10 o'clock yesterday morning a member of the family entered her room, and there found the unfortunate woman entirely lifeless on the floor. Beneath her body was a large carving-knife. Several huge gashes in the ab[???], and a ghastly cut across her throat, showed how determined the victim had been to [???]d her existence. A note, addressed to her husband, was found on a table on her room. It was written in German, but the following is the substance:

abstract: morning but for a mention of a very charming, and in every way agreeable reception, given last night at DODWORTH's studied building, by the artists resident in that delightful locality. The usual mass of gay men and women, literary individuals and artistic personages, responded affirmatively to the courteous invitation of the Committee, Messrs. COLMAN, GRAY and HAZELTINE, and formed a kaleidoscopic view paralleled only by the meritorious creations of the pencil, which hung silent on the walls. Works by Ken[???], Richards, Coleman, Gray, Hazeltine, Carpenter, Lang, H[???], Church and others, with the never-falling and always good contribution from the humanitarian artist ROGERS, who is one of the very best of our esthetic teachers who have seized ideas, suggestions or inspiration from the event of the Nine-teenth Century, and who have reproduce on canvas or in marble the deeds of the day. A more pleasant gathering has never been attended, and the thanks of the guests are due, as they doubtless are rendered, to the hosts of the evening for the kind hospitality and the mature culture of judgment when marked the entertainment provided.

abstract: A warning for; intended rebel operations
snippet: A warning for; intended rebel operations
lead_paragraph: pers of the Southwest announce with much glee that Gen. STERLING PRICE has returned from a visit to Richmond, having obtained all the authority he desired for moving upon a new field of operations. This means unmistakably that Gen. PRICE is to be transferred to the Department west of the Mississippi River, for it is added that Gens. HOLMES and HINDMAN are called east of the Mississippi River, which would leave the Western Department without a head, unless STERLING PRICE were going there. It is further stated that Gen. KIRBY SMITH is to go to Arkansas. It appears, then, that Gen. PRICE and KIRBY SMITH are the officers chosen by the Confederate Government to restore their cause west of the Mississippi, so desperately broken down in HINDMAN's hands.

abstract: Cost of Wars from 179??? to ???315; Resources of the Country During War
snippet: Cost of Wars from 179??? to ???315; Resources of the Country During War
lead_paragraph: The latest cry of the croakers is that we must end the war at all hazards this Spring, -- that if we can whip the rebels by a vigorous effort very well, but if not we must "bow to our destiny and make the best attainable peace." And the reason given for this advice is, that the war is exhausting our resources -- that our business is prostrated, our population diminished, our taxes becoming insupportable, the career of our prosperity checked, and the whole vigor and vitality of the nation wasted. We must stop the war, say these timid or disloyal souls, or rush upon financial, commercial and national ruin.

abstract: We need not remind the public of New-York of the meeting to-night, at the Academy of Music, to inaugurate the Loyal League of Union citizens. The mere fact that the brave, honest, eloquent and true patriot, ANDREW JOHNSON, is to be the chief orator, will bring out more citizens than can be got into any building in New-York. It will be seen that the women of New-York are particularly invited to attend. Let everybody come to the meeting, and, if the women alone fill the Academy to overflowing, the men will doubtless be accommodated with brilliant speakers in the streets.

abstract: We have advices from Europe, two days later, by the steamship Australasian, which arrived at this port last evening. She left Liverpool on the 28th ult., and Queenstown on the 1st inst. The  news by this arrival is interesting. Mr. SEWARD'S  dispatch, declining the acceptance of LOUIS NAPOLEON'S latest peace preposition, had reached
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Europe, two days later, by the steamship Australasian, which arrived at this port last evening. She left Liverpool on the 28th ult., and Queenstown on the 1st inst. The news by this arrival is interesting. Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch, declining the acceptance of LOUIS NAPOLEON'S latest peace preposition, had reached England, and received much attention. The London Times and Morning Post are very bitter against it, while some other prints are disposed to view it with favor. All, however, agree that it effectually shuts the door against tiny further attempts at mediation. The rebel lean is said to be all taken by Continental capitalists. The Mayor of Liverpool had given a grand banquet to the commanders of the American relief ships. A deputation from Birmingham had visited Minister ADAMS, and presented him an address. The aspect of the Polish question remains unchanged, so far as the action of the Government is concerned. The revolution appears to be daily gaining strength. The report comes from Paris that the French Government has received unwelcome news from Mexico. Gen. FOREY, it is said, despairs of being able to capture even Puebla, without a still further reinforcement of troops. There had been no change in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs were dull, and in Provisions nothing was doing. Consols unchanged.

abstract: The Mexican War and the Jecker Bonds; The Jecker bonds--the World
snippet: The Mexican War and the Jecker Bonds; The Jecker bonds--the World
lead_paragraph: The World is quite right in its statement that a notion is very prevalent that a large part of the "Jecker bonds" are in the hands of "high personages about the Imperial Court of France," and that a desire to give value to these bonds was a powerful motive for the Mexican war. It attaches, however, altogether too much importance to the statement of a London firm, that "more than nine-tenths of the bonds, which in the whole amount only to three, not four millions sterling, are now deposited in the City of Mexico, either in the hands of the inspectors of the affairs of the JECKERS, or as collaterals for their debts." The firm which makes the statement is a creditor of JECKER, and has, therefore, a direct interest in the matter which detracts somewhat from its authority.

abstract: publish a letter in another column which throws considerable light on the recent capture of Gen. STOUGHTON at Fairfax Courthouse. It embodies an extract of a letter from an officer who was with Gen. S., and who predicts his capture in precisely the manner in which it took place. It seems he had become quite intimate with a woman living in the town, who was clearly an agent and decoy of the rebels, and who simply betrayed this confiding General into their hands. This is by no means the only instance in which this rebel strategy has been successfully practiced. The betrayal of Samson by Delilah is a military precedent of which the rebels are very fond, and of which also they have made profitable use.

abstract: A very large meeting was held at Cooper Institute last evening, in response to a call, issued by the Dry Goods Clerks' Early-Closing Association, for a public meeting to sustain the objects of the organization. In the absence of the Mayor, Mr. J.B. GRAY, President of the Association, took the Chair and called upon the audience to sustain the movement. He hoped the ladies present would pledge themselves to a total abstinence from evening shopping. [Applause.] The consent of most of the merchants had already been obtained to close the stores at 7 P.M., instead of 10 P.M. as formerly. It was only necessary to have the public indorsement of the movement. [Applause.]

abstract: The confirmation by the Senate of Mr. CLAY's appointment as Minister to Russia, places us under the painful necessity of appealing to his own good sense to decide whether he ought to accept the place or not. It seems to us, and we think nine-tenths of the public will agree with us, that he ought
lead_paragraph: The confirmation by the Senate of Mr. CLAY's appointment as Minister to Russia, places us under the painful necessity of appealing to his own good sense to decide whether he ought to accept the place or not. It seems to us, and we think nine-tenths of the public will agree with us, that he ought for divers reasons to decline it. What office of State it is which he would fill with most credit to himself and most advantage to the country, we confess we are unable to say. But we know one office which he certainly cannot fill, either with credit or advantage, and that is, the office of Minister Plenipotentiary at the Court of a first-class Power. Nature has indicated in the clearest manner, that she did not mean him to be a diplomatist, and his education has not been of a kind to lessen the force of her prohibition. To serve the Republic well in a diplomatic capacity at this crisis in her history, a man needs tact, discretion, judgment, a spirit of subordination, some knowledge of foreign languages, or at least of French, much knowledge of foreign life, and its manners and usages. He needs, above all things, to remember also that diplomacy, like war, is but a means to an end; that it is the art of keeping up the influence and protecting the rights and interests of one's Government by fair words, and skillful arguments, and dextrous play upon the passions and prejudices of those with whom one is dealing. He needs to remember that the resort on the part of an Ambassador to bullying, abuse or invective, is as absurd and as futile as knocking a man down with a cudgel in order to make him love you. Whenever the relations between two Powers assume such a character as to call for violent and threatening language, diplomacy, properly so-called, retires and makes way for the army and the fleet. The Minister shuts up his portfolio and goes home, and the General takes his place.

abstract: --The will of the late Mrs. Blandina Dudley has been admitted to probate in Albany, R.J. Hilton, E. E. Kendrick and R. 11. Pruvn are the executors. The will was made in December 1859.
lead_paragraph: -- The will of the late Mrs. Blandina Dudley has been admitted to probate in Albany, R.J. Hilton, E. E. Kendrick and R. 11. Pruvn are the executors. The will was made in December 1859, and disposes of the property as follows: Silver and plated ware to her nephews and nieces, except R.B. Miller, of Utica, and Sarah B. Tibbils, of Troy. Apparel, diamonds and personal ornaments to surviving nieces, except Mrs. T.; $26,000 to John B. Mitler, Utica; $10,000 to her niece, Catherine Nelison, of New-Brunswick; $5,000 to the children of Rev. Henry Stanley, of Rock Island; $2,000 to Mary A. Wood, of Rock Island; $3,000 to James E. Ten Evck, of New-York; $4,000 to Isabella Forbes, (cook); $1,000 to Eliza Van Worner, (servant); $3,000 to Wm.A. Deitz, Albany; $[???],000 to Albany Orphan Asylum; $1,000 in Children's Friend Society, Albany; $4,000 to North Dutch Church; $500 to Second-street Mission Church; $500 of African Baptist Church; $30,000 to Dudley Observatory, for establishing the "B[???]andina Professorship;" $500 a year to Catherine M. Cook, R.I., or the equivalent of the annuity in money; $1,000 each to her executors, [???] addition to fees, &c., viz: Robert J. Hilton, E.E. Kendrick and Robert H. Pruyn. The remainder of the estate is equally divided between Mrs. Elizabeth T[???]s, Albany, Mrs. Gov. Seymour, and John B. Miller, of Utica. Of the above John B. Miller and Isabella Forbes are dead. Previous to her death Mrs. D had disposed of more than half a million of property, principally to relatives.

abstract: ADMIRAL:I have the honor to report to you that I left the landing below Vicksburgh, in obediance to your written instructions, on the night of the 10th lost, taking with me the De Soto and coal barge, and proceeded down the river. We passed Warrenton without interruption, and reached Red River on the following evening. I destroyed, as you directed, the skills and flatboats among either shore.

abstract: An arrival from Port Royal, yesterday, brings intelligence to March 10. Nothing of importance had transpired since the departure of the last steamer; but the following important orders have reached us.  GENERAL ORDERS,NO.16.--SOLDIERS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE SOUTH: After long and wearying delays, due to cause over when no one in this Department had control, we have at length the cheering prospect of active and very important service.

abstract: On the Union Safe, but Despotism Possible
snippet: On the Union Safe, but Despotism Possible
lead_paragraph: The Postmaster-General made a valuable addition to the polemics of the rebellion, in the brief letter he addressed to Mayor OPDYKE and others, in answer to their invitation to attend the late Union meeting in this City. We published the letter in Tuesday's TIMES, and bespeak for it the consideration it deserves. The point made by Mr. BLAIR is this: That it is not really a dismemberment of the Union that we have to fear as the permanent result of the pending war, but the overthrow of its vital principle -- the sovereignty of the people. The Union, in his opinion, is safe enough. The physical conformation of the country will defy all attempts to permanently dissever it. Its lakes and gulfs, its rivers and bays, its canals and other highways, "bringing the seas to the homes of all the cultivators of the continent," renders the dissolution of the Union which grows out of the necessities of commerce "as impossible as the destruction of the system provided by nature for that intercourse." We may fight with ever so much discontent and determination to be out of the Union; but once out, we may be sure there is not an original party to it that will not ere long fight with equal determination to be in again.
headline: {'main': 'Union Sure, but Despotism Possible.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Union Sure, but Despotism Possible.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Speech at New-York Union Meeting
snippet: Speech at New-York Union Meeting
lead_paragraph: The speeches made at the great Union meeting at Cooper Institute ten days ago seem to be very accceptable to the people everywhere, as they were to the audience that listened to them. Especially do the people commend JOHN VAN BUREN's speech as one recalling the promise of his earlier years. He is not the only one who has found a strange freedom of utterance in speaking on behalf of the country. We all recollect the narrative given by Parson BROWNLOW of his long-standing bronchial troubles, which left him as soon as he began to tell the men of the North of the patriotism and sufferings of the loyal East Tennesseans, and to urge them to similar true-heartedness and devotion. And it has been so everywhere. Among the freest and best speeches made for the National cause, have been those which have come from men who trampled upon party ties in making them.

lead_paragraph: On the 26th a deputation waited upon Mr. ADAMS, the United States Minister, for the purpose of presenting him with an address signed by more than 13,500 of the inhabitants of Birmingham on the subject of the American crisis. The deputation was intro duced by Mr. BRIGHT, M. P., and consisted of Mr. CHARLES STURGE ,(the ex-Mayor), Mr.HENRY MANTON, Mr. GEORGE EDMONDS, (Clerk of the peace), Mr.JAMES TAYLOR, jun., Mr. WILLIAM MORGAN, and Mr. J.A. PASTRIDGE.

abstract: PROBABLE SUICIDE. -- Coroner BARRETT held an inquest on Friday, at No. 314 Grand-street, E.D., on the body of a German, named ANDREAS DACHERT, who is supposed to have comitted suicide the evening previous, by shooting himself. From the testimony it appears that deceased had had trouble with his wife, and had threatened, in the presence of several persons, to destroy his life. Mrs. DACHERT, having reason to suppose that he was about to make the attempt, ran out to procure the presence of a neighbor, and shortly after the report of fire-arms was heard. Upon going in DACHERT was found lying upon the floor, where he died almost immediately. He was shot through the breast, the ball passing between the lungs and severing an artery. The pistol was found lying on the floor.

lead_paragraph: FATAL BURNING ACCIDENT. -- At about 10 o'clock on Friday night, a fatal burning accident occurred at the house of Mr. ROTHCHILDS, No. 187 Avenue D, whereby a domestic lost her life and an infant was so severely burned that it is thought it cannot recover. It appears that Mr. and Mrs. ROTHCHILDS had gone out to spend the evening, leaving the children in charge of FRANCES KOCH, a German servant aged 26 years. The children, while playing, ran against a table upon which stood a lighted kerosene oil lamp. The table was overturned, the lamp broken and the contents se[???] in every direction. The clothes of the domestic caught fire while she was endeavoring to save the children. The infant, which she held in her arms when the accident occurred, she threw upon a bed in the room and ran up two [???]lights of stairs to alarm the neighbors [???], w[???] time, being completely envelop[???] [???]es. She was met on the second landing by [???] the occupants of the house who threw his over [???] arround her and did all he could to extinguish the [???], but the poor girl was so badly burned that she died soon afterwards. The Coroner was noticed and withheld so inquest upon the body to-day.

abstract: We have this morning a partial confirmation of the report of a decided success in the Yazoo River, as published yesterday--that is, we have another report, a little more definite. A dispatch
lead_paragraph: We have this morning a partial confirmation of the report of a decided success in the Yazoo River, as published yesterday -- that is, we have another report, a little more definite. A dispatch from Memphis states that Admiral PORTER has received information that the Yazoo Pass Expedition had captured Yazoo City, and destroyed the rebel fleet known to be there. Another dispatch from Memphis states that the Admiral was momentarily expecting intelligence from Haines' Bluff that our forces had arrived there from above -- which would be the signal for a combined attack upon the rebel fortifications there. Meantime an official dispatch from another source lends a now aspect to affairs on the Mississippi. Gen. ROSECRANS has telegraphed to the War Department a report which has reached him, to the effect that the rebels have evacuated Vicksburgh. Information had previously reached Washington that they were removing their stores and war material into the interior, and the report of the evacuation is not at all unlikely.

abstract: out fully authenticated news from the Yazoo River. It is quite possible that the telegraphic rumors of the taking of Yazoo City, the destruction of the rebel vessels, and the capture of several thousand rebel troops, may be correct. We know that a strong naval force from Admiral PORTER's squadron, accompanied by a land force, had cut their way through Yazoo Pass, entered and ascended the Cold water River, and ten days ago had nearly reached the point where the Tallahatchie pours into the Yazoo. When they got to that point, they had fewer national difficulties to encounter than had previously impeded their progress. And if our fleet was able to rush down and make a sudden assault upon the rebel vessels and land force at Yazoo City, it is quite likely that short work was made with them all. It is true, there were very great dangers attending this expedition, danger of rebel shore batteries, danger of torpedoes, danger of encountering a greater force than was anticipated. Indeed, we were very much in the dark as to what we would meet. But it would be just like our Western Navy, if it had added another neat and splendid victory to its already glorious roll.

abstract: on a Counter-revolution in the West
snippet: on a Counter-revolution in the West
lead_paragraph: The loyalists of Missouri have just experienced a sensation, in the publication of a letter, addressed by one Col. ALEXANDER M. WOOLFOLK, of the Missouri State Militia, to Maj. A. W. MULLINS, a member of the present General Assembly of Missouri. The letter takes a very wide range. It treats at large on the revolutionary spirit abroad. It says "the times are fraught with events of startling magnitude." It declares that, "in the frenzy of the hour, new and startling dogmas are daily broached, and seem to enlist the support of a party in the country, just in proportion to their strangeness and novelty." Having prepared the recipient of his epistolary favor for any absurdity, by these quite truthful preliminary statements, Col. WOOLFOLK proceeds to make his contribution to the "startling dogmas" of the frenzied hour. His proposition is that the Western States, disgusted with President LINCOLN and the war, and giving up the Union as hopeless, shall set up a new Republic for themselves, of which Missouri shall be "one of the brightest stars in the galaxy."
headline: {'main': '" The Frenzy of the Hour."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': '" The Frenzy of the Hour."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

These seats are arranged in blocks, spreading backward into the aisles.

abstract: Mercury--The Rebel Game of Brag
snippet: Mercury--The Rebel Game of Brag
lead_paragraph: The storm of war which gathers along the coast of South Carolina and Georgia, is manifestly not unnoticed by the rebels. Every account which comes from there speaks of immense preparations on their part to meet the imminent attack; and that these will be found to be skillful and extensive, we have no doubt. Nor do they confine themselves to mere material preparation -- to building fortifications and mounting guns. They join with these, as we notice, something of the Chinese mode of warfare, to which they have shown themselves addicted heretofore. They do not, indeed, beat Chinese gongs, or put on hideous masks, or perform horrible contortions in front of our lines of battle; but the American gong, the newspaper, they bring into most vigorous use. The columns of the Charleston papers are filled with the most terrible threats of the fate which awaits our troops whenever the attack is made, and with loud-sounding glorification of the prowess of the rebels and the invulnerability of their fortifications.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Game of Brag.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Game of Brag.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A man named THOMAS NORRIS was badly stabbed at a late hour last night, by a man named GAYON, a notorious character in the Fourth Ward. The affray occurred in the saloon of JOHN MEEHAN, No. 92 Cherry-street. There was no dispute between the parties GAYON making the assault without provocation. NORRIS was cut in the throat and about the head and face. His right eve also was completely cut out. GAYON was arrested by Officer WALKER and locked up in the Fourth Ward Station-house.

abstract: the Value of Union
snippet: the Value of Union
lead_paragraph: Americans are indignant because the Press and the publicists of Europe cannot be made to comprehend the nature of the cause which the North is battling to uphold. Why wonder at this perversity in foreigners, when we see a party growing up in out midst who pronounce that cause unjust and detestable, and who are laboring to destroy that unanimity in the Free States, which is indispensable to the triumph of the National Government?

abstract: In compliance with the call issued by certain of our citizens, who desired to inaugurate a Loyal League, which should, in its membership, devote its influence and its power to the suppression of treason, and the perpetuation of the Union, an immense audience assembled at the Academy of Music last night. Tickets of admission, with Union badges, had been furnished to every loyal man or woman who desired then, and we learn that the demand was such that twenty buildings like the Academy would not have sufficed to accommodate them. Thousands of people had gathered about the doors of the Academy long before the doors were opened, and at the appointed hour they rushed in, filling every seat in the parquet and the various circles in less time than they were ever filled before.

abstract: The " Union League of New-York City" was inaugurated at the Academy of Music last evening by an audience of ladies and gentlemen, larger in numbers, and more enthusiastic in spirit than was probably ever before gathered within the walls of the Academy. The theatre was literally crammed from pit to dome lone before the
lead_paragraph: The " Union League of New-York City" was inaugurated at the Academy of Music last evening by an audience of ladies and gentlemen, larger in numbers, and more enthusiastic in spirit than was probably ever before gathered within the walls of the Academy. The theatre was literally crammed from pit to dome lone before the proceedings were opened, and in the course of the evening thousands were compelled to go away unable to gain admission. JAS. T. BRADY, Esq., was appointed Chairman of the meeting, and made the opening speech of the evening, which was even more emphatic, and anti-copper-headed than the one delivered by him at the Cooper Institute a week before. Mr. BRADY was followed by Gov. WRIGHT, of Indiana, and Gov. ANDY JOHNSON, of Tennessee, who were received with unbounded applause, and made out-and-out thorough-going war speeches. The meeting closed at 11 1/2 o'clock with a patriotic song by the Union Glee Club, followed by nine cheers for Govs. WRIGHT and JOHNSON, and the sentiments they had uttered.

abstract: Mr. GREELEY protested, in sending us the letter, which we gave our readers on Saturday morning, that he did not ask its publication as a favor at our hands. With every disposition to oblige him, we are unable to conceive how the publication of that letter could have been construed into a "favor" to him, even by the most indulgent of his friends. His worst enemy could have done him no worse turn.

abstract: -- We publish  in another column a letter from E.W. STOUGHTON, Esq., of this City, in reply to a communication in the TIMES of Saturday, concerning the recent capture of Gen. STOUGHTON by a rebel night-raid at Fairfax Court-house. Mr. S. submits for public consideration sundry circumstances which, in his judgment, refute utterly the most serious of the imputations contained in that communication upon the personal and professional character of Gen. STOUGHTON. Simple justice to the General requires that they should receive all the weight to which they are entitled. The public is inclined just now, without doubt, to judge with rigor and severity the conduct of every officer who fails, whether through his own fault or not, to perform the special service committed to his hands. At the same time, we do not doubt the public willingness to give a fair hearing to whatever may be said in extenuation of such grave faults as those which are laid to the General's charge.

abstract: An invitation is circulated, signed by a number of the most influential lay members of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this City and vicinity, for a meeting to be held in John-street Church today at 3 P.M., "for the purpose of giving the friends of lay representatives in the M.E. Church an opportunity for consultation and comparison of views." The circular further says: "It is the judgment of many that the times call for the adoption of some measures to further this good and beneficent movement. Our brethren in Philadelphia having issued a call for a Convention of laymen, it is proper that the Methodists of New-York should make some appropriate response." From what we read and hear, we judge that the object aimed at by this meeting is attracting increased attention in the Methodist Episcopal Church, and that this meeting on Monday will be very largely attended. The circular announces that Bishop SIMPSON, who is understood warmly to favor the movement, and Gov. WRIGHT, of Indiana, will be present. The call is signed by a class of gentlemen who exert a wide and beneficial influence in the church of which they are members and ornaments.

abstract: His Position on the Peace Question; Copperheads, The, and Public Opinion
snippet: His Position on the Peace Question; Copperheads, The, and Public Opinion
lead_paragraph: We are for crushing the Secesh; we are also for crushing the Copperhead. To our mind, there is not, essentially, a jot's difference between them. They are simply varieties of the same species. The one moves in the highway, the other in the grass. The one carries his venom in the head, the other in the tail. The one strikes at the heart, the other at the heel. But they are alike malignant, alike detestable, alike fatal to the Republic.

abstract: The Mock Monitor at the Siege of
snippet: The Mock Monitor at the Siege of
lead_paragraph: -- Take it for all in all, the tremendous feat of PORTER's mock Monitor is rather the funniest thing of the war, and the more we hear of it the more laughable the affair seems. We give this morning an account of it written by Admiral PORTER himself, another from a Vicksburgh paper, and a third from our own correspondent. "ERICSSON," says PORTER, "saved the country with an iron Monitor -- why could not I save it with a wooden one?" The Richmond Examiner, however, in its description of the "turreted monster," was wrong in characterizing it as a vessel with a "small house taken from the back garden of a plantation" on top of it. As described by its inventor, the monster was simply a broken down coal barge which was picked up in the river, with a few old boards run around it, some empty pork barrels piled on top of each other for smoke-stacks, and with furnaces built of mud, for the purpose of vomiting forth black smoke.
headline: {'main': 'THE TURRETED MONSTER AGAIN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE TURRETED MONSTER AGAIN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Reappearance of in Public
snippet: Reappearance of in Public
lead_paragraph: The reappearance in public of Mr. ISAAC TOUCEY, after two years of enforced seclusion, is one of those incidents which must convince the most despondent and most unfortunate of the folly of despair. His speech at Hartford, the other night must, we imagine, have sent a thrill of joy through every abode of sin and wretchedness throughout the length and breadth of the land. There is a popular notion that there is a large class of offences for which condemnation or pardon on this side of the grave is hopeless; and we none of us ever listen to five minutes' conversation upon the vanity of worldly things, without hearing men's hardness, uncharitableness and bitterness toward the victims of misfortune descanted upon as one of the most lamentable and notorious facts of this sorrowful life. There is, we are told, on all sides a disposition to accelerate the movement of persons who show any tendency downwards; a strong desire to keep down those who have once fallen, to treasure the memory of their fault, to doubt the sincerity of their repentance, and to predict their relapse. If the sinner's own conscience makes his way hard when he is sinning, his fellows make it harder when he is trying to amend; and vast numbers of those who are groping in darkness are said to prefer the horrors of their situation to facing the jeers and scoffings and scorn that would hail their reappearance in the light.

abstract: -- We are glad to learn, through the advertisement of the Naval Bureau of Ordnance, that proposals for wrought-iron rifled 100-pounders are invited. The wording of the advertisement, however, -- that the guns are to stand 1,000 rounds with the service charges, "without bursting, or wearing in such a manner as to cause apprehensions of bursting" -- is deemed very unsatisfactory by iron-workers, on the ground that the whole case is finally left, not to the developed and most obvious fact of bursting, or not bursting, but to the mere theoretical opinion of officials.
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to learn, through the advertisement of the Naval Bureau of Ordnance, that proposals for wrought-iron rifled 100-pounders are invited. abstract: The intelligence from our forces operating on the Mississippi is important, though not so definite as we could desire. A dispatch from Cairo brings us advices from Memphis to Thursday evening. A movement of troops was taking place below, from which important results were expected immediately. It was believed that Vicksburgh must soon capitulate or suffer a worse late. The Yazoo Pass operations appear to have given us some great advantage, of which we have as yet hardly more than a hint. One dispatch states that Admiral PORTER has received information that the Expedition had captured Yazoo City, and destroyed the rebel fleet known to be there. Another dispatch states that the Admiral was momentarily expecting intelligence from Haines' Bluff that our forces had arrived there from above -- which would be the signal for a combined attack upon the rebel fortifications there. Meantime an official dispatch from another source lends a new aspect to affairs on the Mississippi. Gen. ROSECRANS has telegraphed to the War Department a report which has reached him, to the effect that the rebels have evacuated Vicksburgh. Information had previously reached Washington that they were removing their stores and war material into the interior, and the report of the evacuation is quite likely to be true.

abstract: UNION MEETING AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A meeting of the loyal citizens of Brooklyn, under the auspices of the War Fund Committee, will be held at the Academy of Music this evening for the purpose of reaffirming a determination to encourage and sustain the Government in its efforts to quell the rebellion, and at all hazards of life and property to maintain and perpetuate the Constitution and the Union. Hon. ANDREW JOHNSON, of Tennessee; Hon. J. WRIGHT, of Indiana: Hon. JAS. T. BRADY, Hon. JOHN VAN BUREN, and other prominent men have been invited to address the meeting.

abstract: Ayres, Brig.-Gen., deserved promotion of
snippet: Ayres, Brig.-Gen., deserved promotion of
lead_paragraph: -- Among the recent promotions to the post of Brigadier-General, none will give more universal satisfaction to all who appreciate sterling merit, than that of Capt. AYRES, who has commanded one or more batteries of artillery from the very commencement of the war, and who has rendered most distinguished service in nearly every battle that has been fought since the first gun was fired. He is an officer of rare merit and of still rarer modesty -- never obtruding his services or his claims on public attention, or on the notice of the official authorities; and one result of this has been, that while hundreds of officers who have rendered far less service were pushed rapidly forward to the very highest positions, he remained plain Captain AYRES, though for much of the time doing the duty of a Brigadier, but on a captain's pay. At the battle of Antietam he had six batteries under his command, and at the crisis of the engagement was sent for by Gen, MCCLELLAN, who asked him if he could take his artillery across a stream in front, and through some marshy ground which bordered it. "Sir," was his reply, "I can take my artillery wherever it is wanted." He did take it where it was wanted, and where it carried fearful carnage into the rebel ranks. The Government cannot afford to leave such men in the rear ranks, merely because they will not push themselves forward for promotion.
headline: {'main': 'A DESERVED PROMOTION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A DESERVED PROMOTION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FROM THE STATE CAPITAL.  The House resolutions, raising a Grinding Committee, are well-guarded, and were passed after a full understanding of their scope. The only intention was that the Committee should be a genuine help, and not a machine to grind grists that never should be ground under any circumstances, and would not be, except possibly by a Committee under the control of the owner of the grists.
lead_paragraph: FROM THE STATE CAPITAL.
