abstract: The combined advantages of fine weather and public enthusiasm, exercised a desirable influence over Mr. MARETZEK'S fortunes last week. Three evening performances and a matinee were given, the last a brilliant affair on Saturday, that attracted an overflowing representation of our New-York fair ones, and was in all respects eminently successful.
lead_paragraph: The combined advantages of fine weather and public enthusiasm, exercised a desirable influence over Mr. MARETZEK's fortunes last week. Three evening performances and a matinee were given, the last a brilliant affair on Saturday, that attracted an overflowing representation of our New-York fair ones, and was in all respects eminently successful. The opera performed was "Ernani" -- one of the most pronounced of VERDI's works, and well calculated to show off the strength of the company. We have already referred to its production, and need only say, that its repetition was free from the usual nesligencies and omissions that characterize matinee performances. The artists were in superb voice, and combining suitable, and frequently powerful, action with their vocal vehemencies, brought down the house with legitimate bursts of applause. It is conceded now on all sides, that Mr. MARETZEK's troupe is the best we have had here for many years. The plan of the campaign, both as regards these leading artists and the important auxiliaries of orchestra and chorus, is on the largest scale. When it is remembered that, notwithstanding the increased expenses of the establishment, the prices remain at the lowest standard, it will be seen that the most genial support of the public is needed to make the experiment only moderately successful. The enthusiasm that prevails seems to promise the happiest results to the energetic impresairo. It will not be lessened by an entire change in the programme of the present week. So far we have had nothing but VERDI; the present week -- opening with "Norma" to-night -- is devoted to BELLINI. Mme. MEDORI appears as the Druidess, a role in which she has excited the raptures of critical audiences, and Signor MAZZOLINI has consented to sing the rather unimportant music of Pollio. The caste in other respects includes the principal artists of the troupe, and the orchestra will be under the able direction of Mr. MARETZEK.

abstract: -- An excellent association has just been formed in this City, with the title of the "Protective War-Claim Association," under the Presidency of Gen. SCOTT, and having for its directors Senator MORGAN, Mayor OPDYKE, JOHN JACOB ASTOR, WM.E. DODGE, GEORGE BANCROFT, and other gentlemen of equal public distinction and distinguished patriotism, with the object of acting between the soldiers of this State and the Government, in the claims of the former for pay, pensions, etc. The action of the Association will be in some sense a complement to the operations of the "Allotment system," which has effected such a large amount of benefit to the volunteers and their families. It will secure the just claims of soldiers and sailors and their families; will protect them from imposture and fraud, and will furnish them advice and information, while at the same time it will aid the Government and the country, by preventing false claims from being made against them. All its work is to be done without cost to the claimant, and it will be sustained by the subscriptions of such patriotic gentlemen of this City and State as may be willing thus to serve the country and the soldiers. The character of the gentlemen who act as officers of the Association places it far above suspicion of the possibility of any interested motive, and will secure for it at once the complete confidence of every New-York soldier and sailor in the National service.

abstract: The friends and supporters of the recently revived movement providing for lay representatives in the Methodist Episcopal Church, assembled at the John-street Church yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of taking the subject into consideration. The attendance was very large, and much interest was manifested in the proceedings. The meeting was called to order by Mr. B.L. Ross, and upon his nomination Mr. HIRAM FORRESTER was elected President. Mr. MARK HOYT acted as Secretary. A list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries was then read and approved, after which a fervent prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. DERBY.

abstract: Baird, Rev. Robert, D. D.
snippet: Baird, Rev. Robert, D. D.
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. ROBERT BAIRD, D.D., died at Yonkers, on Sunday, March 15, in the 65th year of his age. Dr. BAIRD was of Scottish descent, and was born in Fayette County, Penn., on Oct. 6, 1798. He pursued his studies at Washington and Jefferson Colleges, and graduated at the latter in 1818. During the year following he was engaged in teaching at Bellefont, contributing frequently to the local newspaper published in that village. In 1819, be entered the Princeton Theological Seminary, and completed a full course there, discharging the duties of tutor in the college during the last year of his connection with the Seminary. After completing his theological studies, he took charge of an academy in Princeton, and held the situation for more than five years, preaching as opportunity offered in the churches of that city and vicinity, and upon resigning that position, in which he had acquitted himself with great credit, he commenced his labors in behalf of our prominent religious and benevolent societies, and in these he spent his life. First he proposed and carried into execution a plan for supplying each destitute family in New-Jersey with a copy of the Holy Scriptures; next, as agent of the Missionary Society of the state, he did much toward organizing its present educational system, and in 1829 he devoted his energies to the American Sunday School Union, in the course of five years increasing its revenues from $5,000 to $25,000 per annum. In 1835 Dr. BAIRD visited Europe, where he remained for nearly eight years, laboring zealously to promote different religious and benevolent enterprises, and upon the organization of the American and Foreign Christian Union he became its agent and Corresponding Secretary. Both by the pen and voice Dr. BAIRD has given the public the benefit of his experiences and observations in his extended European tour. The courses of lectures which he delivered all over the country, upon topics connected with his journeyings, were very popular and instructive. His work upon the "State and Prospects of Religion in America" had a foreign as well as domestic reputation, and his "Visit to No. them Europe" had a wide circulation in this country. A very wide circle of friends will lament has loss.

abstract: Col. WOOLFOLK, of the Missouri State Militia, who wrote a very extravagant and very foolish letter to a member of the Legislature of that State, extolling the project of a Western Republic, has, we perceive, been ordered under arrest by Gen. LOAN, The letter, printed at Jefferson City by a contribution from members of the Assembly, was promptly suppressed. All parties are making haste to disavow their responsibility for the treasonable publication, and we may reasonably conclude this to be the last attempt that will be made to breed dissension in the Northwest.

abstract: Liquor Sales on Sunday a Misdemeanor
snippet: Liquor Sales on Sunday a Misdemeanor
lead_paragraph: -- The Supreme Court has affirmed the decision of Recorder HOFFMAN in the ease of the People vs. OSMER. The only point involved was whether "publicly keeping" liquors on Sundays or election days is a misdemeanor under the Police act of 1860. It is settled that it is not. But the civil penalty for the offence is $50 still, and the sale of liquors on Sunday is, as it has been since 1857, a misdemeanor, punishable by fine and imprisonment. The Recorder settled this point as fully as the other in his opinion, from which we quote:

abstract: The Cultivation of, in Missouri, >amp;c.
snippet: The Cultivation of, in Missouri, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: A St. Louis paper mentions the arrival in that city of two tons of cotton seed, imported from the South to be planted in Missouri fields. The production of cotton in many parts of Missouri and Kentucky is no new thing. Twenty-five years ago it was quite common for small farmers in the Southern counties of those States to grow cotton enough for their own use. Each farmer had his "small patch," and he rarely failed, with due care in its cultivation, to be rewarded for his labor. In those days roads were scarce, and cotton goods were dear before they reached the farmer, and hence the economy in the home production of the article.

abstract: The Yazoo Pass movement, we are now positively assured, has proved a complete success. Twenty-six steam boats have been captured in Yazoo River, eighteen of which were destroyed-- the rest bring probably retained for transports.
lead_paragraph: The Yazoo Pass movement, we are now positively assured, has proved a complete success. Twenty-six steam boats have been captured in Yazoo River, eighteen of which were destroyed -- the rest bring probably retained for transports. Our gunboats, at last accounts, (confirmed by a dispatch from Admiral PORTER.) had already arrived above Haines' Bluff, and the attack upon that position was soon to commence. The fortifications there were not built with a view to repelling attacks from above. A rumor of the evacuation of Vicksburgh was circulated among our forces on the Mississippi, and the supposition was, that the greater part of the rebel force would go to Chattanooga, to aid in a combined movement against Gen. ROSECRANS. The recent operations at Lake Providence and elsewhere had resulted in inundating more than a hundred miles of Louisiana territory, destroying a great deal of property, and completely drowning out the guerrillas. Gen. MCCL[???]NAND's force, on account of the breaking of the levees, had been compelled to embark for Milliken's Bend, sixteen miles above Vicksburgh.

abstract: Copperheads, The, and the Democratic Party
snippet: Copperheads, The, and the Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: It is one of the peculiarities of the serpent species that they can swallow animals much thicker than their own bodies. This is a very nice provision of nature. But sometimes, overrating their powers, they get stuck in the operation. Then the fix is very awkward. The Copperheads are now finding it so. The Democratic party proves too tough a customer. The best part of it stubbornly refuses to be swallowed. The Copperheads can neither gorge nor disgorge. The result is immense squirming.

abstract: Relief for, Wanted; River; war on the
snippet: Relief for, Wanted; River; war on the
lead_paragraph: Care for the wounded immediately after the result of a conflict on the field, in a better manner than heretofore is receiving the attention of the Press, and the subject is being agitated in the Legislature. The experience of Surgeons on the field, and, after an engagement, in hospitals -- the facts that have come to their knowledge of the wounded remaining a night and day, and even for a longer period, upon the ground, without covering and without relief -- and their return to their homes in this and other States, and making known these facts -- naturally awaken inquiry and suggest remedies. Experience is the great teacher, after all. The wonder is that so long a period has elapsed and no organized and systematized method has been adopted to remedy all this. We are not disposed to be fault-finding with the Government, or with any of its departments or officers, where these neglects may have been remedied. The past is beyond our reach. We deal with the present welfare and future good of the army. But in order that the corrective may be universally and permanently applied, the actual state of the case should be known.
headline: {'main': 'Additional Relief for Wounded Soldiers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Additional Relief for Wounded Soldiers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A First Success at
snippet: A First Success at
lead_paragraph: There seems now to be no doubt that our fleet which made its way through the Yazoo Pass and down the Cold water to the Yazoo River has at least met with its first success. A dispatch from Vicksburgh says that it had captured twenty-six rebel steamboats, eighteen of which were destroyed, and our gunboats had arrived at Haines' Bluff, which forms the outer defence of Vicksburgh on the Yazoo. An official dispatch from Admiral PORTER, under date of the 7th inst., confirms the statement of our fleet's having arrived in the Yazoo. He heard the signal of nine minute guns and three guns afterward in quick succession, which were agreed upon to be fired by the Commander of the expedition on his reaching that point.
headline: {'main': 'Vicksburgh and the Yazoo.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Vicksburgh and the Yazoo.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Church's Cotopaxi
snippet: Church's Cotopaxi
lead_paragraph: Mr. CHURCH is steadily vindicating his claim to be considered as the artistic Humboldt of the new world. His untiring pencil, like the pen of his scientific prototype, gathers force from the magnitude and grace from the amazing contrasts of the scenes which it depicts. From the castellated grandeur of Arctic icebergs to the bewildering luxuriance of tropical plains, from the leaping thunders of Niagara to the majestic repose of the Andes, he ranges with a steady eye and an unwavering hand. For a long time CHURCH was canonized by one class of critics and anathematized by another as a very Parsee among painters, a kind of cross between the Magian and the Inca, whose studio was a "Temple of the Sun," and whose genius turned on

abstract: The habitues of the Academy of Music -- and under this name may be included, since Mr. MARETZEK's arrival, nearly all the musical community of the City -- were sorely disappointed yesterday evening to find that there could be no performance owing to the indisposition of Mme. MEDORI. A certificate of her attending physician says that the lady is laboring under a throat disease, but that she will probably be able to sing on Wednesday next. The undercurrents of the operatic world are so mysterious and yet so powerful, that it is hardly safe on all occasions to waste one's sympathy on a suffering singer. In this case Dr. QUIN certifies to the inability of the lady to discharge her duties, and Mr. MARETZEK is compelled in consequence to suffer a heavy pecuniary loss, so that we may believe the postponement is based on genuine grounds. On Wednesday next "Norma" will be produced, or if Mme. MEDORI is still unwell, another opera in its stead.
lead_paragraph: The habitues of the Academy of Music -- and under this name may be included, since Mr. MARETZEK's arrival, nearly all the musical community of the City -- were sorely disappointed yesterday evening to find that there could be no performance owing to the indisposition of Mme. MEDORI. A certificate of her attending physician says that the lady is laboring under a throat disease, but that she will probably be able to sing on Wednesday next. The undercurrents of the operatic world are so mysterious and yet so powerful, that it is hardly safe on all occasions to waste one's sympathy on a suffering singer. In this case Dr. QUIN certifies to the inability of the lady to discharge her duties, and Mr. MARETZEK is compelled in consequence to suffer a heavy pecuniary loss, so that we may believe the postponement is based on genuine grounds. On Wednesday next "Norma" will be produced, or if Mme. MEDORI is still unwell, another opera in its stead.

abstract: An arrival from Havana brings us late Mexican news. The French Army is said to have commenced its march toward Puebla on the 19th uit., on which day the sappers and miners left Orizata--the artlery following on the 21st, and Gen. FOREY himself on the 23d. The attack on
lead_paragraph: An arrival from Havana brings us late Mexican news. The French Army is said to have commenced its march toward Puebla on the 19th uit., on which day the sappers and miners left Orizata -- the artlery following on the 21st, and Gen. FOREY himself on the 23d. The attack on Puebla was expected to commence about the 1st inst. The Mexican commander, ORTEGA, had 24,000 men inside the city, while COMONFORT had 8,000 or 10,000 more for the outer defences. The guerrillas around Vera Cruz continued to give the French a great deal of trouble. Four hundred of the negro troops from Egypt had arrived, but the voyage did not agree with them, and over a hundred of them immediately went into hospital. The report of the occupation of Minititlan by the French is confirmed by an arrival at this port.

abstract: The case of Michael Moore, indicted for murder on the high seas, was called on for trial this morning. abstract: Speech in New-York on St. Patrick's Day
snippet: Speech in New-York on St. Patrick's Day
lead_paragraph: No "friendly" Celt can this year complain of the way in which St. Patrick and his memory green were treated by the heavens above or the earth and all that are in Gotham. A finer day than yesterday the happiest Irishman never desired, and what with the smiling sun, the favoring breeze, the popular cheer, and the universal good nature that prevailed, it was within the power of every Green-Erinite to celebrate St. Patrick's Day, not only "in the morning" but all through the day and night, and far into to-day.

abstract: Food Question, the, in the South
snippet: Food Question, the, in the South
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to resist the evidences we are now daily receiving of great destitution of food in the South. A report of the rebel Secretary of War, made a few weeks since, first brought to light the fact of a serious failure of the corn and wheat crops in the seceded States last year. The Commissary authorities at Richmond, right under the eye of the Confederate Government, lately seized a large quantity of flour at one of the City Mills. The flour was private property, manufactured for the use of families by a miller who had previously proposed to grind for the Government, but had been refused any share of its patronage. The seizure of this flour by Government officers created a stir in Richmond. It was a blow at private rights, and put every man's ability to subsist his own family at the mercy of the rebel Government. The owner of the mills at once reported his case to Gov. LETCHER, and invoked that official, who still claims to represent the proud and free Commonwealth of Old Virginia, to interpose in defence of the rights of her citizens. But Gov. LETCHER did not venture to do so. The doctrine of States' Rights has no more virtue or power in the South. It is a panoply that shields no longer. Gov. LETCHER contented himself with a spirited verbal protest (to the owner of the mills) against the injury he had suffered, and advised him to seek redress (by law, it is imagined,) against the individual officers who had despoiled him.
headline: {'main': 'The Food Question in the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Food Question in the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FIRES--EXPLOSION--A CHILD BURNED TO DEATH.--Last evening absent 6 o'clock, a fire broke out in a small frame shanty at the foot of Henry, street, South Brooklyn, occupied by Mrs. MARY MOORE, a poor woman, who makes her living by going out to do days' work.
lead_paragraph: FIRES -- EXPLOSION -- A CHILD BURNED TO DEATH. -- Last evening absent 6 o'clock, a fire broke out in a small frame shanty at the foot of Henry, street, South Brooklyn, occupied by Mrs. MARY MOORE, a poor woman, who makes her living by going out to do days' work. She left her home after dinner, leaving her daughter FANNY -- 5 years of age -- asleep, and had not returned when the fire was discovered. Before leaving, she had locked the doors. The flames soon enveloped the building, which was reduced to cinders. The little girl was burned to death. Her charred remains were discovered after the fire had been suppressed. His not known how the fire originated....About noon yesterday there was an alarm of fire in the Eighth Precinct, caused by an explosion in the house of Mr. PETER FLANNERY, situated in Twenty-first-street, near Third-avenue, Gowanus. It appears that FLANNERY had a can of wet powder, which he, injudiciously, placed by the side of a hot stove, to day. A neighbor, and his wife, and daughter three years of age, were in the room at the time. The fire communicating with the powder caused an explosion, the force of which blew out the front part of the house. The neighbor, named MCGUIRE, was considerably injured, and the little girl was so badly burned that her recovery is considered doubtful. Mr. FLANNERY and wife were but slightly injured. The house, which is a three-story frame, was very much shattered, and the firemen, in order to prevent further accident, pulled out the entire front and propped up the root so as to keep it from falling. The damage amounts to about $1,000....About 1 o'clock yesterday morning the iron foundry of Mr. MOORE, in Walton-street, near Flushing-avenue, was destroyed by fire. There was a large amount of prepared stock on hand, which, together with the machinery, was greatly damaged. The building is damaged to the extent of $2,800, and the loss on contents amounts to $5,000, mostly insured.... Two serious accidents occurred to firemen, in proceeding to some of the above fires. JAMES J. LAWRENCE, an exempt member of Hook and Ladder Company No. 2, was run over in Court-street last evening, and from all appearances, was dangerously jured. He was conveyed to the City Hospital. A member of Truck No. 1 was run over in Court-street, near Fourth-place, while running to the fire in Gowanus, and sustained a fracture of one leg. Both accidents were caused by racing on the railroad tracks.

abstract: The advance of the French
snippet: The advance of the French
lead_paragraph: Mexican advices to the 1st inst., via Havana--received at that place by the British mail packet Clyde, and published in our columns yesterday--report a positive advance movement of the French forces to the attack of Puebla. It is stated that the French army commenced its march on the 19th ult., and by the 25th, all the divisions, with Gens. FOREY, SALIGNY, ALMONTE, &c., were en route, and it was conjectured that the attack on Puebla would commence on the 1st inst.

abstract: Copperheads, The Place of, in History
snippet: Copperheads, The Place of, in History
lead_paragraph: It was well said by Mr. BRADY in his Brooklyn speech, that "the time will surely come when the men who oppose this war will be deemed more infamous than the Tories of the Revolution." If this fact were fitly realized, we doubt whether there are ten persons in this community who would quietly rest a day under the name of being, at this crisis, in favor of peace with the rebels. No member of society is so abandoned as to court infamy understandingly. When it comes to that, he is no longer a member of society -- he is simply an outcast.
headline: {'main': 'The Copperheads and Future History.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Copperheads and Future History.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: For the Union, Past and Present
snippet: For the Union, Past and Present
lead_paragraph: Twice since the war began has the public mind approached to perfect unanimity in its favor. The first time was immediately after the bombardment of Fort. Sumter by the rebels. The second is -- now. And if the unanimity at the present time is characterized by less of patriotic frenzy than possessed all hearts two years ago, it is not the less real, and is even more significant of triumph for the Union cause. Two years ago the millions of the North were moved by passion. A holy zeal for an insulted flag animated them, and they threw themselves forward upon a prepared and malignant foe with more ardor than discretion. Little account was made at the start of the possibility of repulse. Far too little care was observed in the preliminary organization and discipline of the ardent soldiers, who, in vaster numbers than the Government called for, went out under the flag of the Union. Never, since the days of Peter the Hermit, who aroused all Europe to a frenzied rush to Palestine, to rescue the Holy Sepulchre from Infidel sway, was such an outpouring of voluntary soldiers witnessed as that evoked by the rebel insults in Charleston harbor. But as the bones of the zealous but unprepared crusaders whitened the wayside of their toilsome and dangerous march, so did the graves of our enthusiastic volunteers mark their early invasions of the rebel States.
headline: {'main': 'War for the Union--Past and Present.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'War for the Union--Past and Present.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival at this port last evening of the steamship Champion, from Aspin wall on the 8th inst., we have late and important advices from Central America, and from the United States of Colombia. The last previous intelligence from the Isthmus brought us intelligence of the imminence of a collision between the troops of Guatemala, under President CARRERA, and those of Salvador,
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port last evening of the steamship Champion, from Aspin wall on the 8th inst., we have late and important advices from Central America, and from the United States of Colombia. The last previous intelligence from the Isthmus brought us intelligence of the imminence of a collision between the troops of Guatemala, under President CARRERA, and those of Salvador, under President BARRIOS. This collision took place on the 22d of February, at Coatefeque, about sixteen leagues from the City of San Salvador, and resulted, after two days' lighting, in the total defeat of the Guatemalan army, with the loss of four rifled guns, a considerable quantity of munitions, three hundred killed, and a large number wounded. It is believed, from present indications, that all five of the Central American States will become involved in this quarrel between Guatemala and Salvador. The news from Bogota, the capital of New-Granada, is to the effect that a National Convention of all the States of Colombia had met at Rio Negro, and that MOSQUERA had sent in his resignation of the office of Provisional President, accompanied by a history of his operations during the revolution. The Convention then appointed a Council of Five to carry on the Government, until a Federal Constitution could be made and promulgated. MOSQUERA was continued as Minister of War under the new arrangement. There is no news from the lower South American States by this arrival. The Champion brought only $249,514 in treasure.

abstract: -- Last year at this time the rebels held possession of the Mississippi River from near Cairo to its mouths -- a distance of over a thousand miles. Now they dispute with us only that part of it between Vicksburgh and Port Hudson -- some 200 miles. Columbus, their first great stronghold, twenty miles below Cairo, fell into our hands in March, last year. Vicksburgh, their last great stronghold, which is 600 miles below Cairo, will doubtless be ours in March of this year.

Having received a commission from Gov. MORGAN to raise a company for one of our State regiments, he recruited successfully for some time, but, being anxious to enter the ...
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER PATRIOT MERCHANT GONE. -- We rerecord to-day, the death of Lieut. SPICER J. RUDDEROW, who, like many of our New-York merchants, left his business to defend his country. Having received a commission from Gov. MORGAN to raise a company for one of our State regiments, he recruited successfully for some time, but, being anxious to enter the field, transferred his men, and attached himself to the Second Zouaves, and speedily following his arrival at New-Orleans, fell a victim to the climate of the Mississippi. Lieut. RUDDROW was formerly a member of the Seventh Regiment, National Guard. His career was brief, but his patriotism was of the highest order.

abstract: Election, The
snippet: Election, The
lead_paragraph: This election excites greater interest in view of the fact that it is the first one in a Free State in which the peace issue has been clearly put forth and accepted. In NewYork, and in every other Northern State, the Anti-Administration party made their fight on the ground that the Administration was mismanaging and unnecessarily protracting the war; that it had assumed undue powers in the matter of arrests; and that its Anti-Slavery measures were unwise and unwarrantable. But they made no demonstration against the war itself. They expressly declared themselves not only in favor of it, but for its more vigorous prosecution. The resolutions of the Anti-Administration Convention in this State, which nominated Gov. SEYMOUR, declared that "the present deplorable civil strife has been forced upon the country by the Disunionists of the Southern States now in arms against the constitutional Government;" and that "they will continue to render the Government their sincere and united support in the use of all legitimate means to suppress the rebellion. And Gov. SEYMOUR, in his speech in Brooklyn, during the canvass, said: "They (the rebels) have not contented themselves with the ballot, but have chosen the bayonet and the bullet to settle the question; then with the bayonet and the bullet we must meet them. The men of the South made the bayonet and the sword the arbiters of their doctrine, and, so far as the present is concerned, the sword must be the arbiter, and by it, with our strong arms, we will strike vigorous blows for the life of the Constitution and the flag." The resolutions of the Connecticut Convention, which nominated the other Gov. SEYMOUR, on the other hand, declared that "the time has now arrived when all true lovers of the Constitution are ready to abandon the monstrous fallacy that the Union can be restored by the armed hand," and that "the Democracy of Connecticut pledge themselves to unite in all honorable measures having in view the cessation of hostilities between the North and the South." And Mr. SEYMOUR, the selected candidate for Governor, in his speech at Hartford, during the canvass, said: "We have gone far enough in an unprofitable and cruel struggle. It is time to sheath the sword and spare mankind. It is not by force of arms that we are to have another Union, but by force of reason."

abstract: The Semi-Annual Reception of the Male and Female Departments of Grammar-School No. 10 took place at 1 o'clock yesterday. The space set apart for the accommodation of visitors was crowded to overflowing, and hundreds of persons were compelled to retire, unable to obtain admission. The order of exercises commenced with a "Christmas Carol," which was sung with fine effect by the pupils and teachers. The entertainment was then diversified with declamation, recitation, dialogues, etc., which were duly appreciated by those present Addresses were made by the school officers and others, and at intervals solos were sung with a piano accompaniment. The exercises closed with the solo and chorus, "God Protect Columbia," which was participated in by the entire school. The affair was highly successful and will be long remembered by those who were fortunate enough to be present.

abstract: Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD addressed the Board of Brokers in Beaver-street, yesterday afternoon, upon the subject of the Atlantic Telegraph--the present condition aad prospects of the enterprise. His remarks were substantially the same as those made the day before at the Produce Exchange. He spoke of the manifold advantages, political, social, and financial, that would result from the successful laying of a tele...
lead_paragraph: Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD addressed the Board of Brokers in Beaver-street, yesterday afternoon, upon the subject of the Atlantic Telegraph -- the present condition aad prospects of the enterprise. His remarks were substantially the same as those made the day before at the Produce Exchange. He spoke of the manifold advantages, political, social, and financial, that would result from the successful laying of a telegraphic cable between this country and England, and expressed the opinion that the enterprise was now certain to be carried out. He read a letter from ELLIOTT, GLASS & CO., the English cable manufacturers, in which they expressed the utmost confidence that a cable could be laid down between Ireland and Newfoundland, and as an evidence of the faith that is in them, offered to take $150,000 worth of the stock. With reference to the profitable nature of the investment -- supposing the cable to be laid -- nothing could be surer. The telegraph to San Francisco had returned to the stockholders the entire amount of their subscriptions in less than a year, and the demand for this line was not a tithe of that for a line across the Atlantic. Supposing twelve words per minute to be transmitted by the Atlantic telegraph during the twenty-four hours, the receipts would be (reckoning 62 cents per word) nearly $4,000,000 per annum, or over $1,000,000 more than the required estimate for laying down the cable. In answer to a question, Mr. FIELD said that subscriptions for the enterprise in England amounted, at the last advices, to 205,000; those of this counrty to 27,500, and the estimated cost of the work was 600,000, although it was doubtful if more than one-half of this sum would be required. Shares had been reduced to 5 each, one-fifth to be paid on subscription, and the remainder by installments, subject to the call of the Company.

abstract: -- Our neighbor, Mr. GREELEY, is entitled to commiseration. He is kept in a constant controversy by his particular friends, on points which, so far as we can see, have no immediate practical importance. He happened a few days since to drop the remark that if the Southern States would return to their allegiance, the President would be perfectly justifiable in withdrawing the Emancipation Proclamation for their benefit, and restoring to them the guarantees of Slavery contained in the Constitution. This has provoked a storm of remonstrances, protests, &c., &c., which impose upon Mr. GREELEY a very serious consumption of time and space in defending his position.

abstract: The telegraphic wire from Fortress Monroe sends over the country this morning a series of shocking magnetic shocks. There are but four brief and jerky paragraphs in the dispatch, yet each one of them thrills the nerves. A battle on the Blackwater in Virginia--an attack on Newbern, in North Carolina--a ...
lead_paragraph: The telegraphic wire from Fortress Monroe sends over the country this morning a series of shocking magnetic shocks. There are but four brief and jerky paragraphs in the dispatch, yet each one of them thrills the nerves. A battle on the Blackwater in Virginia -- an attack on Newbern, in North Carolina -- a naval fight at Port Hudson, in Mississippi -and the capture by the French of the capital of our neighboring republic of Mexico. It is a large and somewhat mixed dose, (to change the figure,) and we are not willing to take it all down -- even though it be but four gulps.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest at Beilevue Hospital, upon the body of HERMANN ZENNER, a native of Germany, aged 53 years, who died under circumstances of a very peculiar character. The testimony given upon the inquest all tends to show that a freight train on the New-York and ...
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest at Beilevue Hospital, upon the body of HERMANN ZENNER, a native of Germany, aged 53 years, who died under circumstances of a very peculiar character. The testimony given upon the inquest all tends to show that a freight train on the New-York and New Haven Railroad was running toward this City on Sunday morning last, and that when the train was between Melrose and Mott Haven, the engineer observed a man just ahead of the locomotive, in the act of rolling down an embankment toward the track. The engineer did all he could to stop the train, but the man was passed over before the cars became stationary. The engineer and other employes on the road were all under the impression that the victim had been struck by the locomotive; they, therefore, stopped the train and went back to gather up the remains. To their astonishment, they found the man in a sitting posture upon the track. When addressed by one of his countrymen, he stated that he had not been run over, but that he had been shot by the locomotive can, (meaning the engineer,) and no suggestions which were made could in any degree after his opinions in regard to his having been shot. He was found to be seriously injured, and was therefore conveyed to Bellevue Hospital, where he died on Tuesday night. Dr. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination of the body yesterday afternoon. No external injuries, except some slight abrasions on the nose and hands were to be found. The only theory that can be given as to his death is that the victim was walking beside the railroad track, when the train came along. He tried to climb up the embankment out of danger and in doing so fell backwards. The current of air created by the passing train gave him a shock from which he never recovered. This sudden shock doubtless gave him the idea that he had been shot by the engineer, which idea he entertained up to the time of his death.

abstract: This Commission, consisting of the Mayor and Comptroller, and five members of each Board of the Common Council, it will be recollected, met and organized on the 28th of last month.
lead_paragraph: This Commission, consisting of the Mayor and Comptroller, and five members of each Board of the Common Council, it will be recollected, met and organized on the 28th of last month. This and the ensuing meeting, which was held on the 4th instant, were public. At the third meeting, however, on the 9th instant, the doors were closed to the public, the Board having invited a number of distinguished gentlemen, of practical and scientific ability, to address them on the condition of the harbor defences, and the best means of improving them, and putting the City in a thoroughly defensible condition against the attack of an enemy. The information likely to be elicited, it was judged, it would not be proper to have go abroad. At this meeting Col. RICHARD DELAFIELD, of the United States Engineer Corps, who is in charge of the fortifications in the harbor, gave a detailed account of the existing condition of the harbor defences, suggested improvements upon them which he thought ought to be made, and urged the necessity of early action in this direction. Remarks were also made by WM.H. WEBB, Esq., the well-known ship-builder; Lieut J.V.D. REEVE, of the regular army; ALFRED W. CRAVEN, Esq., Chief Engineer of the Croton Aqueduct; WM. LAIMBEER, Esq., and THEODOSIUS F. SECOR, Esq., the well-known iron-founder. Communications were received from Admiral PAULDING, Commandant of the Navy-yard at Brooklyn, and Capt. ERICSSON, of "Monitor" celebrity. At this meeting the President (Mayor OPDYKE) announced the Standing Committees, as follows:

lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Notwithstanding the continued indisposition of Mme. MEDORI, and the change of opera rendered necessary in consequence thereof, the Academy of Music was completely filled last evening, when "Un Ballo is Maschera" was performed. This says much for the general strength of Mr. MARZTZEK'S company, and the attraction of Mme. GUERRADELLA'S name--for the lady sustained the role of Amelia, having obligingly consented, &c., &c. The performance throughout was an excellent one, differing from the first representation mainly in the superior merit of the baritone. Signor BELLINI is steadily winning his way with the public. The quantity and quality of his voice, combined with the spirit of his action, places him in the first rank of artists. As Reinhardt, he has an opportunity of showing all his best points. In the third act he was extremely powerful -- better than any of his predecessors; and in other and less exigent portions of the work he was all that could be desired.

abstract: A curious medley of news--or rather reports-- comes to us from Fortress Monroe. The first report is, that there was fighting on the Blackwater on Tuesday, of which no particulars are received. It is likely enough that another fight has occurred there. The rebels under PRYOR have been constantly threatening our position beyond Norfolk, and a collision has at any time been imminent.
lead_paragraph: A curious medley of news -- or rather reports -- comes to us from Fortress Monroe. The first report is, that there was fighting on the Blackwater on Tuesday, of which no particulars are received. It is likely enough that another fight has occurred there. The rebels under PRYOR have been constantly threatening our position beyond Norfolk, and a collision has at any time been imminent. No serious engagement, however, is likely to have occurred. The second report is, that the rebels attacked Newbern, N.C., last Friday, and were defeated. This is also likely. The rebels, supposing that the withdrawal of troops from Gen. FOSTER's Department had weakened his force at Newbern so as to increase their chance of recapturing the place, may have made the essay, with the result above stated. The third report -- and this comes from the Richmond papers of the 17th -- is that, on the 14th, Admiral FARRAGUT attacked Port Hudson, and was repulsed, with the loss of the steam-frigate Mississippi burnt and his flag-ship disabled. It is also stated that the land force did not join in the attack. This story, as told, is very unlikely, though it probably has some little foundation. Our latest advices direct from New-Orleans are to the 8th inst., at which time the movement against Port Hudson had not commenced, though it was expected soon The rebel report of the repulse of Admiral FARRAGUT undoubtedly grows out of a naval reconnoissance of the rebel position, preliminary to the grand combined attack by our land as well as naval forces. The fourth and last report -- and this also comes from the Richmond papers -- is that the City of Mexico has been captured by the French. As Gen. FOREY was not expected to commence his attack upon Puebla, which is about ninety miles from the City of Mexico, before the 1st inst., the improbability of this story will be at once recognized.

abstract: The gunboat expedition down the Yazoo River was said to have for its chief object the assailment of Haines' Bluff, immediately north of Vicksburgh. Such may have been its primary purpose, for all we know.
lead_paragraph: The gunboat expedition down the Yazoo River was said to have for its chief object the assailment of Haines' Bluff, immediately north of Vicksburgh. Such may have been its primary purpose, for all we know. But if it be correct, and there seems no doubt of it, that the expedition has got as far as Yazoo City, another admirable and pretty mode of flanking Vicksburgh, and hauling forth the rebels, nolens volens, from that stronghold, presents itself. The Yazoo River in our possession, we control that quarter of the State of Mississippi west of the Central Railroad, and extending from the northern line of the State to Vicksburgh. As our Vicksburgh correspondent points out, we can proceed up the Yallabusha River and cut the bridge of the railroad near Grenada; but, beside this, we can send a land force over the short distance from Yazoo to the Central Railroad, where we would only be a short distance from Jackson, and almost directly in the rear of Vicksburgh.

abstract: London Times Sees a Ray of Hope for This Country
snippet: London Times Sees a Ray of Hope for This Country
lead_paragraph: The London Times rejoices because, as it informs its readers, "at last there appears a ray of hope" from this country. Our readers are sufficiently well acquainted with the tendencies, the wishes and hopes of that paper, to feel at once that its joy must be of ill omen for us, its "ray of hope" only the gathering of thicker darkness over our sky. The Times has hope because, in the proceedings of the Copperheads at the North, it finds indications that "that which careful observers have so long foreseen is at last coming to pass." "The Federal Government is utterly discredited" -- "the Union is resolving itself into the elements out of which it was originally constructed" -- "the States desire peace, and finding the Federal Government unwilling to give effect to their desire, have superseded its action," and "the great fabric, which existed two years ago, exists no longer, even in name."

abstract: Bequest to the Dudley Observatory
snippet: Bequest to the Dudley Observatory
lead_paragraph: The late Mrs. BLANDINA DUDLEY, of Albany, has exhibited in her last will and testament the same noble munificence to science which she illustrated during her lifetime. In addition to her former gifts, she bequeathed the sum of $80,000 for the maintenance in the Dudley Observatory, which she established, of a scientific chair to be known as the "Blandina Professorship." This puts the institution in an excellent position, monetarily considered, giving it a permanent endowment of $80,000, which is safely invested, and yields an annual income of $5,600. The Observatory is now well supplied with astronomical instruments of unsurpassed excellence, some of which our Albany correspondent describes this morning. In short, the buildings, grounds and instruments, the management, the professors' chairs and the endowment, are all now highly honorable to America, to science, and to the noble, lady whose munificence founded the institution, which, we trust, will be sustained for ages. Mrs. DUDLEY gives expression in her testament to the belief that the Observatory "is destined yet to realize the hopes of its early friends and founders in the sure but modest elevation of American science;" and every one who appreciates the worth of science, and the incalculable value of such institutions as this in advancing it, will join in the hope that her faith and charity may, in time, find their full fruition.

abstract: ALLEGED MURDER.--On Sunday last an Irishman, named JAMES KELLET, was found lying on the Hunterfly Road, beyond the city line, suffering from injuries sustained, as then supposed, by falling with his head upon some sharp stones, while in a state of intoxication.
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED MURDER. -- On Sunday last an Irishman, named JAMES KELLET, was found lying on the Hunterfly Road, beyond the city line, suffering from injuries sustained, as then supposed, by falling with his head upon some sharp stones, while in a state of intoxication. Mr. GARRETT STOOTHOFF, who discovered him, put him on his wagon, with the aid of a lady and gentleman passing at the time, and conveyed him to the farm-yard of Mr. VANDERBERG, where he left him. The face of the injured man was bleeding badly, and there was blood on and about the stones. Mr. STOOTHOFF asked him where he lived, and he answered that he did not know. He did not complain of any person striking him. Just before Mr. STOOTHOFF arrived at the spot where KELLET was lying, he met four colored men, named JOHN JACKSON, HENRY JACKSON, SAMUEL JACKSON and FREDERICK JOHNSON. The first-named had a pair of skates. They were laughing, and seemed very merry. KELLET died of his injuries during the night, and an inquest was held on Monday, resulting in a verdict that deceased died of injuries sustained by a fall while in a state of intoxication. Some circumstances having come to light showing that the man, so far from falling and injuring himself, had been knocked down and beaten, the body was sent to the County Hospital for further investigation. The inquest was renewed and the evidence elicited was to the effect that KELLET came to the store of JOHN F. KOCH, on the Hunterfly road, town of New-Lotts, on Sunday morning. The three JACKSONS and JOHNSON, with some white men, were present. Mr. KOCH exhibited a pair of skates for sale, and soon after a conversation took place about gloves. The deceased, after purchasing a paper of tobacco, left. A pair of gloves belonging to JOHN JACKSON, and the skates were missing, and KELLET was at once suspected of having taken them. The negroes pursued him, and JOHN JACKSON, over-taking him, struck him two or three times, knocking him down, and kicked him while down. The skates and gloves were recovered, and the negroes returned to the store where they related their exploits, and JACKSON, who is a powerful fellow, threatened to whip any man who told of the transaction. He was not aware however, at the time that he had injured KELLET so severely that his life was in danger. When he ascertained that KELLET was dead he and his companions left the neighborhood, but were subsequently arrested by the Forty-ninth Precinct Police, and committed to await the result of the second inquest. The post-mortem examination of the body proved that there was a lacerated wound on the left eye of deceased, extending deeply in, with a fracture of the lower border of the maxillary bone; a vertical cut in the upper lip, three-fourths of an inch in length; a punctured wound in the right lower jaw, extending over an inch, and several abrasions on the left side of the face. There was effusion of blood upon the brain, and the fracture of the maxillary bone extended down through the bone of the face to the antram. All the other organs were in good health. The cause of death was compression of the brain, which might have been produced by kicks and blows. Two men, named KOCH and HARTMAN, who served upon the first jury, gave as the reason for not stating the facts as they knew them, that they were afraid of the negroes. The Coroner's jury brought in the following verdict : "That the said JAMES KELLET came to his death by compression of the brain, superinduced by injuries inflicted by JOHN JACKSON, on the morning of the 15th of March, 1863, and that HENRY JACKSON and SAMUEL JACKSON aided and abetted in the attack. We also find that JOHN F. KOCH and WM. HARTMAN knew all the circumstances of and concealed the cause of death of said JAMES KELLET, and placed themselves on the jury, thereby assisting in covering up the facts connected with said KELLET's death." The parties implicated were committed to answer. The two jurymen were released on ball.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a majority report was made in favor of holding the New-York Charter Election at the same time as the General Election. lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a majority report was made in favor of holding the New-York Charter Election at the same time as the General Election. The bill incorporating the Medical College for women was ordered to a third reading. A bill to provide arms and equipment for the State Militia was introduced. The bills relative to the fees of Supervisors, and prohibition Supervisors from holding other County offices, reported favorably. A number of bills were passed, but none of them of importance.

abstract: Spring Fashions--Opening Day
snippet: Spring Fashions--Opening Day
lead_paragraph: St. Patrick's Day was mild and lovely, contrary to expectation -- contrary to custom. "Opening Day" was the same. No one day in the whole year's round is of such interest to ladies of fashion, unless it be NewYear's Day, as the l9th day of March, the Milliners' "Opening Day" in the City of New-York. Bonnets and dresses, flowers and furbalows, are necessary to the existence of Gothamic ladies. To wear a hat during two consecutive seasons would be so great a trial to any one of them, that we feel it our bounded duty to chronicle the fact that all the milliners of the City are bountifully supplied with any quantity of new bonnets of new styles -- if anything, a touch and a half beyond that which has reigned supreme in ugliness during the Winter. Whether it will be a possibility for gentlemen at church or opera to see anything that may be in pulpit or on stage, we regard as entirely a matter of doubt; in fact, so high have the fronts gone up, that, with the exception of some of the fancy stocks on Wall-street, we know of no parallel in altitude.

abstract: We have dispatches from Memphis to the 18th inst., embodying intelligence from the Yazoo Pass Expedition to Saturday morning last, which does not corroborate, in all respects, the reports which have previously reached us.
lead_paragraph: We have dispatches from Memphis to the 18th inst., embodying intelligence from the Yazoo Pass Expedition to Saturday morning last, which does not corroborate, in all respects, the reports which have previously reached us. Our fleet, consisting of the Chillicothe, De Kalb, five small gunboats and eighteen transports, had then only reached Greenwood, three miles above the junction of the Tallahatchie and Yallabusha Rivers. There, on Friday, the Chillicothe, which was in the advance, was fired upon by a rebel battery mounting five guns, and an engagement ensued, lasting till dark, in which only the Chillicothe appears to have been engaged, and which was without decisive results. She received sixty-four shots, one of which entered a port-hole, killing three and wounding fourteen persons. A few shots only were fired on Saturday morning, the Chillicothe being short of ammunition. The Richmond papers of the 16th, in noticing the affair, acknowledge the loss of "some valuable gunners and a few others." In addition to the Greenwood battery, the rebels are said to have strong fortifications at Yazoo City and at Manchester. Greenwood is one hundred and fifty miles from Yazoo City, and of course the report of the capture of that place, with twenty-six steamers, was at least premature.

abstract: -- Considerable excitement was created in Wall-street, yesterday afternoon, by the appearance of a well-executed counterfeit $500 bill, purporting to have been issued by the Central Bank of Worcester, Mass. It was so well done, and so nearly did it resemble the genuine, that Messrs. GWYNNE & DAY, money brokers, of No. 21 Wall-street, received it as genuine. The paper, engraving, and in fact everything about it, is so much an imitation, that good judges pronounce the spurious note to be a photograph. No arrests had been made up to a late hour last night. The police telegraph was immediately put into operation, however, for the purpose of warning the public against the new and dangerous counterfeit.
lead_paragraph: -- Considerable excitement was created in Wall-street, yesterday afternoon, by the appearance of a well-executed counterfeit $500 bill, purporting to have been issued by the Central Bank of Worcester, Mass. abstract: Franklin, Major-Gen., and the Battle of Fredericksburgh
snippet: Franklin, Major-Gen., and the Battle of Fredericksburgh
lead_paragraph: -- We publish in another column a statement of the conduct of Gen. FRANKLIN at the battle of Fredericksburgh, in reply to an impeachment of it contained in a letter from the Editor of the TIMES, written at Washington on the 24th of January. In that letter the impression was given, as our correspondent states, that Gen. BURNSIDE intended his main attack to be made by our left wing, under Gen. FRANKLIN, and that the battle was lost by Gen. FRANKLIN's failure to make that attack, with the force and vigor contemplated by his orders, and which were essential to success.

abstract: the Doctrine of
snippet: the Doctrine of
lead_paragraph: As our readers are already aware, the "diffusers of political information," who set about evangelizing the heathen of New-Hampshire and Connecticut some weeks ago, discovered a grand remedy for all the evils of our political condition, which they produced with becoming solemnity. There was a simplicity and originality and fresh flavor of the groves about it, which led us to imagine that it was one of those droppings of wisdom which Mr. BROOKS heard when sitting round the stumps of the South, in one of those delightful communities, where the workings of the human mind are not trammeled by the arts of reading and writing. But whatever its origin, we all received it with the deference and humility which Northern barbarians like ourselves owe to the academicians of North Carolina and Mississippi. The great cure for our miserable condition, the bottle that was to purge the North of all its peccant humors, and make it fit company for our clear-skinned healthy "brethren of the South," was "self-restraint." We were deliberately and carefully to avoid touching either in the pulpit or on the platform, or in the Press, upon the subject of Slavery; we were, as Mr. SAMUEL J. TILDEN warned us, to treat and consider Slavery in the Southern States absolutely as if it were Slavery in Brazil or Cuba, and preserve a profound silence about it in all its bearings. The South, however, was not, under this arrangement, to act toward us as if it were Brazil or Cuba. It was still to be at liberty to bring bills about Slavery into our Congress, to make speeches in its glorification, to seize slaves in our streets, and employ our soldiers in protecting slave property in our Territories, and our Ambassadors in preaching the Slavery gospel in foreign parts.

abstract: -- The rebels seem disposed to fight nearly all their battles twice over. We have had innumerable instances of this in the war -- both in the West and in the East -- the two battles of Springfield, the two near Pea Ridge, the two of Fort Donelson, the two at Manassas, the two at Winchester, and, indeed, there are many more instances than we now recall. In most cases they have been drubbed even more terribly in the second battle than in the first, and in no instance have they come or stood for a third effort at one place, except, perhaps, in the defence of Vicksburgh. It is true it has been reported for some days that they were advancing for a third time to battle at Fort Donelson -- as if the fearful defeat they met there in February of last year, and the smaller though equally effective defeat they got in February of this year, did not satisfy them. But the latest news would seem to indicate that they had given the subject a second thought, and determined not to risk a third Donelson defeat.

abstract: Importance of his Office; Col. Fry's Appointment
snippet: Importance of his Office; Col. Fry's Appointment
lead_paragraph: One of the most important military offices in the country is that of Provost-Marshal-General, created by the recent act of Congress for enrolling and calling out the militia of the United States. The duty devolves upon the Provost-Marshal-General to put this act in operation and see to its proper enforcement in all the States and Territories. He must devise rules for the conscription, communicate orders, receive reports of men drafted, furnish lists of all deserters from our armies, who are to be arrested by his subordinates, and in all other respects take care that soldiers are provided for the public defence, and that those who are called out are kept in the service. His office is made a Bureau of the War Department, and it is apparent that among the most perplexing and important executive duties pertaining to that department will be thrown into the hands of the Provost-Marshal-General. The Conscription act makes it the duty of subordinate or District Provost-Marshals "to inquire into and report to the Provost-Marshal-General all treasonable practices." Upon the report of the Provost-Marshal-General to his superiors, the question of arrest in such cases will turn, so that the entire class of acts which have hitherto excited so much feeling -- arbitrary arrests for alleged disloyal practices -- will stand hereafter upon the supposed responsibility of the Provost-Marshal-General.

abstract: The Improved Efficiency of Our
snippet: The Improved Efficiency of Our
lead_paragraph: -- The improved efficiency and spirit of our cavalry was admirably illustrated by the gallant fight they made on Monday on the Rappahannock. From the descriptions given by our correspondents yesterday and today; it would appear that the affair was one of the most daring, dashing and successful we have had in the war. As in the case of the cavalry fight reported by ROSECRANS in his army the other day, AVERILL's men used their sabres freely upon the rebels, and taught them a lesson which they have long needed. They have always vaunted of the prowess of their horsemen; and their various successful raids during the war have given them at least a show of ground on which to base their claims. We think, however, that such exploits as those of ZAGONYI, CARTER, PLEASANTON, MINTY and AVERILL quite equal, and some of them far surpass anything that the rebels have ever done. We are glad to see such dashes as these. They hold the enemy in check and keep him on the defensive, beside their effect in inspiriting our own army. Our cavalry will continue to be of more and more use as the main armies of the rebels are beaten and driven back, and it should be kept in the highest state of efficiency by continual work.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a unanimous report  was made by the Railroad Committee in favor of a State interest in the Broadway Railroad bill. A unanimous report was made from the same Committee in favor of the Crosstown Railroad, striking out the streets in which stage lines exist.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a unanimous report was made by the Railroad Committee in favor of a State interest in the Broadway Railroad bill. A unanimous report was made from the same Committee in favor of the Crosstown Railroad, striking out the streets in which stage lines exist. A report was also made in favor of Mr. CONNOLLY's Gold resolutions, with some amendment. The bill amending the Charter of Brooklyn was passed; also the bill incorporating the Medical College for Women.

abstract: Every few days now, we have a grand popular demonstration in behalf of the Union and the prosecution of the war, beside innumerable minor but not less valuable meetings held nightly in the various Wards of the City. The new vitality, the rising spirit, the hopeful unity, the growing determination of the people, is shown in nothing more strikingly than in this. The people never tire of them, but every meeting seems better and stronger than the one which went before.

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA IN BROOKLYN. -- Managerial impositions are normal customs to the City of Brooklyn, and placid submission to them is a first-class specification in the creed of every devout opera-goer of that delightful city, who is glad if anything which approximates even the more elevated Gothamic luck. Never until last night have the habitues of the Brooklyn Academy witnessed the thorough rendition of an opera in that most charming theatre, and a sensation was experienced accordingly which will put ducats in MARETZEK's wallet, and good music in the ears of the Brooklyn audience, than which no audience in America is so thoroughly well-informed as to what is good and what is relatively bad. The opera given is a favorite one in the City of Churches, and, from the opposition which was given its earlier representations, has become the standard opening-work of every troupe that goes there. The house brilliantly filled, the new style of bonnet, which eclipses in altitude everything this side of Trinity Church spire, was observable in every box and in every circle; young men and maidens -- in fact, "every one who is any one" was there. The cast was the same as was given at our Academy, and we need not reiterate the statment that it is most admirable. Mlle. BRIGNOLI did exceedingly well, but MAZZOLINI and BELLINI shared the honors with her, receiving the orthodox encores and ovationary tributes at the end of each act. We congratulate Brooklyn on the sensation, and Mr. MARETZEK on the continuation of a monied flow.

abstract: Pursuant to a call inviting the citizens of the Twelfth Ward to meet in masse to lend their counsel and influence to the movement which is now being made to compel the Eighth-avenue Railroad Company to extend their line to that portion of the City, ...
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to a call inviting the citizens of the Twelfth Ward to meet in masse to lend their counsel and influence to the movement which is now being made to compel the Eighth-avenue Railroad Company to extend their line to that portion of the City, as originally specified in the charter, a large number of interested persons assembled, on Tuesday evening, at the hotel corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street and Eighth-avenue. The meeting was held under the auspices of the "Twelfth Ward West End Improvement Association," and was presided over by Mr. THOMAS MANSON, President of that body. Mr. A.M. LEWIS is one of the regularly appointed Secretaries, and officiated on this occasion.

abstract: 1. Be it resolved by the Senate and General Assembly of the State of New-Jersey, That this State, in promptly answering the calls made by the President of the United States, at and since the inauguration of the war, for troops and means to assist in maintaining the power and dignity of the Federal Government, believed ...
lead_paragraph: 1. Be it resolved by the Senate and General Assembly of the State of New-Jersey, That this State, in promptly answering the calls made by the President of the United States, at and since the inauguration of the war, for troops and means to assist in maintaining the power and dignity of the Federal Government, believed and confided in the professions and declarations of the President of the United States, in his inaugural Address, and in the resolutions passed by Congress on the 25th day of July, 1861, in which, among other things, it was declared "that the war is not waged for conquest or subjugation, or interfering with the rights or established institutions of the States, but to maintain and defend the supremacy of the Constitution, with the rights and equality under it unimpaired, and that as soon as these objects shall be accomplished the war ought to cease;" and that, relying upon these assurances; given under the sanctity of official oaths, this State freely, fully and without delay or conditions, contributed to the assistance of the Federal Government her sons and her means.

abstract: A brief notice is due of HENRY N. FISHER, M. D., a Surgeon in the army, who died on Thursday last, March 12, aged 29. After the disasters in the Peninsular campaign, in Christian zeal and love he promptly volunteered as physician and surgeon, to minister to the necessities of our wounded soldiers, and made several trips between Harrison's Landing and New-York, on one of the transports which brought away our suffering defenders. His faithfulness and efficiency commending him to those in authority, he received an appointment as Surgeon in the army; and since September last, he, with others, has been in charge of Eckington Hospital, in the suburbs of Washington. Here his devotion to the duties of his large care, when some days eighty and a hundred wounded at a time would come, finally wore upon him, and he was attacked by the fatal fever which has laid him in the tomb in the dawn of his manhood, and in the opening prospect of high honor and usefulness in his profession. He is but another among the thousands who have yielded themselves as noble sacrifices on the altar of their country's necessities. Though not fallen in the "battle that is with confused noise and garments rolled in blood," yet he fell at the post of noblest duty, in tenderly ministering to the wounded and dying among our brave defenders. Let his name be inscribed with honor upon the roll of our patriot dead. G.L.P.
lead_paragraph: A brief notice is due of HENRY N. FISHER, M. D., a Surgeon in the army, who died on Thursday last, March 12, aged 29. abstract: Desperate Rebel Attack on Fort Anderson Repulsed
snippet: Desperate Rebel Attack on Fort Anderson Repulsed
lead_paragraph: On the 6th inst. Gen. HENRY PRINCE, with his Division, BELGER'S and RIGGS' Battery, and a portion of the Third New-York Cavalry, started on a reconnoisance to the south of Newbern. It was most successful in its results. The rebel cavalry force in Onslow County was completely broken up. Lieut. WILLIAMS, of the Sixty-third North Carolina Cavalry, and about a dozen prisoners, were captured, and the balance were dispersed, taking to the swamps to avoid being taken.

abstract: FIRE ON BOARD A SCHOONER. -- Yesterday forenoon, about 11 o'clock, a fire occurred on board the schooner Bulrush, of Newport, loaded with hay, and lying at anchor in the basin above the Erie Railway depot. The police boat, together with some tugs, went alongside, and got streams upon the fire, which at that time enveloped the entire vessel. The schooner got loose from her anchorage, and was carried down stream by the tide, opposite the Cunard dock, where she came in contact with some portion of the schooner burned and sunk there some weeks since, and heeled over. The amount of damage could not be ascertained.
lead_paragraph: FIRE ON BOARD A SCHOONER. -- Yesterday forenoon, about 11 o'clock, a fire occurred on board the schooner Bulrush, of Newport, loaded with hay, and lying at anchor in the basin above the Erie Railway depot. The amount of damage could not be ascertained.

abstract: FATAL STABBING AFFRAY IN A GROGGERY-- ARREST OF THE PERPETRATOR.--Thursday night about 10 o'clock, a disturbance occurred in the liquor-shop of GARRETT LAUNDRESS, No.25 Washington-street, between the keeper of the place and John KANE, a seaman, during which LAUNDRESS, as is charged, drew a sharp-pointed sheatn-knife and stabbed KANE in the abdomen, inflicting a mortal wound. Dr. CHRISTO
lead_paragraph: FATAL STABBING AFFRAY IN A GROGGERY -- ARREST OF THE PERPETRATOR. -- Thursday night about 10 o'clock, a disturbance occurred in the liquor-shop of GARRETT LAUNDRESS, No.25 Washington-street, between the keeper of the place and John KANE, a seaman, during which LAUNDRESS, as is charged, drew a sharp-pointed sheatn-knife and stabbed KANE in the abdomen, inflicting a mortal wound. Dr. CHRISTOPHER WELTJE was immediately called to attend the injured man, but medical aid was of no avail, as death ensued soon afterward. LAUNDRESS was promptly arrested by Officer COYLE, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, and locked up to await the result of the Coroner's inquisition. The knife with which the fatal wound was inflicted, was subsequently found in the rear yard of prisoner's premises, and identified as belonging to LAUNDRESS. Coroner WILDEY was notified, and will hold an inquest upon the body at 10 o'clock this morning, at the Twenty-seventh Precinct Station-house in Cedar-street. Dis. BOUTON and WELTJE made a post-mortem examination yesterday afternoon. They found one stab of a serious nature in the left arm, and another in the right side. This is the one which, doubtless, produced his death. The knife had entered between the eighth and ninth ribs, and then passed through into the right lobe of the liver, causing a frightful wound. It has been ascertained that the deceased had been in this country but a short time, he having arrived a few weeks ago from Ireland. He immediately put up at the boarding-house kept by LAUNDRESS. A few days ago the latter turned him away from his premises, on account of some quarrel between them. On Thursday evening deceased returned, and LAUNDRESS was obliged to call in a policeman to eject him from the house. Later in the evening he again returned when the quarrel ensued which resulted in KANE's death.

abstract: United States vs. Reindeer; Price Decision
snippet: United States vs. Reindeer; Price Decision
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Reindeer and her Cargo -- This vessel was captured in the Gulf of Mexico on Sept. 17, 1862, by the bark William G. Anderson. On her passage to this port in charge of a prize crew, she put into Key West, where she was pronounced unseaworthy, and appropriated to the use of the United States. Her cargo was sent here by another vessel. Process of attachment in this suit was returned duly served, and no one appeared to contest the case. By consent of the libelants, a part of the cargo, 73,533 pounds of cotton, was, by decree of Feb. 27, 1863, remitted to James Millinger, or his agent or attorneys.

abstract: -- We are glad to learn that this excellent gentleman and officer has been restored to his command, and has again taken the field. The order dismissing him, which was published a short time since, was made under an entire misapprehension of facts, as all who knew Col. CESNOLA were certain it must have been. He was formerly an officer in the Sardinian army, is a high-toned gentleman, a thoroughly educated soldier, and, we are assured, one of the most capable and efficient officers in the service.

abstract: We have advices from Port Royal to the 16th inst., by an arrival at this port. Intelligence had been received from the Black Brigade, marching into Florida; that they had captured several important points on the way, prisoners, and large quantities of munitions and supplies, and that they were still driving the enemy before them. There is nothing new regarding the movement of Gen. HUNTER's forces. The soldiers were holding indignation meetings to denounce the Copperheads in the North.

abstract: Untimely Discussion; the Seward Dispatches
snippet: Untimely Discussion; the Seward Dispatches
lead_paragraph: Our neighbor of the Tribune unreasonable. He calls on us, in rather a querulous tone, to "state just how much space he has consumed " in discussing the question whether the President could, or could not, withdraw his Emancipation Proclamation in case the rebel States should return to their allegiance. Our impression is, that five or six columns have been "consumed" in that way; but we regard the whole of it, be the same more or less, as having been worse than wasted. The question has not the slightest practical importance at present, and its discussion only tends to divert the public mind from what is important, viz.: The necessity of crushing the rebellion by force of arms.

abstract: The Times (city article) says, the proposal of the Washington Government, for issuing letters of marque, with other indication, have revived the impression that a certain portion of the Washington Cabinet was endeavoring to obtain a solution of the existing difficulty by forcing on a foreign war, so as to enable the breaking up of the Union to be attributed to the overwhelming power of the jealous European aristocracy.
lead_paragraph: The Times (city article) says, the proposal of the Washington Government, for issuing letters of marque, with other indication, have revived the impression that a certain portion of the Washington Cabinet was endeavoring to obtain a solution of the existing difficulty by forcing on a foreign war, so as to enable the breaking up of the Union to be attributed to the overwhelming power of the jealous European aristocracy. This theory alone explains SEWARD's determination to insist that the Federal power has met with nothing but success; and that there is no Southern insurrection.

lead_paragraph: A meeting of loyal citizens, inferior in numbers only to the vast gathering which occupied the building a week ago, was held last night at Cooper Institute. As usual, the speaker's desk and the rear of the platform were draped in the American flag, aside from which there were no decorations whatever. Upon the platform were a few well-known citizens -- John Jay, O. Johnson, B.F. Mudgett, Deputy Collector; Chas. A. Briggs, State Agent of Ohio under the administration of Gov. Chase; D.D. Field, and Col. Wm. S. Bliss.

abstract: The steamship Norwegian arrived at Portland yesterday, bringing advices from Europe five  days later, including a summary of news brought from Liverpool by the Edinburgh, now due at this port. The Norwegian left Liverpool on the 5th, and Londonderry on the 6th inst. The political news by this arrival is comparatively unimportant. There were no new developments re
lead_paragraph: The steamship Norwegian arrived at Portland yesterday, bringing advices from Europe five days later, including a summary of news brought from Liverpool by the Edinburgh, now due at this port. The Norwegian left Liverpool on the 5th, and Londonderry on the 6th inst. The political news by this arrival is comparatively unimportant. There were no new developments regarding the American question. It was reported in Paris that Gen. FOREY, commanding the French expedition in Mexico, had sent urgent demands to his Government for more reinforcements, which could not be sent to him. The Polish question appears to be unchanged. The action of the Governments had not been fully determined, though it was rumored that the French Cabinet had taken action in favor of the Poles. The Liverpool Cotton market was dull, and prices were nominal. Breadstuffs were generally steady, and Provisions quiet. Consols were quoted at 92 3/8 for money.

abstract: Copperheads and the Border States
snippet: Copperheads and the Border States
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that VALLANDIGHAM, recently advertised to deliver an address in Baltimore, received a notification that it could not safely be done, and thereupon, like a prudent man, reserved his sedition for NewYork. He thereby escaped rough handling. An Indiana Copperhead -- CRAVENS, Congressman elect -- has not been so fortunate. It seems that under the wing of "an old man of Kentucky named WICKLIFFE," he ventured into the State Convention at Louisville, took the floor, and commenced vehement abuse of the Administration, with praise of the peace movements. The drift of his discourse was no sooner discovered, than indignant cries arose from all parts of the hall -- as "Put him out!" "Down with the traitor!" "Shame on the Copperheads!" and amid groans and jeers, he was incontinently tumbled out of doors. In the course of a week or two Mr. CRAVENS, imitating VALLANDIGHAM, will probably appear at the Copperhead headquarters in this City, and be received with clappings of hands and shouts of applause.
