abstract: In the TIMES, of yesterday, we published the fact that counterfeit $500 bills were in circulation, and that some of them had been passed sucecsfully upon the brokers in Wall-street. Yesterday morning it became evident that the fraud had been practiced to a greater extent than was at first supposed. Five persons--the most of them Wall-street brokers or their clerks--
lead_paragraph: In the TIMES, of yesterday, we published the fact that counterfeit $500 bills were in circulation, and that some of them had been passed sucecsfully upon the brokers in Wall-street. Yesterday morning it became evident that the fraud had been practiced to a greater extent than was at first supposed. Five persons -- the most of them Wall-street brokers or their clerks -- appeared before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs, and made oath that a man named GEORGE PARK had been guilty of passing upon each of them one of the spurious notes. One of them was passed upon the firm of WHITE. MORRISON & Co., No. 29 Wall-street; one upon GWYNNE & DAY, No. 21 Wall-street, and one upon EDWARD LIVERMORE, No. 40 Wall-street. PARK attempted to pass one at No. 33 Wall, and also one at the banking office of ISHI CRAVEN, NO. 17 Wall-street. At the latter place it appears that the note was suspected, and the broker in charge of the office sent it out for examination. It was soon returned with the information that it was a counterfeit. PARK was therefore detained a few minutes until an officer came and took him into custody. Upon his preliminary examination yesterday afternoon. PARK stated that he had received these bills in the ordinary course of business, and had no idea that they were bad; he further stated that he was a merchant of 20 years' standing, and would not for any amount of money, knowingly, endanger his reputation. He was then committed for a further examination. The Police authorities have in the meantime received dispatches from Boston, Philadelphia, Washington and other places, to the effect that bold attempts have just been made to put into circulation these $500 counterfeit notes. They are so well executed that no person, unless an adept in the business, can distinguish them from the genuine notes of the Bank.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a majority report was made from the Finance Committee in favor of settling the claim of the State against Richmond County for Quarantine damages, for $47,000 instead of $107,000. A majority report was also made from the Committee on the Salt question, against increasing the duty. A minority report was made in favor of increasing the duty to two cents per bushel. A motion to instruct the Committee to report a bill on the basis of the minority report was lost by a tie vote. A motion to have a Grinding Committee was adopted. The bill for the enforcement of water rent liens in Brooklyn was passed.

abstract: Alfred Flock vs. De Forest Manice.--The plaintiff demands that he was the tenant of the defendant at No.599 Sixth-avenue, (running through to Broadway,) occupying and using such premises as a butcher
lead_paragraph: Alfred Flock vs. De Forest Manice. -- The plaintiff demands that he was the tenant of the defendant at No.599 Sixth-avenue, (running through to Broadway,) occupying and using such premises as a butcher that while he so occupied, the defendant commenced blasting rocks on the adjoining premises, and in such a manner as to endanger, as alleged, the occupants of the premises No. 599, and rendered the store unsafe for even consumers to visit. In this way the plaintiff claimed that he had been much injured in his business, and for which he demanded $2,500 damages.

abstract: FIRE. -- About 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the upper part of a three-story brick house, No. 27 Myrtle-avenue, which was occupied as a store, and by two families. The flames spread so rapidly that the occupants had barely time to escape. Very little of the furniture was saved. The first floor was occupied as a bookstore by Mr. G.R. GILLESPIE, the second floor by Mr. JOHNSON, and the third, by Mr. L.W. BLISS. Combined loss, about $1,000 -- partially insured. The premises are owned by Rev. E.M. JOHNSON. Loss about $1,000.

abstract: Howell Vs. Knickerbocker Life Insurance Co.; Payment of Premium
snippet: Howell Vs. Knickerbocker Life Insurance Co.; Payment of Premium
lead_paragraph: Sally Ann Howell vs. The Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company. -- In the year 1853, as appeared in this case, George A. Howell, of this City, as agent for his wife, insured his life for her benefit and the benefit of his children, in the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company, of this City, in the sum of $5.000. The premiums were paid regularly and punctually, as claimed, from that time until 1861. On the morning of the 15th of July, 1862 -- that being the day upon which the premium became payable -- Howell left his residence in perfect health, and proceeded to his place of business, where he made memoranda of several things to be done on that day, and among them was the payment of the premium on this policy of insurance. But before noon of that day he was suddenly struck with paralysis, and lingered in a state of stupor, incapable of speech or action, until the next day, when he died.

abstract: We have intelligence, by the arrival of the brig Emily Fisher at this port, that the rebel privateer Retribution, which captured the Fisher off Castle Island, was not seaworthy, and that her commander, who calls himself Captain PARKER, would no longer trust himself and crew in her far away from land. The privateer has rotten, or partially rotten timbers, and the crew of the Fisher learned that the rebel vessel could at that time scarcely withstand the recoil of the rifled gun which she carried, and that, though she had on board four other guns, it was not deemed safe to mount them. The Captain of the privateer admitted to Captain STAPLES, of the Fisher, that he would condemn the vessel, or have her condemned, when he should get her into some seaport; but he added that the Confederate service would not be the loser by that circumstance, as he should undertake to get a steamer, which he had long desired to do.

abstract: ARREST OF A NOTED BURGLAR. -- JOSEPH MARSHALL was yesterday brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH upon the charge of having committed a burglary at the clothing store of THOMAS F. MOORE, No. 128 Spring-street. The testimony given during his examination, disclosed the fact that on the night of the 16th inst., MARSHALL, entered the store by means of a "jimmy," and stole therefrom sixteen pairs of pants, valued at $50; fourteen coats, worth $75, and three silver watches, of the value of $10. Officer HALSTEAD, of the Eighth Precinct, soon afterward took MARSHALL into custody, but nothing was found upon his person, except two pawn tickets, which showed that two of the watches stolen from Mr. MOORE had been pledged at No. 192 Eighth-avenue. These articles were subsequently identified by MOORE as his property. MARSHALL is a well-known burglar. A few days ago the police arrested him for breaking into the dwelling of ALBERT SCHIENBECK, No. 80 West Houston-street, and stealing therefrom about $50 worth of property. The Justice committed him for trial.

abstract: The British Queen, which arrived at this port yesterday from Havana, touched at Nassau, N.P., and brings our correspondence from that place to the 15th inst. The contraband trade between Nassau and the rebel ports -- principally Charleston -- appears to be rapidly increasing. Our correspondent gives us a list of eighteen steamers, which, are only a part of those engaged in this traffic. One of them is commanded by a Capt. CARLIN, recently released from Fort Lafayette. The privateer Retribution arrived at Nassau about the 1st of March, and after lying in the harbor about a week was condemned by a Board of Survey as unseaworthy, and sold at public auction by N. ADDERLEY & Co., who do all the dirty work of the rebels at that port. She was purchased by ADDERLEY's brother-in-law, and our correspondent believes it to be a bogus sale. It may have been bona fide, however, as we have had reports of the unseaworthiness of the Retribution from other sources. The officers and crew were still at Nassau on the 15th. There had not been a United States war vessel off the harbor for a month.

abstract: Price and the Trans-Mississippi Department
snippet: Price and the Trans-Mississippi Department
lead_paragraph: It has been a long time since we had anything official from the rebel headquarters in Arkansas. Since the time when Gens. BLUNT and HERRON drove HINDMAN, with so much precipitation, across the Arkansas River at Van Buren, the rebel hero has lived in comparative seclusion. We have had occasional intercepted letters from his camp, but they clamored chiefly for shoes and corn, and boasted little of the strings of scalps that he was expected to take from invasive "Yankees." The suspicion might reasonably be indulged that HINDMAN had lost much of the splendor of his early promise when he robbed Memphis banks of their money and expended it on his ragged followers, in the name of the Confederate Government. Without another Memphis to rob, how could HINDMAN feed and clothe his conscript army? JEFF. DAVIS could not answer, nor could any Commissary of the Confederacy. And so, being unable to do anything further for or with his Arkansas army, HINDMAN has done the only thing possible under the circumstances -- he has retired from its command and bidden it an affectionate farewell.

abstract: Accounts from Berlin state that the note of M. DE LHUYS, which was communicated by the French Ambassador to Count BISMARK, insists that Prussia shall keep within the limits of neutrality, and proposes a diplomatic intervention at St. Petersburgh. M. BISMARK told the French Ambassador that the arrangement with Russia was purely a military one; that it was not contemplated to send troops into Russian Poland; that the Russians could only pass the frontier after consulting the Prussian authorities; and that the progress of events in Poland justified the hope that the Convention would cease to be applied. In any case, it was said, Prussia was not pledged to depart from the principles of non-intervention, although neutrality could not be spoken of in a question of insurrection. The military measures taken on such a large scale by the Prussian authorities, are perfectly justified by the character of the insurrection, as well as by the great interest which Prussia has in restraining the Polish movement. Prussia only wishes to defend her frontier. At the same time she will do all she can to prevent the insurgents from drawing succors of men, arms, and ammunition from the Prussian provinces. As to the diplomatic intervention with the Russian cabinet, Prussia does not believe she can participate in it, as such an act, would be equivalent to lending a moral support to the insurrection. The English Ambassador, Mr. BUCHANAN, is said to have made similar remarks to those of the French Minister. A letter from Berlin says, however, that Mr. BUCHANAN, after having condemned the Convention, "expressed the strong desire of the English Cabinet that Prussia should stop in this path, otherwise it was possible that France would decide to intervene energetically, and in case of war, England could not depart from her neutrality toward France, as public opinion, and that of the English Parliament, had pronounced very strongly against the policy of Prussia, which is endangering the peace of Europe."

abstract: month of March this year was unusually quiet all over the field of operations. Great movements everywhere seemed on the very eve of takings place, but until the fight at Newbern, on the 14th, which was followed by the affair on the Blackwater, the cavalry affair on the Rappahannock, the naval affair at Port Hud
lead_paragraph: -- The first half of the month of March this year was unusually quiet all over the field of operations. Great movements everywhere seemed on the very eve of takings place, but until the fight at Newbern, on the 14th, which was followed by the affair on the Blackwater, the cavalry affair on the Rappahannock, the naval affair at Port Hudson on the Mississippi, and two or three small skirmishes in Tennessee, there was almost nothing in the military line to chronicle. By these it will be seen that the second half of the month has begun briskly, and we think likely that before it is ended, some of the most important successes of the war will have been consummated.

abstract: Mr. MURPHY introduced a bill permitting city railroads, in any of the cities of the State, to consolidate, on obtaining the consent of at least two-thirds of the shareholders of the companies interested. If any stockholder shall, within twenty days after the determination is arrived at, object to said consolidation, and demand payment for his stock, he may apply to the Supreme Court for the appointment of three persons to appraise the value of his stock, and said Court shall appoint these three persons to appraise the same, and the amount appraised by them shall be paid by the company to the individuals -- the expense of the appraisers to be borne by the company.

abstract: Robbery of Sick and Disabled
snippet: Robbery of Sick and Disabled
lead_paragraph: ed to protect from robbery our soldiers who are compelled by wounds, sickness, duty or leaves of absence to travel between Washington or Baltimore and this City. The line seems to be infested with thieves and pickpockets to a degree unparalleled by anything on record. They steal everything -- greenbacks, postage currency, wallets, knapsacks, clothing, papers, and even crutches. They are expert to an extraordinary degree, and they are so vigilant, wide-awake and untiring, that if they could be put in command of our regiments and brigades, we should hear of no more "surprises." Almost every soldier that comes through has his story to tell about them, and, like the rebels, they seem to be growing continually more desperate.

abstract: PASSION SUNDAY.--To-day, the fifth Sunday in Lent, the Sunday but one before Easter, is called by the Roman Church "Passion Sunday," a title by which the sixth, or "Palm Sunday," is called in the Reformed Church. "To-day," says Dr. COXE, of Calvary, "is called Passion Sunday, because the Services begin to relate the story of our Lord's sufferings and death. The Atonement is preeminently the theme of this day."

abstract: And the War
snippet: And the War
lead_paragraph: Several indications of late observed in Kentucky inspire more hope in the permanent Unionism of that State than we have ever previously had. We have never denied to the loyal people of Kentucky full praise for their fidelity and genuine heroism, under very great difficulties. At the beginning of the rebellion BERIAH MAGOFFIN was Governor of the State, a political adherent of JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, and undoubtedly possessed of the rebel proclivities of the apostate Vice-President. The Legislature was nearly balanced, and the tendencies of the public mind were all apparently toward the rebellion. SIMON BOLIVAR BUCKNER, arch traitor that he was, was placed in command (by MAGOFFIN and the Legislature,) of the State Guard of Kentucky, and the first idea of duty taught to this Guard was, that they were to defend the sacred soil of Kentucky against the tread of any armed Federal force, though called out to defend the Constitution, the Union and the laws! Add to these facts the presence of a quarter of a million of slaves in Kentucky, and the prevalence of a despotic Pro-Slavery sentiment that had long before trampled out every humanizing thought of gradual emancipation taught in other days by HENRY CLAY, and let any candid Northern man answer whether the chances did not seem a hundred to one, or a thousand to one, against holding Kentucky to the Union. Who could resist such power, such combinations and such influences working with desperate energy in favor of the rebellion?

abstract: A Guardian Angel of Connecticut
snippet: A Guardian Angel of Connecticut
lead_paragraph: Connecticut enjoys one advantage over the rest of the Union, which may tend to bad feeling between her and the other States, if she continues to retain it. In nearly every important canvass she is blessed with the ministrations of FERNANDO WOOD, of this City, and she is, we believe, the only State -- New-York, of course, excepted -- upon whom this eminent political philosopher makes his light to shine. What it is about Connecticut which incites his interest we have been unable to discover, after an attentive consideration both of her laws and manners. But whatever it be, it is certain that whenever an important election is at hand, he flies over the border, and distributes warning, reproof and encouragement with a prodigality which is well calculated to make the Connecticut people desire that elections occurred oftener. We could wish that Mr. WOOD were not so exclusive in the distribution of his wisdom, for the sake of the rest of the Union, but we have the consolation of knowing that though his partiality may exasperate other States, it can only draw closer the bonds of Union between us and "the land of steady habits."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented both for and against a Broadway Railroad. The bill appropriating $500,000 to equip the State Militia was reported favorably; also the bill to facilitate the acquisition of land for the Croton Water-works. A Grinding Committee, consisting of nine members, was announced by the President. A bill permitting the consolidation of City railroads was introduced; also a bill to increase the duty on salt. The Cross-town Railroad bill was recommitted for amendment, and the Broadway Railroad bill was made the special order for Tuesday night next. The Union-avenue bill was reported unfavorably. Mr. CONNOLLY's bill, prohibiting banks from making loans on gold coin, was reported unanimously. The bill to incorporate the Parochial Fund of the Episcopal Church of Western New-York was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: The People vs. Edward W. Broune. -- It will be remembered that Dr. Broune is charged with causing the death of Clementina Anderson, by procuring an abortion upon her; and that recently the entire panel of jurors and an extra panel of two hundred and fifty were exhausted without obtaining a jury to try the indictment -- only six men having been found who were qualified to sit as jurors, under the requirement of the law and the challenges of the prisoner. These six were sworn to impartially try him, and had taken their seats in the jury-box. The Court, however, Justice BARNARD, was finally satisfied that a jury could not be obtained in this County, and ordered that the case be postponed, with a view, as understood, of sending it to another county for trial, and discharged the jurors already sworn.

abstract: ulars of the operations of an accomplished rogue in that region, by which several of the banks have been plundered to the extent of $23,500, by means of forged drafts. It appears that about the middle of January last, an individual, by the real or assumed name of O.B. CLARK, made his advent in Rutland. He represented himself to be the general agent of "MILLARD, SINGLETON & CLARK, of Quincy, Ill., importers, dealers and growers of pure blood and graded sheep stock," and the son of the CLARK of that firm, for whom he was buying sheep in Vermont. This CLARK contrived to get himself introduced by a well-known gentleman of Shelburne, Vt., of high standing, and also a dealer in cattle and sheep, upon whom it is now supposed that CLARK had managed in some way to impose himself as the agent of the above-mentioned firm. After pretending to operate in the purchase of sheep, spending some money, and occasionally getting a small genuine draft cashed, he established a business reputation at the banks, of which he suddenly took advantage to present forged drafts to banks at Rutland, Brandon, Orwell, Middlebury, Vergennes and Bellows Falls, for the following amounts: At Brandon, $4,700; Orwell, $4,300; Middlebury, $3,600 or $3,700, and a like sum at Vergennes, and at Bellows Falls, $3,600, all of which were cashed. Some of the drafts purported to be drawn by the Logansport branch of the State Bank of Indiana on the City Bank of New-York City, and others by a Toledo (Ohio) Bank, upon a New-York Bank. The information that the drafts were forgeries was received at Rutland on Friday, but in the meantime the rogue had disappeared with his plunder.

abstract: The obsequies of Sergt. JOHN H. THOMPSON, formerly of the One Hundred and Sixth New-York Regiment, and son of Rev. JOSEPH F. THOMPSON, D.D., were observed at the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday. The officiating clergymen were Rev. Drs. STORRS and BUDDINGTON, of Brooklyn. Over the pulpit were suspended the American colors, joined together with pendants of white and black crape, and the pulpit itself was draped with narrow ribbons of the latter material. At each end of the pulpit was placed a vase of delicate flowers. The coffin was covered with the National flag, upon which were laid wreaths and bouquets. The ceremonies commenced with a chant, by the choir, of a selection from MENDELSSOHN's "St. Paul," after which Rev. Dr. BUDDINGTON read portions of Scripture. Rev. Dr. STORRS then pronounced the address, in which he eulogized in feeling terms the life and noble acts of the lamented deceased. Before separating, the congregation were permitted to take a final look of the remains. The benediction was pronounced by Rev. Dr. STORRS.

abstract: The question of a supply of ice for the coming Spring and Summer months, is beginning to assume a phase of no little interest and importance, as the most extraordinary Winter that ever visited America is gradually drawing to its close. In a few weeks more, the Ice-king will have taken the wings of the wind, and borne himself to those more northern regions where snow and ice prevail in perpetual abundance, and whence we shall not hear from him again until the earth has performed his annual revolution. But if the ancient monarch goes off without treating us to another sharp and decisive "cold snap," the good people of New-York, and all who depend upon her for their supplies of ice, will have reason to regret the departure of the frosty King, and the extreme gentleness with which he has demeaned himself this season. For, by all calculations, the supply of ice this year will fall far short of the necessities of the ordinary domestic consumers, to say nothing of the tens of thousands of foreign ones.

abstract: Gen. EDWIN V. SUMNER was a native of Boston. He entered the army as second lieutenant, second infantry, March 3, 1819, and was appointed from New-York. He has been upon constant duty ever since. He served with distinction in the Mexican campaign, on SCOTT's line, and was severely wounded in the battle of Cerro Gordo. In that campaign he was Major of the Second Regiment of Dragoons, and led the charge at the bridge of Medelin, near Vera Cruz, in which a regiment of lancers was broken and put to flight.
lead_paragraph: Gen. EDWIN V. SUMNER was a native of Boston. He entered the army as second lieutenant, second infantry, March 3, 1819, and was appointed from New-York. He has been upon constant duty ever since. He served with distinction in the Mexican campaign, on SCOTT's line, and was severely wounded in the battle of Cerro Gordo. In that campaign he was Major of the Second Regiment of Dragoons, and led the charge at the bridge of Medelin, near Vera Cruz, in which a regiment of lancers was broken and put to flight.

abstract: Le Nord states that Mr. SLIDELL had just had an interview with M. DROUYN DE LHUYS, in the course of which mention was made of Mr. SEWARD's recent dispatch. Mr. SLIDELL is said not to have concealed from the French Minister his surprise that Mr. SEWARD could think the seceding States willing to send members to the Washington Congress. It is also reported, says Le Nord, that the Government of Richmond has just contracted at Paris a loan for 60,000,000 francs.

abstract: We do not remember to have seen the arguments against any attempt on the part of European Powers to overthrow republican institutions, and establish a monarchy in Mexico, at any time set forth with such clearness and force, and the policy of the United States in that event laid down with such distinctness, as we have found in a dispatch from our able Minister to Austria, the eminent historian, Mr. MOTLEY, which was written on the 12th of February of last year, when the candidacy of the Austrian Archduke MAXIMILIAN was first put forward by LOUIS NAPOLEON for the throne which, even then, in defiance of his constant disavowals to the United States, and in direct violation of the express terms of the Treaty of London, he had determined to establish, if he could, in Mexico. That dispatch is so able, and our position, as then laid before the Government of Austria, is so applicable to the issues of the present moment, as developed by the attitude of France since the Emperor has given to the world that strange piece of bravado, the Forey letter, that we reproduce the portion referred to entire:

abstract: Sumner, Gen., the Death of
snippet: Sumner, Gen., the Death of
lead_paragraph: The loss of the veteran officer and hero, Gen. SUMNER, will be mourned by the whole land. A soldier from his youth, and continuously in the military service of his country, throughout his whole career he stood forth as the very noblest embodiment of what an American officer and patriot should be. Brave as a lion, chivalrous and pure, frank, honest earnest, of fine intelligence and perfect fidelity, of manly mould, courteous and kindly manner, clear-headed, clear-eyed and generous-hearted, devoted unto death to his flag and his country, he has furnished in his military life, of nearly half a century, an admirable illustration of all these qualities. He had been in service all over the Continent -- on the Great Plains of the West, fighting the hostile savages, yet avoiding by his skill and generosity more battles than he ever fought -- in Mexico, where under SCOTT, he commanded at the most famous cavalry actions of that war -- in Kansas, where by his firmness, justice and humanity, he brought to an end a fierce local contest, which, seven years ago, threatened to overspread the country -- on the coast of the Pacific -- and, latterly, in Virginia, in the Army of the Potomac, whose fortunes he followed just one year, but in all of whose battles, from Yorktown to Fredericksburgh, he was a prominent and heroic participator. At the last-mentioned battle, it will be remembered, Gen. BURNSIDE, fearing that his impetuous valor would impel him to rush with his men into the very jaws of the enemy's batteries, and that thus his invaluable advice to him and his invaluable services to the country would be lost, compelled him to stay on this side of the river; but as the smoke and thunder of the battle rolled up, and he could see his old division battling with fearful odds, the lion soul rose within him, so that it was only the most peremptory orders of his chief that could restrain him.

abstract: Two delegates of the Christian Commission, in this City, sailed in the Roanoke for New-Orleans, to join the efficient force now with the Banks expedition. One of these gentlemen is the Professor of Anatomy in one of our Medical Colleges, and was formerly Mayor of Boston. He gives his time for six months to this beneficent work. The other is a clergyman of good repute. At Port Royal, Newbern and Fortress Monroe other delegates of the Commission are now stationed. Volunteer chaplains and delegates are receiving commissions as rapidly as they can be fitted out and forwarded. From Philadelphia, seventeen delegates have gone to the Army of the Potomac this week.

abstract: -We are glad to learn that the Rooms of the "New-England Soldiers' Relief Association" are to be furnished with a collection of books adapted to the place. One of the young men of the popular "Army Committee," New-York Christian Alliance, has undertaken the work. The want of a good collection of books has long been felt by those in charge of the Rooms. A portion of the building will be devoted to a Reading-room, where men are free to resort. Donations of money or books may be sent to the care of Messrs. JOHN J. HINCHMAN & CO., No. 26 Vesey-street, New-York.

abstract: Laws; Necessity for in all Great Nations; Copperhead Resistance to the Laws
snippet: Laws; Necessity for in all Great Nations; Copperhead Resistance to the Laws
lead_paragraph: "Not to crush these serpents before their rattles are grown, would be ruinous," wrote LEE to WASHINGTON, in 1776, of the Long Island Tories, who avowed an intention of resisting the authority of the Provincial Congress. WASHINGTON concurred, but proceeded with characteristic discretion. He replied to LEE: "You can seize upon the persons of the principals; they must be so notoriously known that there will be little danger of committing mistakes." LEE, the historian says, acted up to the letter of these instructions, and, with a vigorous hand, disabled some of the rankest of the species.

abstract: We have already given the remarks of the leading English journals upon Mr. SEWARD's dispatch in reply to the Emperor NAPOLEON's proposition for a joint meeting of Commissioners from the North and the South. Our Paris correspondent, in a letter this morning, shows that from the French Press the dispatch has excited little attention, although the journals got no special order from the authorities as to the course or line of argument they were to pursue in the matter. It fell on a public indifferent to the question -- the Polish insurrection taking precedence of everything else. In the eyes of all, however, the rejection was regarded as a check for the French Government, and it was admitted on all hands that there would be no farther attempt at intervention.

abstract: The monotony of affairs, in this vicinity, is relieved occasionally by operations whose character is the very reverse of those that usually make up the sum total of stern war. Playing upon the credulity of the watchful rebels at Vicksburgh, horse racing; deer and duck hunting, visits from rare old characters from the plantations around us; are among a few of these events whose lightness serves to dispel the gloom of the shadows around us.

abstract: CHURCH MOVEMENTS. -- The Rev. Dr. KREBS, of the Rutgers-street Church, has been unanimously invited to take charge of the Madison-avenue Presbyterian Church, late Rev. Dr. BANNARD's. It is confidently expected that he will accept the invitation, and that he will be accompanied by a portion of his former friends and parishioners, who, for several years past, have been removing up town. It is stated that the Rutgers-street congregation have voted to dispose of their present Church property, and to remove up town. The Church thus far has been sustained by the cooperation of its members, who have already removed, with those who yet remain. But the latter are now so diminished in comparison with the former, that it is found necessary for the preservation of this old and important church, that it should be removed to a more convenient location in the upper part of the City. The property including the large and elegant church, parsonage, and vacant ground adjacent, will soon be offered for sale.

abstract: Haws. Hon. Robert T., Ex-Comptroller of New-York
snippet: Haws. Hon. Robert T., Ex-Comptroller of New-York
lead_paragraph: We have to announce the death of Hon. ROET. T. HAWS, Ex-Comptroller of this City, whose recent severe illness terminated fatally yesterday morning at his residence, No. 95 Allen-street. There are few public men in our day who sustain so reputable a character as did Mr. HAWS. As a merchant he was known among his fellows as possessed of a clear, strong mind, great firmness of character and of personal integrity beyond suspicion or reproach. During the last ten years he gave much time and attention to local politics, at first as a Whig, and subsequently as a Republican. He was a member of the Board of Aldermen for four years, and his record does not show a single "absent" While acting in that capacity, his enlarged mercantile experience, his sound financial judgment, and his honorable integrity, proved of the highest value to his constituency and the City at large. Subsequently in 1858 he was nominated by the Republicans, the Americans and the People's party for the Comptrollership, in opposition to GRORGE H. PURSER, who ran for the Tammany Democrats, and STEPHEN P. RUSSELL, who represented the "Antis." He was elected and held the position with credit to himself and eminent satisfaction to the tax-payers until the expiration of his term, when he was succeeded by the present incumbent.

abstract: The Guerrillas in
snippet: The Guerrillas in
lead_paragraph: -- The rebel guerrillas are again at work in Kentucky. Before day yesterday morning, they attacked the village of Mount Sterling, sixty miles east of Frankfort, in the northeastern part of the State, and after a fight, captured the Union garrison of a couple of hundred men. It is possible they may capture other posts and garrisons, if they are not promptly attended to.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, petitions were presented both for and against a Broadway Railroad. The bill appropriating $500,000 to equip the State Militia was reported favorably; also the bill to facilitate the acquisition of land for the Croton Water-works. A Grinding Committee, consisting of nine members, was announced by the President. A bill permitting the consolidation of City railroads was introduced; also a bill to increase the duty on salt. The Cross-town Railroad bill was recommitted for amendment, and the Broadway Railroad bill was made the special order for Tuesday night next. The Union-avenue bill was reported unfavorably. Mr. CONNOLLY's bill, prohibiting banks from making loans on gold coin, was reported unanimously. The bill to incorporate the Parochial Fund of the Episcopal Church of Western New-York was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: It is now evident that the tribe of orators and journalists who have undertaken the task of dragging the people of the United States down to their own level, have turned their attention to the Conscription act, and are torturing their wits to convert it into an instrument of division and discomfiture.
lead_paragraph: It is now evident that the tribe of orators and journalists who have undertaken the task of dragging the people of the United States down to their own level, have turned their attention to the Conscription act, and are torturing their wits to convert it into an instrument of division and discomfiture. And we need not doubt that they will meet with a certain measure of success. Wherever we see knaves and charlatans, we may be sure that there are dupes not very far off. The field of imposture is just as fertile in politics as in money matters, and is almost as zealously cultivated.

abstract: On Convention of all the States
snippet: On Convention of all the States
lead_paragraph: The rebels at Richmond are very hard to please. JOHN VAN BUREN has been, in his proposed treatment of them, the most accommodating of men. He advised the capture of Richmond as a point of honor on the part of our Government, but after we had possession of the rebel capital, he thought we should issue a call for a general Convention of all the States, and try to settle the controversy between the North and South. If we failed to satisfy the South that we meant them good and not evil, and that mutual prosperity could best be secured by continued union, Mr. VAN BUREN was inclined to sing, "Wayward sisters, depart in peace."

abstract: When I arrived here yesterday it was confidently asserted that to-day was to witness the opening of the canal from the river into the lake. The canal had been completed, and all that was necessary to allow the water to rush in was the cutting of one small strip of the levee, a narrow embankment of only six or seven feet in thickness.
lead_paragraph: LAKE PROVIDENCE, Thursday, March 12, 1863.

abstract: We published, a day or two ago, an extract from a Richmond paper indicating that the rebels contemplated falling back from the Rappahannock, and establishing their lines nearer Richmond. Our Washington correspondent informs us that reliable information has been received there that the movement has commenced.
lead_paragraph: We published, a day or two ago, an extract from a Richmond paper indicating that the rebels contemplated falling back from the Rappahannock, and establishing their lines nearer Richmond. Our Washington correspondent informs us that reliable information has been received there that the movement has commenced. If so, we shall doubtless soon have important news from the Army of the Potomac.

abstract: We are glad to announce that Mr. MARETZEK'S tribulations, which were heavy to bear last week, are at an end. Mme. MEDORI has recovered from her throat complaint, and Signor MAZZOLINI is reported to be in excellent voice. lead_paragraph: We are glad to announce that Mr. MARETZEK'S tribulations, which were heavy to bear last week, are at an end. Mme. MEDORI has recovered from her throat complaint, and Signor MAZZOLINI is reported to be in excellent voice. The interrupted programme of last Monday will be commenced afresh to-night with the performance of "Norms"--a work in which the lady has won some of her greatest European triumphs. The cast of the opera is in all respects admirable, and the performance will undoubtedly be a memorable one. Signor MAZZOLINI is the Pollio, and Signor BIACHI the Oroveso. Mlle. SULLEE, a most correct and admirable artiste, sustains the role of Adalgisa.

abstract: Stanley, A. P., D. D.; Lectures on the History of the Jewish Church; Green, Prof. William Henry; The Pentateuch Vindicated from the Aspersions of Bishop Colenso
snippet: Stanley, A. P., D. D.; Lectures on the History of the Jewish Church; Green, Prof. William Henry; The Pentateuch Vindicated from the Aspersions of Bishop Colenso
lead_paragraph: Up to this time the Spring season has been one rather of promise than of performance among publishers. Many causes have retarded the issue of books now in various stages of preparation. Principal among these is the enhanced cost, not merely of paper, but of all the other materials (binders' board, muslin, &c.) that enter into the mechanical construction of a book. Some relief was hoped for from the action of Congress on the paper duties, but the reduction which was carried of 15 per cent. from the former rates is of no practical effect in the existing state of the exchange market, and as a benefit to the book and newspaper publishers, is merely illusory. It results from these increased prices that a volume formerly manufactured for 30 cents, cannot now be produced for less than from 45 to 48 cents, thereby demonstrating the necessity of a corresponding addition to the former scale of retail prices, to which it was feared the public were hardly ready to respond. The general ease of circumstances, arising from an abundant supply of money, has, however, shown that this apprehension was unfounded, and publishers are now eager to mee the buoyant demand for really good sterling literature, as a glance at their numerous announcements will prove. Messrs. HARPERS, beside a host of minor works, have just ready KINGLAKE's History of the Crimean War -- a book that has excited a more vivid sensation abroad than any publication since Lord MACAULAY's England -- and the able and exhaustive work on Japan, The Capital of the Tycoon, a Narrative of Three Years' Residence, by Sir RUTHERFORD ALCOCK, the first English Minister to that country. The important scientific subjects connected with man, his fate on this earth, his position in the series of animated beings, his typical forms and varieties of species, receive ample discussion in Sir CHARLES LYELL's Geological Evidences of the Antiquity of Man, Prof. HUXLEY's Man's Place in Nature, and Mr. CHARLES BRACE's Races of the Old World, a Manual of Ethnology, to be published respectively by Messrs. G.W. CHILDS, (of Philadelphia,) APPLETON & CO., and C. SCRIBNER. The latter publisher will also soon issue an edition of the New Testament, with explanatory notes or scholia, by Prof. HOWARD CROSBY, late of New-Brunswick, who has just accepted the pastorate of the Fourth-avenue Church, New-York. Among the great historical works promised, which we hope in due time to introduce to our readers, is D'AUBIGNE's History of Calvin and his work of Reformation in the Church, printed from advance sheets furnished by the author to Messrs. ROBERT CARTER & BROTHERS. MERIVALE's able and scholarly History of the Romans under the Empire, to be brought out in superior style by Messrs. APPLETON, and a translation of Gen. JOMINI's Military and Political Life of the Emperor Napoleon, from the Press of D. VAN NOSTRAND, executed by no less an authority than the Commander-in-Chief of the United States army, Maj.-Gen. H.W. HALLECK.

abstract: By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Europa yesterday, we received advices from Eu-  rope two days later than came to hand by the Norwegian. The news is not specially important. The great topic in England was the entry of Princess ALEXANDRA into London, which event took place on the day the Europa left Liverpool--the 7th inst.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Europa yesterday, we received advices from Europe two days later than came to hand by the Norwegian. The news is not specially important. The great topic in England was the entry of Princess ALEXANDRA into London, which event took place on the day the Europa left Liverpool -- the 7th inst. The latest telegrams via Queenstown state that the Royal squadron, convoying the Princess, arrived at Gravesend before noon, and that the party reached London at 1 1/2 o'clock, and were welcomed with an excitement and enthusiasm never before equaled in England. The party subsequently proceeded to Windsor. The comments of the journals on American affairs are unimportant. Parliamentary proceedings were generally uninteresting. The King of Belgium had consented to arbitrate between Brazil and England. The French and British Governments, it is stated, had agreed as to the tenor of their notes to Russia regarding Poland. Both speak as earnestly as diplomacy allows of their hopes for the fulfillment of the solemn promises made to the Poles. A slight advance had taken place in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were generally unchanged.

abstract: The journeymen bricklayers of Jersey City held an adjourned meeting at Turner's Hall, on Saturday evening, to hear the report of the Committee appointed to wait upon the employers and ask an increase of wages. They reported that two of the employers, who had considerable contract work on hand taken last Fall, conceded that the men ought to have an advance, and they were willing to pay $2 a day from the 1st of May. All the other employers said they would pay $2 a day from the 1st of April, if it was a general thing. The report was accepted, and a motion was concurred in that the journeymen ask $2 a day from the 1st of April. The journeymen painters also held a meeting, and appointed a Committee to wait upon their employers and ask an advance of two shillings a day. They adjourned to meet again the present week.

abstract: Gen. Wool's Order on Duty
snippet: Gen. Wool's Order on Duty
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. WOOL issues a final and impressive order to-day, which will command the earnest attention of every enlisted soldier in this Department. The day of hesitation and equivocation is past. The Government must know what men absent from duty will willingly return, and what knaves will defy its authority and incur the penalties of the crime of desertion by staying away from their posts. Under authority of an act of Congress, the President has offered pardon to all who report themselves for duty by the 1st proximo. The orders of Gen. WOOL designate the places of rendezvous for those soldiers who may avail themselves of the benefit of this humane measure. And they further solemnly warn all who fail to report, that they "shall be arrested and punished as the law provides."

abstract: -- The Council of Twenty-five and the Committee of Twenty-five, appointed at the meeting for organization of the Loyal National League, at the Cooper Institute, on the evening of the 20th inst., held separate and joint sessions yesterday afternoon. JOHN A. STEVENS, Esq., President of the Bank of Commerce, was appointed Treasurer of the League, by vote of the Council. JAMES A. ROOSEVELT, Esq., was appointed Secretary of the League, by vote of the Executive Committee. Standing and other committees were also appointed, and the meeting adjourned until Thursday.

abstract: Frederick W. Kaupe vs. Ira C. Pierson. -- This was an action to recover for the alleged wrongful detention by the defendant of certain groceries belonging to the plaintiff, and which the plaintiff claimed the defendant became unlawfully possessed of. The defence was that in September last, one Henry Kempe was indebted to one Gilbert Griffin and one Martin L. Van Time, in a cause of action arising upon a contract, in the sum of $140 18. That action was commenced thereon against Henry Kempe in the Third Judicial District Court, and a judgment of $1,516 62 was recovered.

abstract: We give, this morning, a very interesting budget of news from the South. There are glimpses of the inside condition of affairs at all the points of interest--Richmond, Charleston, Vicksburgh, the Yazoo, the Mississippi and Middle Tennessee. The Richmond papers continue to be greatly exercised at the position of the loyal conservatives of the North.
lead_paragraph: We give, this morning, a very interesting budget of news from the South. There are glimpses of the inside condition of affairs at all the points of interest -- Richmond, Charleston, Vicksburgh, the Yazoo, the Mississippi and Middle Tennessee. The Richmond papers continue to be greatly exercised at the position of the loyal conservatives of the North. The Dispatch says: "Of the two classes of our mortal foemen at the North, there is little to choose;" but it adds that "EDWARD EVERETT and CALEB CUSHING are to be despised and execrated more than PHILLIPS or GARRISON;" and, in a high chivalric tone, decides that "no man of honor could take EVERETT or CUSHING by the hand, the latter especially." At the same time we learn that the garroters who infested the city in which this pink of chivalry and mirror of honor dwells, have flitted, but that their place has been taken by a "jolly set of well-dressed Baltimore burglars," who are often arrested with "jimmies" in their pockets, -- that drunken men, in the uniform of Confederate officers, are daily seen in the streets, and the theatres are infested with drunken chivalry, -- that a regular fist-fight occurred in Capitol-square in the presence of hundreds of ladies, no effort being made to separate the pugilists, who fought it out, -- that the number of dens where the vilest of "apple brandy" is sold is astonishing -- that at every bar hangs a card upon which is printed "Blockade, 75 cents," and that a small wine glassful is measured out for one "blockade." The question might arise, if one wine glassful or "blockade" of the "vilest apple brandy" costs 75 cents, what is the number and cost of the "blockades" required to make a rebel officer or "man of honor" drunk, and how many drunks would it require to degrade either of them to the level of "taking by the hand EDWARD EVERETT or CALEB CUSHING, the latter especially?" But such questions are quite out of place under the circumstances. Another extract says that hot coffee in Richmond is sold at the restaurants for one dollar per cup -- or "blockade," we suppose. It is evident that the people of Richmond must either be blessed with tremendous piles of money, or must be rather scant in their "blockades," whether of the inebriating cup or the cup that cheers without inebriating. We judge the former must be the case, as the streets and theatres are described as daily infested with reeling drunkards. Probably the standard for judging a "man of honor" in the South is the amount of money one has on hand; and if so, we do not wonder at their refusing to shake hands with our Northern Conservatives, for few of them could afford to get happy were liquor sold at Richmond rates.

abstract: GOOD NEWS RECEIVED AND EXPECTED.  The news received to-day by the Government from Port Hudson and Vicksburgh is of the most cheering character. abstract: Col. LUDROW, Commissioner for the exchange of prisoners, arrived here to-day and made his report to the Secretary of War. He has succeeded, after much labor, in getting all the citizens released and exchanged. The rebel authorities tried very hard to force many of these prisoners into their service. Col. LUDLOW confirms the reports of the great distress existing in Richmond and other parts of the South for want of food. He says they met with a serious loss by the burning of an immense storehouse of supplies, of which no newspaper mention has ever been made.

abstract: Loyal and Disloyal Democrats
snippet: Loyal and Disloyal Democrats
lead_paragraph: The World takes exception to the use of the expression "loyal Democrats," "as if," it indignantly exclaims," "as if there were any disloyal Democrats." We think our neighbor must admit, on reflection, that there are some circumstances which justify outsiders in making this classification of Democrats. There are such apparent differences in the position of different men, who are or have been alike called Democrats, that the ordinary human understanding finds difficulty in considering them both as standing on the same platform. Thus, for instance, a so-called Democrat introduces into the Legislature of Indiana a resolution demanding an armistice, while another introduces into the Legislature of Ohio a resolution that "we will have no armistice." The Democrats in the New-Jersey Legislature introduce various sets of peace resolutions, and the officers of the Eleventh Regiment of New-Jersey, among whom we cannot doubt that there are some Democrats, resolve that "the passage or even the introduction of the so-alled peace resolutions is wicked, weak, and cowardly." Mr. VALLANDINGHAM declares that the "object of a vigorous prosecution of the war is disunion, separation, destruction, despotism" -- Mr. SEYMOUR of Connecticut declares that "we have gone far enough in an unprofitable and useless struggle: it is time to sheathe the sword." But Mr. BRADY and Mr. VAN BUREN and Gov. WRIGHT and ANDREW JOHNSON, Democrats all, and speaking not for themselves alone, declare that the war shall go on until the authority of the Government is restored and the rebellion is destroyed, and that there is no other way to attain peace than that.

abstract: About 12 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a horrible wife-murder was perpetrated by a man named TIMOTHY O'MARA, at No. 94 West Fortieth-street, near Broadway. The facts and circumstances connected with the tragedy are substantially as follows: T. O'MARA, a hostler, with his wife CATHARINE, and two children, who are boys, aged about 7 and 4 years, formerly resided at the place mentioned, but about a year since he joined the Thirty-seventh New-York regiment of Volunteers, and for some time past he has been with the army on the Rappahannock. About six weeks ago he deserted, and made his way to this City. Two weeks since he again rented his old residence for himself and family. He has been in the habit of coming home late at night, and generally grossly intoxicated. His wife was a woman of very sober and industrious habits.

abstract: The journeymen tailors of the City are on a strike for more pay. On Wednesday last the "Central Journeymen Tailors' Association" -- a very respectable organization, with a somewhat elongated name -- passed a resolve that there should thenceforth be an advance on the prices paid for work as follows $1 25 on business costs; 50 cents on fine costs, and 25 cents pantaloons and vents.

abstract: -- Mrs. LUCILLE WESTERN, a a lady of provincial repute, who, it will be remembered, appeared meteorically at the Academy of Music some weeks since, commenced a star engagement at this house last evening. The play was, as before, a dramatic version of "East Lynne -- " a good version, but over-absorbent of incidents that are available only in narrative form. Miss WESTERN appeared in the characters of Lady Isabel and Madame Vine. It is unpleasant to speak of a much lauded performance in terms of censure, but we cannot avoid saying that Miss WESTERN has yet to study the characters she tries to impersonate. Her intensities are too hysterical to come within the range of art, and too ceaseless to belong to nature. They are simply painful. In the business of the scene she is superfluously minute, and resorts to expedients that have not heretofore found a recognition on the stage -- such as filling her mou[???]h with a large portion of an article of dress, in order to stifle her emotion. The English language, too, does not sound so graceful as it should from the lips of so young and fair an artist. In fact, it is frequently mispronounced. That the lady possesses natural ability is beyond doubt, but it is equally apparent that her style has been vitiated by premature "starring" and indiscriminate praise.

abstract: Between the two classes of our mortal foemen at the North there is little to chose. One is commercial and the other crazy. If the latter are more cruel and devilish in their 10th, the former are more persistent and systematic in action. If we had only the lunatics to deal with we might hope for a lucid interval, or possibly that their insanity might vary its form. But of the commercial classes we can entertain no such expectations. They have invested their money in the war, and they intend to get it back, if they send every dollar they have left after that which is gone.

abstract: The Constitution brought from the wreck of the Golden Gate $100,000 in treasure : also, 3,000 bags of coffee from the Isthmus, creating a panic in the market. Rio declined to 27c.; Costa Rica to 25c. Alcohol and Whisky improve. Money easy. Atlantic currency exchange, equivalent to 40@45 premium for gold in New-York, 3@6 premium. Sterling, 48d. abstract: From all accounts that reach us, we are led to the conclusion that ere a great while Gen. Bragg will be forced either to engage Rosecrans in battle, or fall back upon Chattanooga. The country would deplore the necessity which may force him to the adoption of the latter alternative. It is all-important that we continue to hold Middle Tennessee and North Alabama, of otherwise we shrlt find ourselves in straitened circumstances for army supplies another year hence.

abstract: -- The long promised performance  of "Norma," with Mme. ME[???]ORI as the heroine, took place last evening, and attracted the best house of the season. The lady, although exhibiting on her entrance the traces of recent indisposition, had evidently reserved herself for the task, and during the representation appeared to grander advantage than she has yet had the opportunity of doing. Her interpretation of the opening recitative was replete with dramatic effect, and Casta Diva, although attended with mechanical difficulties [???] was finally  rendered -- the cabaletta creating a perfect furore and an enthusiastic recal. In the duo scene with Adalgisa and the finale to the act she was equal to GRISI, and both in singing and acting elicited tumultuous applause.
lead_paragraph: -- The long promised performance of "Norma," with Mme. ME[???]ORI as the heroine, took place last evening, and attracted the best house of the season. The lady, although exhibiting on her entrance the traces of recent indisposition, had evidently reserved herself for the task, and during the representation appeared to grander advantage than she has yet had the opportunity of doing. Her interpretation of the opening recitative was replete with dramatic effect, and Casta Diva, although attended with mechanical difficulties [???] was finally rendered -- the cabaletta creating a perfect furore and an enthusiastic recal. In the duo scene with Adalgisa and the finale to the act she was equal to GRISI, and both in singing and acting elicited tumultuous applause.

lead_paragraph: Saturn and Mercury are at last in conjunction. The National Intelligencer and the Post both agree that the President should not use the authority given him by the last Congress to issue letters-of-marque. The chance that this may be done disturbs the moral balance of both. This is really a very curious phenomenon.

abstract: LAURA KEENE's THEATRE. -- A drama in three acts called "Jesse McLane" was produced here last evening. It is described as an entirely new work, but savors strongly of an English origin -- a circumstance that need excite no surprise when it is remembered that Miss KEENE has frequently procured her novelties from the other side in advance of their production there. Albeit on the well-worn topic of wifely infidelity and desertion, the play is a powerful one. The heroine is the wife of a Pittsburgh miner; she is tempted by the proprietor of the mine, elopes with him, and hardly does a creditable thing -- except suffer afterward. The miner goes in pursuit, not for purposes of revenge -he wrestles with himself and conquers that feeling -but in fulfillment of a vow made to the girl's parents that he would, under all circumstances, watch over and protect her. The interviews with the seducer, leading to the final catastrophe, are of the usual kind, the denoument, however, being novel, and not strictly in accordance with poetic justice.
lead_paragraph: LAURA KEENE's THEATRE. -- A drama in three acts called "Jesse McLane" was produced here last evening. abstract: ING LAW.--Mr. VAN DYCK, the Bank Superintendent of this State, has given notice that he shall take steps to forbid the circulation of any notes as currency, within this State, which are not issued in strict conformity with the laws of this State.
lead_paragraph: ING LAW. -- Mr. VAN DYCK, the Bank Superintendent of this State, has given notice that he shall take steps to forbid the circulation of any notes as currency, within this State, which are not issued in strict conformity with the laws of this State. Those laws require that all such notes shall be based on a deposit in the Superintendent's office of State stocks, United States stocks, and bonds and mortgages, in certain specified proportions. Mr. VAN DYCK deems it his duty to proceed by law against the circulation of notes based on any other securities, no matter by what Government their issue is authorized, and he suggests that the remedy in the premises lies with the Legislature.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, the laborers employed by the Erie Railroad Company to work on the piers, assembled on the dock as usual, but refused to proceed to work unless they received $1 50 per day. Some time previous to the affair of yesterday, the workmen demanded the same wages and the privilege of having Sunday to themselves, but finally agreed to resume work for $1 25 per day. The foreman refused to comply with their repeated demand, whereupon they congregated in the street and in the vicinity of the piers, making an aggregate number of over a thousand people, and expressed their determination not to work. At 8 o'clock the foreman notified the men that he should take steps to employ other workmen; but in consequence of the absence of unemployed men, he did not carry out his measure. At 9 o'clock the crowd had gathered opposite the Duane-street dock, leaving Pier No. 36 entirely deserted. This being the case, a cartman or some person in authority employed negroes to remove some cotton bales. No sooner had the negroes got to work than the strikers ran wildly toward them and commenced assaulting them so that at last they were compelled to abandon their labors, and were driven off the pier amid a shower of clubs, stones and other missiles. One person, supposed to be the ringleader, was arrested by a policeman from whom the mob immediately rescued him. At about noon a portion of the laborers were informed that their demand had been complied with and that they would receive in future $1 50 per day.
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday morning, the laborers employed by the Erie Railroad Company to work on the piers, assembled on the dock as usual, but refused to proceed to work unless they received $1 50 per day. Some time previous to the affair of yesterday, the workmen demanded the same wages and the privilege of having Sunday to themselves, but finally agreed to resume work for $1 25 per day. The foreman refused to comply with their repeated demand, whereupon they congregated in the street and in the vicinity of the piers, making an aggregate number of over a thousand people, and expressed their determination not to work. At 8 o'clock the foreman notified the men that he should take steps to employ other workmen; but in consequence of the absence of unemployed men, he did not carry out his measure. At 9 o'clock the crowd had gathered opposite the Duane-street dock, leaving Pier No. 36 entirely deserted. This being the case, a cartman or some person in authority employed negroes to remove some cotton bales. No sooner had the negroes got to work than the strikers ran wildly toward them and commenced assaulting them so that at last they were compelled to abandon their labors, and were driven off the pier amid a shower of clubs, stones and other missiles. One person, supposed to be the ringleader, was arrested by a policeman from whom the mob immediately rescued him. abstract: -- The Courrier des Etats Unis gives no credit to the wild report that the French army has entered the City of Mexico, -- though it does believe the announcement made in the dispatch from San Francisco, that on the 2d of March they were only eleven leagues from the capital. It explains the matter by supposing that Gen. FOREY had decided to leave Puebla behind him; and this view of the case is confirmed by letters from Havana, which state that Gen. BAZAINE had passed Puebla to take up a strong position at Huamantla, between Puebla and Mexico. It is added that 10,000 men were left before Puebla to hold the garrison in check.

abstract: The steamer George Washington, which arrived at this port early yesterday morning, from New-Orleans on the afternoon of the 15th inst., brought dispatches from Baton Rouge, which were put on board at the Southwest Pass. These dispatches contain the first reliable intelligence received regarding Admiral FARRAGUT'S operations at Port Hudson.
lead_paragraph: The steamer George Washington, which arrived at this port early yesterday morning, from New-Orleans on the afternoon of the 15th inst., brought dispatches from Baton Rouge, which were put on board at the Southwest Pass. These dispatches contain the first reliable intelligence received regarding Admiral FARRAGUT'S operations at Port Hudson. Though very brief, they are sufficient to show that the rebel reports of the affair of the 14th were much exaggerated, though in some respects true. A dispatch from CHARLES S. BULKLEY, Assistant Superintendent of the Military Telegraph in the Gulf Department, states that the Admiral, leading in the Hartford, attacked the Port Hudson batteries at 11 o'clock at night; that the firing on both sides was rapid and severe, and that the Mississippi ran aground, was abandoned and burned. Another dispatch, received at the New-England rooms in this City, states that the Admiral passed the Port Hudson batteries with his fleet -- all but the Mississippi, which suffered the fate above indicated. The two dispatches concur in the important statement that Gen. BANKS' army was within five miles of the enemy's works, in good spirits. The next arrival from New-Orleans will probably bring us more exciting intelligence.

lead_paragraph: It was at one time in the ambition of the South to establish Slavery in all the United States. Massachusetts, it was supposed, would prove most refractory under the proposed discipline of Southern plantations, but ROBERT TOOMBS, of Georgia, did not doubt that he would live to see her subdued, and he boasted that he would "call the roll of his slaves on Bunker Hill."

abstract: I told you in my last that we were on the eve of action, and I was not mistaken. abstract: The Abbot collection of paintings, many of them of national interest, will be sold this evening at the Institute of Arts, No. 625 Broadway, by Mr. EDWARD SINTZENICH, a gentleman thoroughly versed in the merits of the works that pass under his hammer. The collection includes the Washington series, by J.B. STEARNS, a fine reproduction of COLES' "Voyage of Life," and examples, convenient in size, of Gignoux, Huntingdon, Hart, Louis Lang, Sontag, Vernert, Inman, Nehlig, Wm. Shayer, Roudel Delessard, Coutourier, Van Beest, Lazurus and other well-known names. The sale will be continued to-morrow evening.

abstract: of the Board of Aldermen has made a report in favor of building, as an experiment, two stone piers, one on the East and the other on the North River, for the purpose of testing their utility as compared with the wooden piers, which are all the City has had hitherto. The report urges very strongly the necessity of a complete system of substantial stone piers and wharves for the convenience of our commerce, and shows how far behind every other considerable commercial city in the world New-York has hitherto been in this respect. The matter deserves the attention of all who are interested in the commercial prosperity of the City. We trust some prompt and efficient action will be taken upon it.

abstract: New-York; D. E. Crary, steaming; five men killed
snippet: New-York; D. E. Crary, steaming; five men killed
lead_paragraph: About 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a terrific explosion occurred on board the steam-tug D.E. Crary, lying at the foot of Spring-street, North River. The noise produced by the explosion was heard for a long distance, and such was the violence of the concussion, that the lamps along West and the adjoining streets, were extinguished. Fragments of the boat were thrown into the air in every direction, some of which were subsequently found five blocks distant from the scene of the disaster.

abstract: Copperhead Walls of What Might Have Been
snippet: Copperhead Walls of What Might Have Been
lead_paragraph: The splendid chapter in Les Miserables which describes the battle of Waterloo, is marred in several places by the author's absurd speculations upon what might have hapdened, if certain things had not happened; if the peasant that guided the Prussian column had lost his way, if NAPOLEON had not had a pain in his stomach, or if it had not rained. The splendid chapter in Les Miserables which describes the battle of Waterloo, is marred in several places by the author's absurd speculations upon what might have happened, if certain things had not happened; if the peasant that guided the Prussian column had lost his way, if NAPOLEON had not had a pain in his stomach, or if it had not rained. There must be a good deal that is fascinating about this sort of intellectual diversion, or a man of HUGO's resources would certainly not be tempted to indulge in it; and we know as a matter of fact, that for the mass of twaddling moralists, and cheap philosophers and metaphysicians, it has irresistible attractions. Its greatest charm lies in the circumstance that anybody, no matter how slender his stock of knowledge, or how limited his capacity, can indulge in it to his heart's content without the slightest fear of refutation or contradiction. He has only to provide himself with an emperor or a general or statesman and a piece of orange-peel or a badly-baked pie, and he has, forthwith, the fate of mankind in his hands, and can mold it at his leisure without let or hindrance. The emperor has only to step on the orange-peel and fracture his thigh and die of gangrene, or the general has only to eat the pie before breakfast on the morning of battle and be led off the field suffering from severe griping, and two or three kingdoms, or all Christendom, fall into the philosopher's hands for rearrangement and redistribution. Or he may, if he is ambitious, eschew orange-peel or pie -- though effects produced by these trifles are by far the most striking -- and by supposing great and decisive victories to have been crushing defeats, by supposing whole nations to have said Aye when they actually said No, by supposing statesmen to have known things which at the time it was impossible for them to know, or supposing them to have done things which at the time would have seemed very foolish, though they now look wise -- he at once gets the
headline: {'main': 'What If Your Uncle Had Been Your Aunt?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What If Your Uncle Had Been Your Aunt?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Reaction in Public Feeling and its Cause
snippet: Reaction in Public Feeling and its Cause
lead_paragraph: Not since the opening of the war has a month passed so absolutely uneventful in a military way as the last. Hardly an advance step has been taken in any quarter, hardly a blow struck. The five great armies -- under HOOKER, under ROSECRANS, under GRANT, under HUNTER, under BANKS -- remain precisely in statu quo, or if any of them have moved, the result is wholly unknown. The month has been as barren, too, in naval results. And yet not a month has passed, since the beginning of the war, in which the public spirit has undergone so great a change. Deep despondency has given way to high confidence. The difference of thirty per cent. in the price of gold is but an inadequate token of the difference in the public feeling.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The opera of "Linda di Chamounix" will be produced here this evening, for the first time under Mr. MARETZEK'S present direction. Madame MEDORI, whose enormous success has become the town talk, appears as the heroine, and Madame SULZER, Signor BELLINE, Signor BIACHI and Signor COLETTI are also in the distribution.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The opera of "Linda di Chamounix" will be produced here this evening, for the first time under Mr. MARETZEK'S present direction. Madame MEDORI, whose enormous success has become the town talk, appears as the heroine, and Madame SULZER, Signor BELLINE, Signor BIACHI and Signor COLETTI are also in the distribution. The most interesting feature of the cast is Signor MINETTI, Mr. MARETZEK's other tenor, who makes his debut as Carlo. This gentleman is said to possess an admirable voice, and of the soft, sympathetic kind, so much affected by our public.

abstract: All the iron-clad vessels building for the United States Government, save two, are, we believe, constructed from plans furnished by Capt. ERICSSON, and, as a matter of course, bear a certain resemblance to each other.
lead_paragraph: All the iron-clad vessels building for the United States Government, save two, are, we believe, constructed from plans furnished by Capt. ERICSSON, and, as a matter of course, bear a certain resemblance to each other. The two exceptions are the Keokuk and Onondaga. The former has been already described in detail. Of the latter, nothing has been hitherto printed in these columns. She was designed by the proprietor of the Morgan Iron Works, Mr. GEORGE QUINTARD, and is building by Mr. ROWLAND. She will be launched in a few weeks.

abstract: The Democrat learns from a gentleman just from Vicksburgh, that the steamer Diligent, with the Eighth Missouri Regiment, had succeeded in entering Yazoo River above Haines' Bluff. Her course was through Cypress Dayou, which debouches into the Yazoo opposite JOHNSON'S plantation, where Gen. SHERMAN'S troops landed last December; thence through Shelle's Bayou into the Sunflower, which empties into the Yazoo twenty miles above Haines' Bluff. The Diligent was accompanied by a light gunboat.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, March 24.

abstract: All England is in a state of extatic glorification to-day. The Royal Princess of Denmark passes through London on her way to Windsor Castle, where, on Tuesday next, she is to be married to the Prince of Wales. She arrived in the Thames yesterday, lands this morning at Gravesend, comes by railway to London, and will pass through the metropolis, from the Bricklayers' Arms station to Paddington, attended by the civic dignitaries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Fridays, March 6, 1863.

abstract: When in 1858, the late lamented ROBERT T. HAWS was a candidate for City Comptroller, an address was published in the newspapers advocating the election of the ticket headed by his name. That address which was prepared by E. DELAFIELD SMITH, Esq., attracted much attention at the time, from the force and ability with which it was written. The following extract, in which Mr. HAWS is eulogized, will now be read with interest. Its subject has passed away from the midst of a sorrowing community, having more than verified the glowing predictions with which the writer accompanied his praise of the character and capacity of his associate and friend:

abstract: -- Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of CATHARINE O'MARA, whose murder by her husband was reported in our columns yesterday morning. The testimony before the jury substantially tallied with the report which we gave. The jury, without leaving their seats, found that deceased died of "wounds inflicted with a razor in the hands of her husband, TIMOTHY O'MARA." Answering the usual questions, O'MARA said to Coroner RANNEY that he could recollect little that had occurred; he knew that he had taken a razor from the mantelpiece, but subsequently his memory failed until he saw his wife dying, with her throat eut; his wife had always been sober and affectionate, and there had been nothing in her conduct to provoke him to the commission of the crime. The Coroner thereupon committed O'MARA to the Tombs.
lead_paragraph: -- Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of CATHARINE O'MARA, whose murder by her husband was reported in our columns yesterday morning. The Coroner thereupon committed O'MARA to the Tombs.

abstract: Police Commissioners; Gov. Seymour's Charges
snippet: Police Commissioners; Gov. Seymour's Charges
lead_paragraph: liberty of asking what Gov. SEYMOUR is doing in regard to the charges preferred against the Metropolitan Police Commissioners at the outset of his administration? It will be remembered that the very first official act which Gov. SEYMOUR performed after taking the oath of office was to summon these Commissioners before him for examination, -- the time for which was fixed two days before the meeting of the Legislature. A general outcry against so sudden and so summary a proceeding -- called for by nothing but an assumed partisan necessity for securing their removal before the meeting of the Legislature -- arrested it. But Gov. SEYMOUR then announced that he should take the earliest opportunity of making a rigid inquiry into the truth of the charges preferred, and of holding the Commissioners to their duty.

abstract: The spirit which some of our Copperheaded citizens have endeavored to infuse into the channels of labor, has of late manifested itself in symptoms dangerous alike to the peace and quiet of our community and the best interests of those most disafected. Within the last day or two, however, a more sensible and kindly feeling seems to have come over the minds and hearts of those whose bread and butter are somewhat interested; and, although in certain departments of labor, strikes and such like movements exist, the great body of workingmen see the folly of a factious course and are using courteous argument where at first they threatened force.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions and remonstrances against a Broadway Railroad were presented. A petition from A.T. STEWART and others offered to accept the grant as reported by the Senate Committee, and to pay the City $2,000,000 for it. A unanimous report was made by the Bank Committee against the policy of paying the interest on the State debt in coin. The Canal Committee reported against the recommendation of the Canal Beard to reduce the tolls on hides, grass seed and other articles. A favorable report was made on the New-York Crosstown Railroad. The bill appropriating $175,000 to the Lake Ontario, Auburn and New-York Railroad was ordered to a third reading. The Broadway Railroad bill was considered during the evening session, but was not disposed of. It was made the special order for Thursday night.

abstract: -- It is seldom that an opportunity is afforded of passing a more pleasant or profitable evening in the way of amusement or instruction, than is presented on the occasion of a public lecture by Mr. HENRY GILES. His own humor is, if possible, more humorous than the laughter-provoking anecdotes he borrows and frames so neatly for illustrations of his general subject, when humorous anecdotes are fitting to his theme, and the pathos of his presentations of the sorrows of his favorite, Ireland, never fails to touch effectively all who listen to his story. Such was again the effect of his lecture last evening, upon "Irish Social Character and Humor." It was the second of the series he is now engaged in delivering, and, notwithstanding the night was stormy, Clinton Hall was well filled by an audience that laughed and wept alternately, as the lecturer dwelt upon the joys or sorrows of the Irish in Ireland. The subject of the next lecture, which he proposes to deliver on Tuesday evening, will be "Daniel O'Connell."

abstract: The Rebel Invasion of
snippet: The Rebel Invasion of
lead_paragraph: The news received, last night, of the occupation of Danville, Ky., by a rebel force, from 3,000 to 10,000 strong, and that a much larger force was following in its wake, seems to give consistency to the repeated intimations, of late, that the rebels contemplated another invasion of Kentucky. Danville is the first town of any importance reached in Kentucky on entering the State from the direction of Knoxville, Tennessee. And as all the reports we have had of rebel preparations to invade the State have made Knoxville the rendezvous of the forces for the expedition, they have apparent corroboration in the result.
