abstract: And Port Hudson, the Siege of
snippet: And Port Hudson, the Siege of
lead_paragraph: The siege of Port Hudson by the army and navy of Gen. BANKS may be said to have begun. Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, both on the east bank of the Mississippi River, 230 miles apart, and forming the two great final points of rebel defence on the Father of Waters, are both virtually invested by armies and navies of great magnitude and power. The military situation at each of these points is in some respects alike, in others it differs. At Port Hudson the Union army, under Gen. BANKS, is on this side of the river; at Vicksburgh the Union army under Gen. GRANT, is on the opposite side of the river to the objective point. At Port Hudson, the fleet is below the city; at Vicksburgh, it has been above the city. The strategy of Gen. BANKS aims to getting in the rear of Port Hudson with his land force, while FARRAGUT's vessels cooperate in front. The strategy of Gen. GRANT aims to flank Vicksburgh from the north with both his army and navy, or at least part of them, while another part may operate in front. It would seem from the rebel dispatch we gave the other day, to the effect that our forces had attacked Helena, which is a village twenty-five miles east of Port Hudson, that Gen. BANKS succeeded admirably in his first manoeuvre, and the subsequent dispatch, by way of New-Orleans, that he had got within five miles of Port Hudson, would indicate that the movement was progressing satisfactorily. The news from Gen. GRANT's flanking force, military and naval, for the last few days, has also been, on the whole, eminently cheering; and the official dispatch we publish this morning from Commander PENNOCK, opens up brighter prospects of success than we have ever yet had. It would seem from this and the unofficial dispatches, that one, or perhaps two new routes have been discovered by which our fleet can get into the Yazoo River, and consequently to the rear of Haines' Bluff and Vicksburgh.

abstract: -- The action brought in the Brooklyn City Court, by Miss MARIA BERNHARDT, against JOHN G. REITHER, heretofore noticed, was terminated yesterday. The defendant was a widower and plaintiff a servant in his family. He engaged to marry her and obtained the consent of her parents. He paid attentions regularly, took her to places of amusement, &c., and during this intimacy, as alleged, seduced her. The action was for breach of marriage promise and seduction. A number of witnesses were examined on both sides, and the case being given to the jury, a verdict for plaintiff was rendered. Damages, $3,000. This was the second trial, the jury having disagreed upon the first.

abstract: The news from Vicksburgh and vicinity this morning is of a very important character. Dispatches to the Navy Department announce that Admiral FARRAGUT's flag-ship, the Hartford, was below Warrenton on the 20th. This confirms the report received by way of New-Orleans, that she had succeeded in passing the rebel batteries at Port Hudson. It is announced further, however, that she is the only one of the fleet which did succeed in passing them. Admiral FARRAGUT's Secretary was on his way to communicate with Admiral PORTER. We have also an official statement of the discovery of the new passage into the Yazoo River, described in yesterday's TIMES. An interesting account of the movement through this passage will be found in our letter from Vicksburgh. The Carondclet, commanded by Capt. MCLEOD MURPHY, took the lead, and finding the way practicable -- or, rather making it so by cutting away the branches of the trees -- was immediately followed by a number of other gunboats and troop-transports. Admiral PORTER himself accompanied the fleet, on board the captured gunboat Gen. Price. The water was found of ample depth through the whole course of eighty miles. A rebel engineer was captured at Sunflower Lake, who gave information that there were at Yazoo City thirty steamers of large size, and 6,000 troops, with a battery of six guns. Gen. GRANT had put in motion a large body of National troops, and it was his intention, in conjunction with Admiral PORTER, to surprise and capture the entire rebel force there. Our latest intelligence from the Yazoo Pass Expedition is to the effect that it had come to a stand-still before the rebel batteries at Greenwood, waiting for reinforcements. The movement into the Yazoo in the rear of the rebel position, however, would doubtless make the fortifications at Greenwood untenable.

abstract: On Loyalty
snippet: On Loyalty
lead_paragraph: They won't abide FERNANDO in Connecticut, and he hies back to his native heath. He gathers his lieges in Mozart Hall, and bids them buckle up. He has made up his mind to perish for his country. We doubt if he does it. Calm reflection may convince the great patriot that it is his duty to spare himself. He may find warning in the example of CATO, who, it is said, threw away the remains of Roman liberty by the precipitation and temerity wherewith he rushed upon the sword before the proper time and occasion. It was a fatal mistake, and we think our modern Cato will conclude to avoid it.

abstract: Yesterday the keel of a new steam propeller was laid at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard in the ship house, from which the Shamrock was launched. She will be called the Nyack, average, 593 tons burden, and carry about 6 guns. Her length will be about 147 feet, width 30 feet, and 12 feet deep. She will draw only 5 or 6 feet of water to enable her to navigate the shallow rivers of the South.

abstract: The rapidity and steadiness with which Mr. MARETZEK steps from one success to another, is a good proof that his artists are of the class that can be depended on for all kinds of work. On Monday last, Mme. MEDORI achieved the greatest triumph of the season, winning for the opera of "Norma" a new vitality. The performance was so excellent throughout, that it has been universally pronounced to be the best ever given in America -- a statement which probably exceeds the requirements of truth, but indicates clearly the supreme excellence of the occasion that brought it forth. After a success in a part so vehement as the Druidess, it was a bold, and even hazardous venture for Mme. MEDORI to essay a role so completely different in all its requirements as Linda, in the opera of "Linda di Chamounix," produced here last night, yet it was completely successful. In the first act, to be sure, it is necessary to extend some of "the great charities of the imagination" to the lady. Her appearance, always charming and lady-like, is scarcely petite or picturesque enough for the village maiden, who, on the stage at all events, is a very dainty creature, and in this City has been charmingly impersonated. In the second act all disadvantages of this kind had disappeared,and in every portion of the work, except the trivial scenes with the Marquis, there was no musical inability on the part of the lady. In the second act, indeed, the dramatic points were so grandly incorporated with the vocal ones that we doubt if its touching duo finale has ever been heard to greater advantage. Mme. MEDORI sang, indeed, with superb feeling and nicety. Dramatically the third act was, of course, the best and carried off the honors. Mlle. SULZER was an excellent Pierrotto, and in the organ air of the first act won a merited round of applause. Signor BELLINI as Antonio, and Signor BIACHI as the Prefetto, were alike good; the first-named artist especially so in the great scene of the second act. Mr. MARETZEK's new tenore di grazia, Signor MINATTI, made his debut as Carlo, and was very favorably received. He has a head voice of exceeding sweetness -- rather cloying, indeed, from this cause -- and phrases better than any singer we have had. He is evidently a fine artist. He succeeeded in winning an encore for his romanza.

abstract: -- The journeymen tailors of Brooklyn met at the Military Garden on Tuesday night, and formed an organization for the purpose of taking measures to obtain a higher rate of wages. The meeting was mostly composed of Germans. Remarks were made by several, who stated that it was impossible to support their families at the rate of wages they now received. They resolved to meet again on Thursday evening to perfect arrangements.

abstract: The Feast of the Annunciation was celebrated yesterday morning in all the Roman Catholic Churches of this City by solemn high masses. At the Cathedral, Rev. JOSEPH WOODS officiated. The mass sung was EIKEN's third part in D. The high altar, pulpit, faldistorum and the altar were covered with purple, in deference to the penitential solemnities of Passion Week. At the Church of the Immaculate Conception, and at St. Peter's, St. Francis Xavier's, and St. Andrew's and Father CUMMING's Church, the services were attended by very large congregations.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday morning, to take action respecting the death of Ex-Comptroller HAWS. Remarks eulogistic of the character of the deceased were made by Messrs. PURDY, DAVIS and TWEED, and resolutions were adopted deploring his loss, ordering the county offices to be closed during the remainder of the day, and that the Board would attend the funeral in a body.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday morning, to take action respecting the death of Ex-Comptroller HAWS. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a number of bills were reported complete by the Grinding Committee, -- among them the one amending the Revised Statutes relative to evidence, and the one relative to Common Schools in New-York. The bill providing a bounty of $150 for volunteers who reenlist, and of $75 for new recruits, was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: We understand a movement is on foot to establish in this City a Traveler's, or, what may, perhaps, more properly be termed, a Pioneer's Club, of a national character, on the same general principles as those upon which the Travelers' Club in London is founded. It is proposed, however, that the influences and uses of the contemplated Pioneers' Club in New-York shall ramify more extensively throughout this community and the country at large, than is usual with associations of this kind. The proposed Pioneers' Club originates, we are informed, in the idea that great advantages will arise, not only to the individual members, but to the country, in bringing together, in club-rooms, traveled gentlemen who are located permanently in New-York, and those of the pioneer class, men of business, letters and science, of whom so many are constantly visiting this citfy or business or pleasure. It is thought that by this means a great amount of most valuable information relative to our frontier regions, especially, and to the continent at large, now entirely lost, will be obtained, and made available under the auspices of the Club. It will very readily be perceived that there is a wide field for such an Association, and the wonder is that it has not been thought of before.

It is thought that by this means a great amount of most valuable information relative to our frontier regions, especially, and to the continent at large, now entirely lost, will be obtained, and made available under the auspices of the Club. abstract: -- FERNANDO WOOD is doing the country an essential service. He is putting forth, in clear and unmistakable terms, his real views concerning the rebellion. He repudiates the idea of loyalty to the Government, proclaims his open and irreconcilable hostility to the further prosecution of the war, and calls upon the State authorities to resist the execution of the laws of Congress. The more he calls, the more they won't do it. We want just now no better guarantee for the substantial loyalty of the masses of the Democratic party in this State, than is given by the attempt of WOOD and his associates to array them in hostility against the Government. We find, moreover, in the very fervor and zeal with which he is prosecuting this endeavor, evidence of its desperate nature. WOOD sees clearly that although the Democratic party may, on the eve of an election, yield an apparent assent to his doctrines, they have no thought of making him the leader of their councils. His present movement, therefore, is an attempt to force them into acquiescence. He will fail, and the result of his attempt will be to throw himself out of position with his own party. He will be compelled to revive the Mozart Hall organization again, as the only mode of maintaining a foothold anywhere.
lead_paragraph: -- FERNANDO WOOD is doing the country an essential service. He is putting forth, in clear and unmistakable terms, his real views concerning the rebellion. He repudiates the idea of loyalty to the Government, proclaims his open and irreconcilable hostility to the further prosecution of the war, and calls upon the State authorities to resist the execution of the laws of Congress. The more he calls, the more they won't do it. We want just now no better guarantee for the substantial loyalty of the masses of the Democratic party in this State, than is given by the attempt of WOOD and his associates to array them in hostility against the Government. We find, moreover, in the very fervor and zeal with which he is prosecuting this endeavor, evidence of its desperate nature. WOOD sees clearly that although the Democratic party may, on the eve of an election, yield an apparent assent to his doctrines, they have no thought of making him the leader of their councils. His present movement, therefore, is an attempt to force them into acquiescence. He will fail, and the result of his attempt will be to throw himself out of position with his own party. He will be compelled to revive the Mozart Hall organization again, as the only mode of maintaining a foothold anywhere.

abstract: -- The following prisoners, indicted by the last Grand Jury, having pleaded guilty to the charges against them, were severally sentenced in this Court yesterday: GEORGE HATTON, false pretences, was sentenced to the Penitentiary for three months. EDWARD TORNEY, for burglary in the third degree, was sentenced to the Penitentiary for two years. CHARLES SMITH, alias Baker, colored, for grand larceny, was sentenced to State Prison for two years. MICHAEL HIGGINS, on the charge of burglary in the second degree, and MARY ANN JOHNSON, on the charge of forgery in the second degree, pleaded not guilty, and were remanded for trial.
lead_paragraph: -- The following prisoners, indicted by the last Grand Jury, having pleaded guilty to the charges against them, were severally sentenced in this Court yesterday: GEORGE HATTON, false pretences, was sentenced to the Penitentiary for three months. abstract: -- Yesterday evening another Loyal League meeting was held at the Lake House, Seventieth-street and Third-avenue, Nineteenth Ward, for the purpose of forming an Auxiliary Union League. The hall was crowded, notwithstanding the bad weather -- a large number of ladies being in attendance. Mr. R. MCGINNIS was unanimously chosen President, and called the meeting to order, after which he made a patriotic address. Several other speeches followed. Strong resolutions were passed in favor of prosecuting the war until the rebellion is crushed. The proceedings terminated at 10 o'clock, with three cheers for "The Union as it was" and "The Constitution as it is."
lead_paragraph: -- Yesterday evening another Loyal League meeting was held at the Lake House, Seventieth-street and Third-avenue, Nineteenth Ward, for the purpose of forming an Auxiliary Union League. Strong resolutions were passed in favor of prosecuting the war until the rebellion is crushed. The proceedings terminated at 10 o'clock, with three cheers for "The Union as it was" and "The Constitution as it is."

abstract: -- Last evening the installation of Rev. Dr. HOWARD CROSBY, by the Fourth Presbytery of New-York, took place at the Presbyterian Church, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street. The attendance was quite large, notwithstanding the inclement weather. The exercises, which were of an exceedingly interesting character, were conducted by Rev. Dr. COX. The sermon was preached by Prof. HENRY H. SMITH. The charge to the Pastor was delivered by Rev. Dr. ADAMS, and the charge to the people by the late Pastor of the Church, Rev. Dr. PARKER.

abstract: Democrats, Loyalty among the
snippet: Democrats, Loyalty among the
lead_paragraph: -- Even the New-Jersey Democrats are becoming anxious to have it understood that, in spite of their opposition to the war, they don't intend to put themselves in a position of hostility to the Government. Their passage of a bill to borrow a million of dollars for State defence has led to the suspicion in some quarters, and to the hope in others, that they meant to resist the execution of the Conscription law and the collection of the National taxes. But Mr. RANDOLPH, their leader in the Senate, took occasion to disabuse the public of this impression. He warned them against supposing for a moment that this money was to be used in any other way than in sustaining the General Government, and in putting down all appeal to other than legal means for the redress of real or imaginary grievances. "As long," said he, "as laws are upon the statute-book, or those of the General Government exist, they must be obeyed."

abstract: -- "The Fall of Rome" was the subject of the lecture (second of the course) delivered by Rev. JOHN LORD, in the rooms of the Historical Society, last evening. The attendance was respectable, and, whether so intended or not, a large proportion of his audience, while he spoke of the shame and degradation of society in the latter days of the Empire, thought he had, when he composed his discourse, been giving much of his mind to a consideration of the social peculiarities of those now rebelling against our Government.
lead_paragraph: -- "The Fall of Rome" was the subject of the lecture (second of the course) delivered by Rev. JOHN LORD, in the rooms of the Historical Society, last evening. abstract: On Tunesday night the salesrooms of BANGS, MERWIN & CO., were crowded by persons attracted by the announcement of the sale of rare and valuable coins. The sale was opened by the offer of some rare specimens of the early American dollar. One of 1794, now very scarce, was sold at $40, -- about ten dollars higher than at previous auctions. A splendid proof piece of the flying eagle dollar of 1839 was purchased at $35. Proof sets of 1857 and 1858 were sold respectively at $15 and $13. The prices for half-dollars did not range high, one of 1794 being purchased at $2 25. When the quarter dollars were offered, there was but little competition among the buyers. A fair specimen of 1796 sold at $2, and one of 1805, in excellent preservation, at $4. A dime, struck in 1800, was knocked down at $6, and a fine one of 1805, at $2 50. A half-dime of 1794, sold at $3 62; one of 1803, at $2 37, and one of 1830, at $2 50. A gold half-eagle of 1799 was bought at $15 25, and one of 1803 at $16. The collection of American cents offered was very fine, and the bidding was more than ordinarily spirited. The highest prices obtained were as follows: A cent of 1792, but little circulated; $5 12; a "wreath" cent, with the inscription "One hundred for a dollar" round the rim, $6 75; a fillet-head cent of 1796, in good preservation, $6 25; a cent of 1798, in poor condition, $15 and $25. An uncirculated cent of 1802 sold at $4, one of 1805 at $4 25, and one of 1817 -- a splendid specimen from the Fenotte cabinet -- at $3 75. A half cent of 1793 was purchased at $6 50; one of 1831, a rare piece, and a "proof," at $7, and one of 1841, of the same character, at $8. A proof half cent of 1852 brought $5 25.

abstract: This week two remarkably fine specimens of the animal man commence a course of scientific preparation for a contest that, some time during the Spring, is to prove which of them is sooner able to beat the other into a state of insensibility. For two months no expense nor trouble will be spared to bring them to the highest point of physical perfection. Their whole time will be devoted to the attainment of health and strength. No indulgence that could, for a moment, enervate the mind or body, will be permitted them, and no treatment will be neglected that can tend to brace the nerves, harden the muscles and clear the brain.
lead_paragraph: This week two remarkably fine specimens of the animal man commence a course of scientific preparation for a contest that, some time during the Spring, is to prove which of them is sooner able to beat the other into a state of insensibility. abstract: The funeral of ROBERT T. HAWS, late Comptroller of the City, took place at 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon from St. Stephen's Church in Broome-street. During the afternoon, up to 3 o'clock, the remains of the deceased were exposed to view at his late residence, No. 95 Allen-street, and the large number of citizens, of all classes, who thronged the premises, attest the wide popularity and high esteem in which he was held by the public. At the hour of 3, Rev. Dr. JOSEPH H. PRICE, Rector of St. Stephen's, read the ordinary Episcopal family service, consisting of selections from the Scriptures and a prayer. The coffin was then closed and the body was removed to St. Stephen's Church -- the procession passing through Allen-street to Grand, up Grand to the Bowery, up the Bowery to Broome-street, and thence through Broome-street to St. Stephen's Church. At the head of the procession walked Rev. Dr. PRICE, followed by the coffin, borne on the shoulders of four men -- the pall-bearers walking on either side. The following citizens acted as pall-bearers:

abstract: Times is beginning to be terribly mystified in regard to American affairs. It does not in the least understand the obstinacy with which the American people persist in their determination to put down the rebellion, after they have been told over and over again, by all Europe, that "it can't be done." They continue to get up formidable expeditions, but nobody knows where they are going, nor do the people themselves seem inclined to give up the contest, even if some of these expeditions fail. Equally puzzling to the Times are the renewed demonstrations of hostility to the rebellion on the part of Congress and the great body of the Northern States. In spite of its own predictions, as to the effect of the peace movements in the North, the Times sees things taking quite another turn. It says:

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamships Etna and Saxonia, the former from Liverpool and the latter from Southampton, we receive advices from Europe three days later -- to the 12th inst. The news is rather meagre, save as relates to the marriage of the Prince of Wales and its attendant festivities. The English journals teem with accounts of the triumphal journey of the Prince of Wales and the Princess ALEXANDRA from Gravesend, through London, to Windsor, and of the royal wedding, to the exclusion almost of all other topics. Six women lost their lives by suffocation in the streets. There is nothing new regarding American affairs. Polish affairs continue threatening. LANCIEWITZ had been proclaimed Dictator, and had issued a stirring manifesto, calling the Poles to arms. There was no change in quotations for cotton in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs were steady and Provisions flat. Consols 92@92 1/[???] for Money.

abstract: Prince of Wales, Marriage of the
snippet: Prince of Wales, Marriage of the
lead_paragraph: There are very few persons on this side of the Atlantic, be they never so un-English in feeling, who can read the reports of the extraordinary excitement in London over the Prince of Wales' wedding without a certain degree of pleasure as well as diversion. We are all more or less moved when we witness genuine enthusiasm in others, whether it be inspired by a trifle or by the grandest circumstance. And our emotion takes precisely the character of the sentiments that stir us. It certainly appears that John Bull was never so much excited as now. And the cause of his excitement being innocent, and his exhibition of it inoffensive, and only fatal to some half-a-dozen women and children, it is not in human nature to withhold a hearty sanction to his wild and uproarious joy. How can we resist the contagion when we are mentally in the midst of a crowd of millions of shouting Englishmen, Scotchmen and Irishmen?
headline: {'main': "The Prince's Wedding-Day.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Prince's Wedding-Day.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, PETER CULLEN, aged 20, printer by trade, was tried and convicted of burglary in the third degree, in breaking into the tailor store of ALEX. SANDER, No. 51 East Twelfth-street, on the 1st instant, with the intent to commit robbery. The prisoner was jointly indicted with WM. DIMMICK, who pleaded guilty to an attempt to commit the burglary, but CULLEN chose to stand trial, and claimed that he was a stranger to DIMMICK, and that when he was arrested he was assisting the officer to catch him. The officer, however, disproved this statement, and CULLEN got two years and six months in the State Prison, while his accomplice, who pleaded guilty, was let off with two years and two months.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, PETER CULLEN, aged 20, printer by trade, was tried and convicted of burglary in the third degree, in breaking into the tailor store of ALEX. abstract: Our Legislature has now been in session nearly three months, and not a syllable has it yet uttered upon the vital issue of war or peace with the rebellion. Other Legislatures, in behalf of their States, have spoken. Ohio has inscribed, in characters as bold as HANCOCK'S signature of the Declaration, that she is for war without ceasing, until the rebellion succumbs.
lead_paragraph: Our Legislature has now been in session nearly three months, and not a syllable has it yet uttered upon the vital issue of war or peace with the rebellion. Other Legislatures, in behalf of their States, have spoken. Ohio has inscribed, in characters as bold as HANCOCK'S signature of the Declaration, that she is for war without ceasing, until the rebellion succumbs. Michigan has put herself down to the same effect. So has Maine. New-Jersey has registered herself for bargaining with the rebels, and for peace, if peace can be bought. It is high time that the State of New-York should declare herself. She lags, when, by virtue of her rank, she ought to have been foremost. What loyal men, who consider that the equivocal message of Gov. SEYMOUR exposed the fidelity of the State to suspicion, want to know; what the rebels, whose last hope is Northern defection, want to know; what the powers of Europe, who anticipate a paralyzing struggle between State rights and National rights, want to know; what the future historian, who shall seek to make up an exact record of this great epoch, for honor or dishonor, will want to know, -- is the spirit and purpose of that State, known a "the Empire State," in the crisis of the struggle.

abstract: Yesterday, the Committee of the Legislature on Military and Harbor Defence; Committees of the Common Councils of New-York and Brooklyn; the Harbor Defence Committee and the Executive Committee of the Chamber of Commerce; also, Col. DELAFIELD, Col. H.S. LANSING, Capt. E.E. MORGAN, Capt. W.C. THOMPSON and other invited guests, proceeded down the Narrows on board the revenue cutter E.C. Winants, Capt. J.C. LOWBER, for the purpose of examining the defences and fortifications that protect New-York Bay and harbor. The steamer left the pier foot of Whitehall-street at 10:30 A.M., and steamed down the harbor to the fort at Sandy Hook, reaching that point at about 12 M. The various Committees then stepped ashore, and proceeded to examine the Government works which are in course of construction. Col. DELAFIELD, the Chief Engineer, accompanied the gentlemen in their tour, and gave all necessary information appertaining to the structure.

abstract: the Rise of Gold
snippet: the Rise of Gold
lead_paragraph: The greatest evil of the recent rise in gold was undoubtedly its effect in enhancing the price of all foreign commodities, and consequently of all home commodities the price of which is ordinarily kept down by foreign competition. But next to this was the unscrupulous use made of it as a weapon of factious warfare against the Government. It has for months been made to serve as an instrument for exciting disaffection among the working classes, and for discouraging enlistments, and shaking the confidence of the people in the result of the war. What with the speculators in Wall-street who operated in the Secessionist interest, and the journalists outside who chronicled and interpreted the results of their labors, the chapter which we have just been furnishing to the history of gold, has been creditable neither to our patriotism nor to our political economy.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- BELLINI's Opera of "Norma" will be repeated to-night. This work obtained on Monday last the most pronounced success of the season. So thoroughly excellent was the performance that the ordinary lethargy of the audience was completely dispelled, and a demonstration occurred, such as is seldom witnessed in our Academy. The distribution to-night is the same as on Monday last, Mme. MEDORI sustaining the role of the Priestess; Mlle. SULZER that of Adalgisa, and Messrs. MAZZOLENI and BLACHI appearing in the male parts.

abstract: The United States bark A. Haughton. Acting Master N. GRAHAM, arrived yesterday. She reports that a great number of refugees were coming into Pensacola, and two days before she left a schooner, with about sixty persons, men, women and children, on board, arrived from East Pass, having been sent in by Acting Master BRUNER, who commands a small force at that point. They all report a general want throughout the section of the country they left. The report which appeared in a City paper a short time ago, that our pickets were frequently shot by the enemy, is incorrect, as the Haughton has been at Pensacola for the last three months, and not an instance of the kind has been heard of. The health of the troops at that post is good.

abstract: THE LATE EXPLOSION ON THE STEAK-TUG D.E. CRARY -- RECOVERY OF TWO MORE BODIES. -- The bodies of BENJAMIN SMITH, the engineer, and JOHN JOHNSON, a deck hand on the steam-tug D.E. Crary, at the time of the explosion, were recovered from the water yesterday morning. They were very much mutilated, so much so that they could with difficulty be recognized. The remains were taken to the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house, where Coroner WILDEY will continue the inquest at 9 o'clock this morning.

abstract: Yesterday, the fairest which has yet dawned upon the Spring, was the festival of the milliners, the semi-annual celebration of which creates a flutter of excitement in the female bosom, and very often a second flatter, not so pleasurable, in the pockets of the bosom's lord. Be that as it may, nothing unpleasant, either in the present or in prospective, appeared to disturb the enjoyment of the gay crowds which yesterday thronged Broadway, and, with that airy grace which belongs to the gentler sex, and which even beaver cloaks and velvet bonnets cannot wholly conceal, flitted in and out of the various millinery emporiums, intent on that most absorbing of all objects, the discovery of a pretty Spring bonnet.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, ALBERT BOGART, a genteel looking young man was placed on trial charged with stealing $200 from a soldier named JOHN SHANNON. It appeared from the testimony that SHANNON and BOGART came to this City from Washington, together, arriving here late at night, and stopping at the Girard House. They slept in the same room, and early in the morning BOGART got up and put on SHANNON's pants containing the money, and left the Hotel, leaving his own pants behind. He was arrested at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, when he stated that he had put on SHANNON's pants by mistake. He returned the money minus $13, which he had spent during the day, but which he subsequently made up to SHANNON. It was shown on the trial that SHANNON was a deserter from the army. The Jury found a verdict of guilty, and the prisoner was remanded for sentence, and SHANNON was ordered back to the House of Detention to be apprehended as a deserter.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, ALBERT BOGART, a genteel looking young man was placed on trial charged with stealing $200 from a soldier named JOHN SHANNON. It appeared from the testimony that SHANNON and BOGART came to this City from Washington, together, arriving here late at night, and stopping at the Girard House. They slept in the same room, and early in the morning BOGART got up and put on SHANNON's pants containing the money, and left the Hotel, leaving his own pants behind. He was arrested at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, when he stated that he had put on SHANNON's pants by mistake. He returned the money minus $13, which he had spent during the day, but which he subsequently made up to SHANNON. It was shown on the trial that SHANNON was a deserter from the army. The Jury found a verdict of guilty, and the prisoner was remanded for sentence, and SHANNON was ordered back to the House of Detention to be apprehended as a deserter.

abstract: River; the, regained
snippet: River; the, regained
lead_paragraph: The partial check our Western naval force received in the loss of the Queen and the Indianola below Vicksburgh has been recovered from. Admiral FARRAGUT, whose intrepidity led the Union fleet to New-Orleans, through the fire of the forts below, has performed a like gallant feat at Port Hudson, and we are once more masters of the Mississippi River between Vicksburgh and that point. We have had dispatches from the Union vessels announcing their presence below Vicksburgh, and to-day we have the important statement that FARRAGUT came upon the Indianola, while the rebels were at work upon her, and captured her without resistance. The Queen of the West is reported withdrawn for safety up the Big Black River, which falls into the Mississippi fifty miles below Vicksburgh. The possession of the Mississippi River below Vicksburgh, as well as above, seems therefore to be complete and undisputed.
headline: {'main': 'The Mississippi River Regained.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mississippi River Regained.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. BURNSIEE has issued an order, which was published yesterday morning, assuming command of the Department of the Ohio. He is understood to be taking his measures rapidly to arrest the rebels now attempting to reach the Ohio through Kentucky. The advance of the rebel force, which occupied Danville on Tuesday, is variously estimated at from 3,500 to 10,000 men. There was considerable skirmishing on Tuesday and Wednesday between our cavalry and the rebel advance, and a number of prisoners were captured. A dispatch from Louisville reports skirmishing near Camp Dick Robinson, resulting favorably to the national troops. The forces are said to be about equal -- ours, under command of Gen. CARTER, having the advantage of position. There were no further reports of a rebel advance.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Capt. SMITH, of the bark Princeton, from Demarara, arrived yesterday, reports: Sailed from Demarara, March 3; passed the Island of St. Lucia on the 6th, and saw a large bark rigged steamer going into the harbor of Gros Islet on the South West End. Passed St. Thomas on the 8th, and was boarded by a boat from the harbor, who reported the United States steamer Oneida, Commodore WILKES, as lying in port, and also that the steamship Vanderbilt had captured a large steamer and sent her to Key West, (the Peterhoff, before reported.)

abstract: State Legislature and the Country
snippet: State Legislature and the Country
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of bills were reported favorably, and most of them passed to a third reading. Among them was the bill to reimburse the Manhattan Company for money advanced; the one relative to the New-York Common Schools, and the one relative to Trust funds in the hands of County Treasurers. The bill to encourage volunteering and reenlistments was passed. The bill confirming certain ordinances of the New-York Common Council was reported adversely, and the report was agreed to. The Broadway Railroad bill was considered during the evening session, and was further made the special order for to-night.

abstract: London newspapers tell us that six lives were lost in the crush of the procession on the occasion of the marriage of the Prince of Wales. These were the lives of women and children who were literally squeezed to death by the confusion and pressure of the unmanageable crowd. It is also stated that the passage way for the carriages of the procession could not possibly be kept open, and it was only by tact, coaxing and management on the part of the persons in attendance, that the crowd was induced to give way and allow a passage for the vehicles. What a pity it is that England has not a "strong Government," -- one strong enough, at all events, to keep the streets open on such an occasion as the marriage of their future sovereign! The British Press is very fond of reproaching us with our weakness and incapacity in this respect; -- but possibly the Prince of Wales may remember the incidents of his own reception in this City well enough to contrast them with those which marked his wedding day in London. Although our streets were crammed from morning to night, -- although we had only an ordinary police without arms, and no soldiers to sustain their authority, and although a very large proportion of the hundreds of thousands who crowded our streets on that day, were men who bore the Prince and his country no good will, hot a life was lost, not a limb was injured, not a woman or child was hurt in the slightest degree, nor did the Prince hear, during the whole day, a single word of personal disrespect. John Bull may find it desirable, some day, to "strengthen" his Government a little by infusing into it a trifle more of the democratic element.

What a pity it is that England has not a "strong Government," -- one strong enough, at all events, to keep the streets open on such an occasion as the marriage of their future sovereign! The British Press is very fond of reproaching us with our weakness and incapacity in this respect; -- but possibly the Prince of Wales may remember the incidents of his own reception in this City well enough to contrast them with those which marked his wedding day in London. Although our streets were crammed from morning to night, -- although we had only an ordinary police without arms, and no soldiers to sustain their authority, and although a very large proportion of the hundreds of thousands who crowded our streets on that day, were men who bore the Prince and his country no good will, hot a life was lost, not a limb was injured, not a woman or child was hurt in the slightest degree, nor did the Prince hear, during the whole day, a single word of personal disrespect. John Bull may find it desirable, some day, to "strengthen" his Government a little by infusing into it a trifle more of the democratic element.

abstract: Advices from Europe, one day later, are received by the steamship Bohemian, which arrived at Portland yesterday. She left Liverpool on the 12th and Londonderry on the 13th instant. The news is important. The pirate Alabama had been spoken by an English vessel, and reported having destroyed thirty-four American vessels. The report that LANGIEWICZ had been declared Dictator of Poland is confirmed. He had issued a stirring address to his countrymen, which will be found in our dispatches. It is reaffirmed that the Czar had sent a dispatch stating that whatever might be thought of the abstract justice of the demands of the Poles, no overtures or terms of compromise could be listened to so long as they continued in armed insurrection. Further casualties are reported as having occurred on the occasion of the Prince of Wales' wedding. Seven women were crushed to death and upward of a hundred persons had limbs broken. Several riots occurred in Cork, in which it was necessary to call upon the military to restore order. The Cotton market closed with an advance of 1/2d. on the week. Breadstuffs were generally unchanged, and Provisions dull. Consols stood at 92 1/[???] for money.

SCOTT is President, and which gave the impulse which has led to the formation of so many similar Leagues throughout the country.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, it was voted to consider the General Appropriation bill as the special order on Thursday next. Among the bills reported favorably was one to incorporate the Union Trust Company -- a majority report. The bill relative to the Common Schools of New-York was passed. It increases the tax to five dollars per pupil. The bills for the Improvement of the Chemung Canal feeder at Corning, and for the completion of the Nine-Mile Creek feeder, were also passed.

Among the bills reported favorably was one to incorporate the Union Trust Company -- a majority report. The bill relative to the Common Schools of New-York was passed. It increases the tax to five dollars per pupil. The bills for the Improvement of the Chemung Canal feeder at Corning, and for the completion of the Nine-Mile Creek feeder, were also passed.

abstract: Niblo vs. Harrison, impleaded. -- An order must be entered, directing the receiver, who has been appointed pendente lite, to pay into Court, to the credit of this action, all the money which shall have come into his hands as receiver herein, less his commissions, and that upon such payment, the order appointing him be set aside and vacated; and also providing and directing that all further proceedings in this action be stayed until the committee as appointed by the Supreme Court shall have been discharged, or until such further order of this Court in the premises, as may be made upon the motion of either party on notice to the other.

abstract: lost her chief glory, and must henceforth resign with that the soubriquet of which she has long boasted. Westward the hog wends his way, and over Chicago, the City of the Lake, his star now rises and sets. The season of '61 -- '62 showed that Cincinnati was no longer entitled to the swinish distinction of being the chief pork-packing, city of the world, as Chicago then packed forty thousand more hogs than she did; but the statistics of the present season, just published, reveal the amazing fact that while Cincinnati has packed 562,582 hogs, Chicago has, by regularly established packers, packed no less than nine hundred and seventy thousand, two hundred and sixty-four, or close upon a round million. We sympathize with Cincinnati; we congratulate Chicago -- henceforth crowned the true and undisputed Porkopolis.

abstract: There was a very large and enthusiastic meeting of unconditional Union men in Orcton Hail, Newark, N.J., last evening, held under the [???]uspices of the Loyal Union League of Newark. The meeting was called at 7 1/2 o'clock, and at last time the hall was crowded and the stairway full of citizens eager [???]o enjoy the promised addresses from JAMES T. BRANDY, Esq., and Hon. JAMES WABSWORTH. The meeting, however, was not organized for some little time after the hall was full, and the interval was occupied in conversations between individuals, relative to the [???]ange which has taken place and is still progressing in the feelings and speech of the Democracy of New-Jersey in relation to the policy of sustaining the Administration in a more vigorous prosecution of the war against rebellion. In this connection the feeling seemed yo be unanimous that Mr. VALADIGHAM had done were good by his visit to New-Jersey than any other man who had visited that State since the opening of the war. There were many honest men in New-Jersey, they said, es everybody knew, who had not voted for Mr. LINCOLN for President, and who believed that mistakes had been made ay his Administration, but who never dreamed of refusing to sustain his legitimate authority as President, nor of encouraging treason by throwing obstacles in the way of those who were doing their utmost to put it down. These men, when they heard that those who they knew to have once ranked as Democrats; and who, like FERNANDO WOOD, when the right began, had declared that the rebels must wa[???] over their dead bodies before success should crown their criminal efforts, when they heard the loyalty of such men spoken of with suspicion, were inclined to believe the fault lay with the suspecting and not with the suspected. But Mr. VALLANGHAM's timely visit, "and FERNANDO WOOD's published apeeches, had set them right on the question of Copperheads add what "Copperhead" means politically. They were loyal at heart -- men familiar with the word, and knew its meaning as applied to an American citizen. They could not, even with the aid of WOOD and VALANDIGHAM, see how the man or faction knowing no such word as "loyalty" in their political lexicon, who talked, of rebellion as simply an error, and treason merely as political heresy, could be Democrats' of the old Jackson School, in which they had been educated; and it required the speech of VALLANDIGHAM, and the printed word of WOOD, to assure them that men holding such language claimed to be Democrats. Ever since the persons named had given them assurance that such was the fact. Loyal Leagues had been organizing, and there was a gratifying prospect of an early extinction of Copperheadism in New-Jersey. Such was the character of the conversations during the interval and the conclusion arrived at, when

abstract: Our news from the Mississippi, this morning, is from both National and rebel sources. It is reported, by way of Cairo, that the new expedition to the Yazoo has been successful, three of Admiral PORTER's gunboats having reached Greenwood. A barge, containing a thousand bushels of coal, was successfully floated past the Vicksburgh batteries, for Admiral FARRAGUT, on Saturday night. The rebels report, through the Richmond papers of the 25th, that Admiral FARRAGUT, with the Hartford and Monongahela, engaged the Grand Gulf batteries as they passed up, but with no effect. The two vessels were at Natchez on the night of Tuesday, the 16th, and left the next morning.
lead_paragraph: Our news from the Mississippi, this morning, is from both National and rebel sources. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "Norma," last evening, attracted an overflowing audience, and was as successful in all its details as on Monday evening, when it created a furore. It is not only in the music of this opera that Mme. MEDORI is heard to the best advantage. It affords to that lady an opportunity of displaying the earnestness of a nature that is thoroughly dramatic, and needs only such a work to find utterance. The intensity of her action, the calmness with which she always remains superior to the situation, the dignity which was in her moments of wildest frenzy -- as, in the trio finale of the third act she still preserves her authority as the chief priestess of a mystic religion, are elements that can only be fused into a perfect whole by the fire of genius, such as Mme. MEDORI undoubtedly possesses. Such a Norma has never been seen on the American stage, and it is not a matter of surprise that on Mme. MEDORI's repetition of the character last night, it elicited all the enthusiasm of a first performance. The lady was frequently recalled.

abstract: Impressments by the Rebels
snippet: Impressments by the Rebels
lead_paragraph: of provisions by the rebel Government seems to be going on all over the Southern States, and is producing the greatest discontent and excitement, not only in Virginia, but everywhere. In Texas they have seized corn, sugar, cotton, leather, and everything they could lay their hands on. A Texas paper says that the impressment agents are shunned by the people as they would shun lepers; and that their threats have compelled even the wives of soldiers to give up the necessaries left for their support. So far as that State is concerned, it will now happily be relieved from these authorized and merciless robberies by the fleet of Admiral FARRAGUT. His vessels not only control the Mississippi between Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, but a number of them have ascended the Red River, the only route by which these supplies can be carried from Texas, and doubtless some of the steamboats bearing them have fallen into his hands. They will furnish most opportune aid to the men of his fleet.

abstract: SIDNEY SMITH would not speak disrespectfully of the Equator. We certainly intended nothing of the kind, the other day, in our distant allusion to Saturn. The National Inlelligence does us injustice. We hold that planet in great veneration. Possibly, sometime, when we cease to be "young" and "versatile" and "sprightly," and all that, we may become Saturnian, too. The Saturnian Age, they tell us, was the golden age -- when purity and simplicity had it all to themselves. The old poets say. it will be restored. If so, we hope to be there. We have sometimes thought that ALEXANDER POPE had us in his eye in his prophetic vision of the "Saturnian Times." It pains us that our ancient cotemporary should have such perturbations. We protest we meant nothing disrespectful.

abstract: On Democracy and the War
snippet: On Democracy and the War
lead_paragraph: Atlas and Argus says, with a great deal of justice and force, that "it would be a sad thing for our country, if the assertions made by the Republican partisan organs were true, that the Democracy of the North are in sympathy with the rebellion, and prepared to resist the laws of the Federal Government." We are glad the Atlas begins to appreciate the responsibility of such a position: we may hope, perhaps, that it will begin bye and bye to use its influence to keep the Democracy from taking such ground. Hitherto the Atlas has done everything in its power to excite hostility against the "laws of the Federal Government," and thus to prepare the minds of the Democracy for resisting them. To a certain extent its endeavors have been successful. Quite a number of prominent men in the Democratic party -- such men as WOOD and BROOKS in this State, VALLANDIGHAM in Ohio, and TOUCEY in Connecticut. -- have come out openly, under the shelter of such doctrines as the Atlas & Argus has advocated, in favor of resistance to the National laws and in expressions of open sympathy with the rebellion. The Atlas begins to perceive that "it would be a sad thing for the country," if this course should be generally taken by the Democratic party.

abstract: His Secret about Peace
snippet: His Secret about Peace
lead_paragraph: Some time since, FERNANDO WOOD made the statement, over his own signature, that peace propositions were received from the Confederates at Richmond, last December, which, if adopted, "would have been satisfactory to the people both North and South." This implied, of course, a return of the seceded States to the Union, as no other settlement could be satisfactory to the North. These propositions, said Mr. WOOD, were laid before the Administration at Washington, but were instantly and unceremoniously rejected. Mr. WOOD added, that the evidence of these facts existed in the handwriting of one of the highest officers of the Government, and that he only withheld it from the public because of the obligation of secrecy imposed.

abstract: store of Messrs. B.B. TILT & SON, No. 361 Broadway, was burglariously entered on Monday night last, by means of false keys, and property to the amount of about $1,300 was stolen therefrom. The firm discovered their loss the next day, and offered a reward of $500 for the apprehension of the burglar and the recovery of the property. Yesterday afternoon Detectives ELDER and MCCORD seized the property as it was being conveyed through Eldridge-street. It was carefully stowed in a large trunk, and consisted mostly of choice silks. A man named GEORGE HEATH was taken into custody upon suspicion of being the burglar. He was taken before Justice DODGE at the Tombs, and committed for examinations.

abstract: Wedding in London was a more sanguinary affair than at first appeared. We learn now that seven women were crushed to death by the mob, and upwards of one hundred persons had their limbs broken. This in London alone. Probably in other cities of the islands, where the excitement seems to have been nearly as great, there were enough killed to make up a hundred, "and the wounded doubtless count by thousands. This makes a respectable hecatomb for the occasion; but it was not enough. In Cork -- and in how many other Irish cities we know not -- riots were got up, and the streets had to be several times cleared at the point of the bayonet. In London the breakdown of the Police is described as complete, and the "fierce-looking chargers" upon whom the Press love to descant, had hard work to prevent a general tumult. In England an ocean of bad beer was drank, and in Scotland and Ireland seas of usquebaugh, and the amount of drunkenness seems to have been frightful. Had it occurred on this side of the Atlantic, the English Press would have dilated upon the affair as an unparalleled scene of killing, maiming and fighting, of yelling, drunkenness and madness. It is well for the women of England and the peace of the kingdom that there are no more Princes of Wales to wed.

abstract: secular days after to-day in which the clemency of the President is extended to deserters. He gave twenty-one days' notice that all who should return to the designated places of rendezvous before the 1st of April should be subjected to no other punishment for their criminal delinquency than loss of pay for the time they were absent without authority. After that time, we have reason to believe, there will be examples furnished of the necessary rigors of military law. The days of grace will not be extended, and the penalty will not be relaxed. There will be no sympathy, as there can be no respect, anywhere, for those who fall by the bullet as a punishment for this highest of military crimes. Our army and the country have suffered enough already by desertion. There will be general gratification, both among their comrades and among their fellow-citizens at home, to see these skulkers brought to justice; and to see that those who would fly from the bullets of the enemy only do so to be met by a charge a thousand times more sure to kill. As soon as it is found more dangerous to run away from the army than it would be to remain in it, though there were a pitched battle every week, there will be no more desertion. This is the policy the rebels have carried out for the past year, and it is the only just and proper policy in time of war. Those who know of deserters anywhere in the City will do them the greatest kindness by urging upon them an instant return to their regiments, or by reporting them to the authorities.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to provide a bounty for conscripts was reported favorably. A majority report was made in favor of allowing soldiers in the service of the United States to vote. The Broadway Railroad bill was considered. A motion prohibiting the operation of the road on Sundays was adopted. The amendment proposed by Mr. PRUYN, that the Governor and Senate appoint five Commissioners to build the road, and that the surplus profits be devoted to the Central Park and Croton Water Departments, was lost.

abstract: -- This Association, composed of ladies attached to sixty different churches, has done much for the relief of the soldiers in the way of furnishing necessary clothing, &c., for the wounded on the field and for hospital purposes. At the late Promenade Concert, at the Academy of Music, the sum of $5,800 was realized above all expenses, besides which $9,000 have been collected during the Winter and invested in woolen cloths, which were made into undershirts, drawers, &c., and sent to the armies through the agency of the United States Sanitary Commission. The ladies of the Female Employment Society, No. 30 Court-street, paid out of their own funds for the making up of all the articles sent to the soldiers.
lead_paragraph: -- This Association, composed of ladies attached to sixty different churches, has done much for the relief of the soldiers in the way of furnishing necessary clothing, &c., for the wounded on the field and for hospital purposes. At the late Promenade Concert, at the Academy of Music, the sum of $5,800 was realized above all expenses, besides which $9,000 have been collected during the Winter and invested in woolen cloths, which were made into undershirts, drawers, &c., and sent to the armies through the agency of the United States Sanitary Commission. The ladies of the Female Employment Society, No. 30 Court-street, paid out of their own funds for the making up of all the articles sent to the soldiers.

abstract: And Richmond Sentinel--Two Rebel Organs
snippet: And Richmond Sentinel--Two Rebel Organs
lead_paragraph: It matters not where a man lives -- if his proclivities and desires are in a given direction, through these he will look at and interpret events and things. The apophthegm that "the wish is father to the thought," contains the philosophy of much that we see and hear in men and newspapers. Rebels in Richmond, New-York and London alike and continually predict failure to our arms; and of each succeeding development of events, or each action in the field, they give the same version and interpretation, though each of them may profess to be guided by totally different motives from the other.

abstract: Rebel Cotton Loan, The
snippet: Rebel Cotton Loan, The
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Europe two days later, by the arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship Asia. The dates are to the 15th inst. The news is important. The diplomatic correspondence, called for by Parliament, in reference to the war in America, had been issued. Mr. MASON's latest letters urge the English Government to declare the blockade of the Southern ports a nullity, or not to respect it, because it can be shown that the North has not been able to render it complete and total. The refusal of this application is cause of dissatisfaction to the South. The latest cause of dissatisfaction on the part of the North is that England has done too little to satisfy the National Government in the case of the Alabama. The London Times, in an editorial on this correspondence, says the irritation that may be traced [???] nearly an equal degree in both divisions -- North and South -- is of itself a proof that England has not unduly inclined to either side. The latest dates of correspondence leave both with no grounds for more than remonstrances, and both have much less to say against anything England has done than in favor of something they assert she ought to do. The Times reiterates its arguments in defence of the position of England in the matter of the Alabama. The Union and Emancipation Society of Manchester having sent a protest to Earl RUSSELL against fitting [???]t vessels for the Confederates in England, Earl RUSSELL replies by policing out that the act of Parliament requires evidence on oath to enable proceedings to be taken against parties suspected of contravening the law. It is asserted that irritation among the operatives in Lancashire was becoming very strong. They complain of the behavior of the Relief Committees, the administration of the Poor law, the enormous reduction in wages, and that the workman is sinking more and more deeply into the power of his employer by running into debt for rent. The rebel loan of 3,000,000 was expected to be introduced in London and Paris soon after the sailing of the Asia. The accounts from Poland, although vague, show conclusively that the revolution is assuming the most formidable proportions. The Revolutionary forces are said to have reached already some 50,000 men. The latest telegrams via Queenstown state that the Russians have suffered another defeat near Myserzowo, losing 100 killed. The attitude of the French Government continued to be decidedly in favor of the Poles. An advance of 1/2d. per pound had taken place in Cotton in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were quiet. Consols, 92 1/8 for money.

abstract: The Manchester Guardian gives the following particulars of the meeting of Lancashire unemployed operatives, in Stevenson-square, to return thanks to the American people for their contributions of food to the relief fund. We may observe that an impression prevailed that the real object of the promoters of the meeting was to get up an agitation in favor of the Federal Government, and steps were taken by the friends of the Confederate Government to defeat that object. The Guardian says: "After some delay, Rev. C.W. DENISON commenced the proceedings with a prayer, not one word of which, owing to the hooting and applause, could be heard beyond the spot where it was uttered. The prayer being concluded, several attempts were made to go on with the programme; but, beyond the success which attended a call for three cheers for the Queen, and three more for the royal bride and bridegroom, those efforts were wholly ineffectual. At length the expedient was hit upon of inviting the opposite speakers to come and say what they had to say upon the platform. This done, the leader of the opposition began to address the mixed crowd amid the most [???]uous confusion. He asked what business had those ships and those carts full of bread to be drawn up in that square? What was it the promoters of that meeting intended the people to do? He said he did not wish to appear ungrateful to the American people for their gift of the bread, but he wanted to know why it was brought into that square, instead of being sent to the proper quarter -- the quarter that the people have had to avail themselves of for the last nine months. At the conclusion of this speech, THOMAS EVANS endeavored to obtain a hearing, but the crowd refused to listen to him. Several other persons having failed in a similar manner, Mr. EDWARDS stood forward and was rather more successful. He denied that the object of the meeting was to offer a bait to the people, but the promoters had thought that, upon such a day of rejoicing, something better might be done than to give an empty pageant to the starving poor. They had accordingly spent $200 to carry out their intentions, and they were prepared to distribute to those who were in want 15,000 loaves of bread. Rev. C.W. DENISON rose, and, after order had been restored, he proposed that the people should offer up their praises to God in a hymn in which all could join. [Confusion and laughter, and cries of 'No religion,' 'Plenty of humbug without that.'] The reverend chaplain managed to obtain a hearing, and addressed the meeting upon emancipation. At the conclusion of his address the meeting became quite ungovernable. The crowd surged to and fro and kept up an incessant uproar that drowned the voice of several successive speakers. The scene of confusion rose to its height when a loaf of bread was hurled with great force across the bows of a model of the Alabama, in the direction of the platform. From this moment it was obvious that any attempt to restore order would be fruitless. The several bread-carts were carried by assault, and their contents were thrown in all directions. In vain some persons on the platform protected against the disgraceful scene, while others pointed to what was going on as a worthy finish to such a meeting. In many cases severe injuries were caused by the force with which the loaves struck the people in the crowd. During this riotous scene, a loaf, thrown from the crowd, struck Rev. Mr. DENISON. He thereupon quitted his place on the platform, and left the meeting. By this time the bread-carts had been taken possession of by some authorized persons, who proceeded to distribute the loaves in a less dangerous manner; and when their stores were exhausted, the windows in the upper story of a bakery near at hand were thrown open, and more loaves were thrown out upon the crowd below. In the midst of such contusion, a vote of thanks was passed to the people of the United States for the generous gift they had sent to the people of Lancashire."

abstract: on negro equality and Slavery; What he Said on Slavery the Corner-stone of the Confederacy
snippet: on negro equality and Slavery; What he Said on Slavery the Corner-stone of the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: Professor MORSE has had the goodness to furnish the public, through the columns of the World, with his reasons for becoming a member of that "Society for the Diffusion of Political Information," whose clandestine birth excited so much scandal a few weeks ago. After paying his repects in a few nervous epithets to the reporter whose presence among the accoucheurs created so much disturbance, he proceeds to give his reason for supposing that the Republican party and the North in general stand in need of the instruction, upon questions of political economy and public morality -- of persons like himself, and Messrs. BROOKS and FERNANDO WOOD. This reason is neither more nor less than the doctrines which he alleges to be held by the entire Republican party, on the subject of negro equality. He is satisfied that they, as well as the Abolitionists, believe the negro race to be, in every respect, the equal of the white race, and that it is therefore entitled to the same political and social rights and privileges, and he devotes nearly a column to defending Mr. STEPHENS' famous declaration that "negro inequality" is the "corner-stone" of the new Confederacy He says:

abstract: A LADY ARRESTED ON A CHARGE OF LARCENY. -- For the past few days considerable talk has been occasioned in that part of the city called Frankfort, owing to the fact that a respectable and wealthy widow had been arrested and taken to Lackport for examination, charge with the larceny of a note of the amount of $2,400. It is contended by the lady, the defendant in the case, that she gave a man residing in Lockport, who had been transaction some business for her, a note for the amount above stated in payment for his services. When the note became due it was presented to the defendant by a man, a stranger, to whom it had been transferred by the original owner. The lady stated that she could not pay the note then, but would in a few days. About ten days thereafter the holder of the paper again made his appearance, and presented it, and the lady paid $1,900 in cash, and gave another note for the balance, the interest on the original note being thrown off through generosity, as she supposed. This is the defendant's case, or as much of it as is proper to publish at the present time. The prosecutor alleges, as we he hear, that the defendant while visiting at his house in Lockport wrongfully obtained possession of the note. The further examination of the case was postponed until to-morrow, meanwhile the lady is at large on bail or on her own recognizance. There are other matters connected with the case which will probably be developed in behalf of the defence which promise to give it some magnitude. The defendant's character has always stood above suspicion here, and her arrest is very mortifying to her and her friends. -- Rochester Union, March 20.

abstract: The official Turin Gazette publishes the bill authorizing the conclusion of the new loan, followed by a royal decree regulating the terms of its emission. The principal conditions are that a portion of the loan will be taken by private individuals (Messrs. ROTHSCHILDS and the National Bank,) and the remainder be submitted to public subscription. The rate of purchase will be determined by ministerial decree. The subscription is to be paid in ten installments, the first payable at the time of subscription, and the last upon the 20th of March, 1864. The rate of emission is at 71. The contract holds good for 700,000,000 lire, but it is not intended to raise more than 500,000,000. One hundred millions of lire have been reserved, to be submitted to a national public subscription.

lead_paragraph: This is Palm Sunday -- next before Easter -- so called because the day of which it is the anniversary of Christ's entrance into Jerusalem, where with great honor he was greeted, the multitude welcoming Him with hosannas, strewed branches of palm in His way -- the palm, the emblem of victory. On this eventful day, according to the Scripture record, our Lord, after entering the temple, healed many of the sick, blind and lame. St. Philip announced to our Lord that certain Greek proselytes, who could not enter the interior of the temple, were anxious to see Him, and He, therefore, went to them in the Court of the Gentiles. There He predicted the conversion of the Gentiles, and the glorious harvest of His own death and resurrection; and as He uttered a prayer to the Father, He was answered by a miraculous voice, which the people mistook for thunder. Our Lord further fulfilled prophecy in clearing the Temple of the profane traffickers by whom it was polluted. At evening, He returned to Bethany with the Twelve, and was the guest of Lazarus, and Mary and Martha. In commemoration of this day by the Catholics, sprigs of the palm, or some other evergreen, previously blessed by the priest, are carried to church -- silent though expressive memorials of Him who disdained not to accept the same tribute from His Apostles.

abstract: SUPPOSED SUICIDE IN THIRD AVENUE. Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday after noon, a man, whose name is given as Mr. JOHN SMITH, was found dead in his room at No. 572 Third-avenue, under very peculiar circumstances. He was a man about 39 years of age, a native of this City, where he has always resided, and so far as is known, he has always borne a good reputation.
lead_paragraph: SUPPOSED SUICIDE IN THIRD AVENUE. -- Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday after noon, a man, whose name is given as Mr. JOHN SMITH, was found dead in his room at No. 572 Third-avenue, under very peculiar circumstances. He was a man about 39 years of age, a native of this City, where he has always resided, and so far as is known, he has always borne a good reputation. He owned a stall in Washington Market, where for several years past he had been doing a thriving business. He was a single man, and, with a younger brother, resided at the house of his parents at the place above indicated. Yesterday morning he intimated to his family that he was too unwell to attend to his business, and that he should therefore remain at home. About 2 o'clock in the afternoon, his mother visited his room with some medicine, when, upon opening the door, she was startled by the spectacle presented. Her son was lying lifeless upon the floor, and in his right hand was a pistol. An examination of the body was made, when it was found that all upper portion of his head had been shot away, and that death must necessarily have ensued immediately after the shot was fired. All the circumstances of the case went to show that he died by his own hands. Coroner RANNEY was notified to hold an inquest upon the body.

abstract: If the rebel Generals see clearly that it is impossible for them to hold Vicksburgh, or, the Mississippi being virtually in our control, that it is not worth holding, there is nothing likelier than that they should move the larger part of their force northward to join BRAGG, and then, with this great combined army, make a frantic effort to push through Tennessee, and into Kentucky. On the face of it, at least, this would be turning the tide of war, and it would lake months of hard work before we could drive them back, again. They are "feeling" that section of country very extensively, and their ma[???] vrings in front of ROSECRANS look as if they were trying to draw him down and away from his base, that then they, may have the way more fully opened, up to them.

abstract: The negotiation of the Confederate fifteen million loan in Europe, seems to be a most difficult matter -- which is not to be wondered at, considering the value of Confederate stock in the Confederacy itself. Their agents have toddled around from one city to another, from Bourse to Bourse, from Paris to Amsterdam, from London to Frankfort, with pretty paper promises of the great repudiator in their hands, and with pockets full of inviting cotton bonds based on burning bales. They have, probably, sold enough of the latter in England to pay the salary of MASON and other emissaries, and to bribe the Anglo-secesh Press; and they may have met with as signal success in France; but beyond that, the Confederate hawkers can get nothing from their bonds but grief.
lead_paragraph: The negotiation of the Confederate fifteen million loan in Europe, seems to be a most difficult matter -- which is not to be wondered at, considering the value of Confederate stock in the Confederacy itself. abstract: -- Among the foreign news which we published yesterday was an extract of a letter from Frankfort, (Germany,) which mentioned that public opinion in Germany against Slavery was too strong to allow any one to interfere, by speech, writing or action in its favor; and that the course of the Confederates was so universally detested there, that persons who ventured to advocate that cause in the Clubs, had been remonstrated with, and then expelled. It would seem by this that there is actually a deeper devotion to our country and its war for freedom in Frankfort than in New-York. We hear a great outcry from Secessionists here about intolerance and suppression of freedom of speech, as if they could be permitted, without rebuke, to preach and propagate the devilish doctrines of JEFF. DAVIS in the Press, on the rostrum, in the streets and in society. But here the people have made no such determined stand in their public, political, and social relations as our friends in Germany have made for us. We should like to know, for instance, if there are not members of prominent Clubs in New-York who have "ventured to advocate the cause of the Confederates," and to show their sympathy with the rebellion, and who yet have neither been remonstrated with nor expelled? In such a supreme crisis of our country and of liberty as this, there is a patriotic intolerance which it were well to have more widely and universally applied.

abstract: The only news we have from Vicksburgh and vicinity this morning is rebel news, and if at all to be relied upon, it is certainly bad enough. One of our gunboats, in attempting to pass the rebel batterles at Vicksburgh, is said to have been sunk with all on board, while another was very badly damaged.
lead_paragraph: The only news we have from Vicksburgh and vicinity this morning is rebel news, and if at all to be relied upon, it is certainly bad enough. One of our gunboats, in attempting to pass the rebel batterles at Vicksburgh, is said to have been sunk with all on board, while another was very badly damaged. The new expedition to the Yazoo is said to have met a check, and to have been turned back. We prefer to wait for our own advices before deciding how much reliance to place on these reports.

lead_paragraph: GEORGE TICKNOR CURTIS, Esq., addressed the Democratic Union Association last evening on "Loyalty." lead_paragraph: The undersigned members of the Seventh Connecticut Volunteers beg to express to their fellowcitizens at home their views in regard to the prosecution of the war in which we are engaged. Prevented from offering our sentiments at the ballot-box, we yet feel more intensely than ever before for the welfare of the ancient Commonwealth, of whose name and [???] were never more proud than while beholding for the past two years, her unwearied and wise patriotism, and her paternal care of her sons in arms.

abstract: The Knights of St. Patrick held a meeting last evening, at the Astor House, to complete arrangements for a great mass meeting to be held at the Academy of Music, on Tuesday night, the 7th of April, the proceeds to be devoted to the relief of the suffering poor of Ireland. The price of tickets is set at 50 cents, and it is expected by the "Knights" -- who comprise a large and influential body -- that this contribution in the cause of charity will swell to a large sum. Committees were appointed to wait upon Archbishop HUGHES and Bishop LAUGHLIN of Brooklyn, to solicit the cooperation of the reverend clergy in both dioceses. Several distinguished public speakers are to be invited to address the meeting. Among them, Richard O'Gorman, Judge Emmett, Charles O'Conor, Jas. T. Brady, Horace Greeley, Henry Giles, Judge Daly, and several others. Ten thousand tickets are issued for the occasion. It is said that all the prominent Irish Societies in this City, Brooklyn Jersey, will contribute their strength to fill up the meeting.
