abstract: Unity in Support of the Union
snippet: Unity in Support of the Union
lead_paragraph: Upon one most important point our people seem to be just at present absolutely unanimous. Men of all parties seem to agree that, whatever else may happen, the Union must be preserved. We hear nothing now, from any quarter, of letting the South go in peace. Six months or a year ago there were thousands among us who were half inclined to regard the attempt to quell the rebellion as hopeless, and who were more than half inclined to end the war by conceding independence to the Southern States. We hear no such talk now. Even those who are most impressed by the magnitude of the struggle, and by the sacrifices which it costs to carry it on, seem to have become satisfied that if there is no way out of it except by disunion, it must be continued indefinitely. Thousands who would willingly grant the rebels large and liberal terms of peace, who would concede whatever they might demand in the nature of added guarantees and enlarged powers under the Constitution, who would even put the Government of the country into the hands of JEFF. DAVIS, and substitute the Montgomery Constitution for that of the United States, -- even these men would not consent to a division of the Union. They will fight two, three or five years longer if necessary to prevent such a result.
headline: {'main': 'Unity in Support of the Union.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Unity in Support of the Union.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The contest at Albany over the Broadway Railroad seems to be taking the usual course. It is simply a struggle between two or three different rings as to which shall have the gratuitous grant of this enormous franchise. Senator PRUYN's proposition to create a Railroad Commission, with full power to build such roads as the public convenience may require, and to operate them for the benefit of the City, is the most rational suggestion which has yet been made on this subject. But no one has an interest in its success sufficiently direct to enable him to interest members in voting for it; hence it will probably fail. If the franchises which are given away in this City were carefully husbanded by our City and State authorities, they could easily be made to pay half the expenses of our City Government.
lead_paragraph: -- The contest at Albany over the Broadway Railroad seems to be taking the usual course. abstract: We perceive, with great regret and apprehension, that various writers and orators have once more begun to prophesy that the war will be over by a certain day of a certain month.
lead_paragraph: We perceive, with great regret and apprehension, that various writers and orators have once more begun to prophesy that the war will be over by a certain day of a certain month. Only a week ago we learnt from one of these seers that the next Fourth of July was to dawn on a prosperous, peaceful and united Republic. We have no doubt that for the next quarter we shall have these predictions on every side, and have editors debating furiously whether it will be on the 11th or 13th day of the month that JEFFERSON DAVIS will try to make his escape into Cuba, and the Confederate Congress take refuge in the Dismal Swamp. "Reliable gentlemen" and "intelligent contrabands" will swarm in every town, with full, true and particular accounts of conversations overheard by them between rebel functionaries and their wives, wondering whether they will be hanged or only imprisoned if they surrender. The "backbone of the rebellion," flexible as it has shown itself to be, will be declared "broken" every time we capture an earthwork or occupy a village, and we shall have long discussions about the best manner of punishing the Southern leaders. Bellicose politicians will be found belaboring each other as to whether they will execute or only banish men who, at that very moment, will probably be surrounded by 200,000 soldiers -- desperate, well-organized and well led.
headline: {'main': 'More Delusive Prophecies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'More Delusive Prophecies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We published a brief dispatch, yesterday, from Cairo, which is corroborated this morning, giving a report, received via Memphis, that two divisions of our troops had entered the Yazoo River by way of the Sunflower, and that they had been landed at Eagle Bend, just above Haines' Bluff, and only a mile and a quarter from the rebel fortifications.
lead_paragraph: We published a brief dispatch, yesterday, from Cairo, which is corroborated this morning, giving a report, received via Memphis, that two divisions of our troops had entered the Yazoo River by way of the Sunflower, and that they had been landed at Eagle Bend, just above Haines' Bluff, and only a mile and a quarter from the rebel fortifications. This is, in a measure, contradicted by rebel dispatches from Vicksburgh, dated the 25th, which state that the expedition had been repulsed by batteries at the junction of Deep Creek and Sunflower Rivers, thirty-five miles above the junction of the latter with the Yazoo. Another rebel dispatch from Vicksburgh, backed by an official report, states that two of our gunboats attempted to pass the batteries at Vicksburgh, at sunrise on the morning of the 25th, and that one of them was sunk with all on board, while the other was badly riddled, and supposed to be in a sinking condition. Still another rebel dispatch states that another advance is being made against Fort Pemberton by the Yazoo Pass Expedition.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The miserable condition of the Brooklyn streets is attracting more attention now, since the breaking up of Winter, than ever before. In some localities the filth has accumulated for about six months, and complaints are general in consequence. There is not a Ward or a section of the city which is kept in even a passable condition, and in many places it is so bad as to make it difficult to cross any portion of a street, except at the crosswalks, without sinking ankle-deep in mud. The police report the condition of the streets every month, and for the 1st of April the record is anything but creditable to the authorities having charge of the matter.

abstract: -- Capt. WM. PERINE, formerly of the firm of PERINE, PATTERSON & STACK, shipbuilders at Williamsburgh, L.I., having been awarded a contract for building one of the recently ordered iron batteries of light draft for river service, has leased a water front north of SECOR & CO.'s yard in Jersey City. A building is now in course of construction, 190 feet in length by 30 feet wide, for the machinery. The battery will have one turret for two guns, and will be furnished with water-tanks on the sides, by the emptying of which the vessel will be so lightened as to be enabled to navigate in six feet of water.

abstract: The Military Preparations of
snippet: The Military Preparations of
lead_paragraph: Considerably more than a year has passed since the arrival, in the neighboring Provinces, of several regiments of British Regulars, including a crack brigade of Guardsmen and several companies of artillery. The arrival altogether was auspicious, regarded from a colonial point of view. The Province, to begin with, had been literally stripped of red coats. A few companies of Rifles in dusky green, were about all that remained to garrison the great forts of Quebec, Montreal and Kingston, and to attest before strangers the fact of British supremacy in the northern portion of the Continent.

abstract: The funeral of Mrs. LUCY MARIA, wife of HENRY C. BOWEN, who died suddenly on Wednesday last, took place at Plymouth Church yesterday afternoon. The occasion drew together a very large audience,and the services were of an unusually solemn and impressive character. After a hymn by the choir, and the reading of appropriate selections from the Scripture, by Rev. Dr. BURDINGTON. Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER addressed the audience briefly, and paid a feeling tribute to the memory of the deceased. No calamity outside of his own family, he said could come so near to him as the death of this Christian woman. It was her hand that was first stretched out to him on his arrival in Brooklyn; and under her hospitable roof he spent his first hours among this people.And, during the long years of his subsequent acquaintance with her, he had ever found her a good neighbor, a faithful wife, a kind and affectionate mother, and a sincere and, devoted Christian. As her life had been calm and peaceful, so was her departure as "sweet as the flying of a bird that sings while it flies." The example of her blameness life, and the admonition of her sudden death was expressively set before his hearers by the Pastor, who was himself deeply affected while speaking. Rev. Dr. S[???]ERS followed in a touching and beautiful prayer, and Mr. BEECHER pronounced the benediction. The body was then removed to Greenwood Cemetery.

abstract: The prize steamer Nicolai I., Executive Officer ALFRED EVERSON, commanding, captured on the 21st inst. by the United States gunboat Victoria, Capt. EDWARD HOOKER, off Little River, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The prize steamer Nicolai I., Executive Officer ALFRED EVERSON, commanding, captured on the 21st inst. by the United States gunboat Victoria, Capt. EDWARD HOOKER, off Little River, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday. The Captain states that he made three attempts to enter Charleston, and came near running down one of the vessels stationed there. The night being dark, he escaped being fired into. When captured, he was feeling the strength of Admiral LEE's squadron. The day being hazy, she unwittingly ran into the embraces of the Victoria, which was fully prepared to receive her. Discovering his danger, the Captain immediately turned to the southward, when a few rifle shell were fired at him, and he surrendered. On boarding her, the officers and crew were found to be in a state of intoxication, having imbibed too much of the "London Dock," which which they were abundantly supplied.

abstract: -- A soldier is now stopping at the New-England Rooms -- Sergeant THOMAS PLUNKETT, late color-bearer, who lost both arms at the battle of Fredericksburgh. His regiment was charging on the rebel works, when another Sergeant, who was bearing the colors, was killed. Sergeant PLUNKETT seized them and rushed to the front with them, when he was struck by a shell, which tore off both arms. The gallant soldier has no relations, and a subscription list has been opened for him at the New-England Rooms.

abstract: NEWARK METHODIST EPISCOPAL CONFERENCE. -- The session of this Conference was continued at the Hedding Church in Jersey City, on Saturday. The following local preachers, having been recommended by their charges, after examination, were elected to Deacon's orders: F.A. Farrow, Swain Thaskara, Chas. A. Yerrington, Stephen Smyth, J.J. Broswell and J. Oakley. The Conference was addressed by Dr. PORTER, of the Book Concern, urgin the claims of the periodicals upon the attention of the preachers. Resolutions from the New-Jersey Conference, in reference to enlarging Pennington Seminary, were introduced, and, after discussion, were referred to the Committee on Education. Yesterday, Bishop BAKER preached in the Hedding Church, and ordained the Deacons. In the afternoon, the ordination of Elders took place in St. Paul's Church, when the sermon was preached by Rev. L.R. DUNN.

abstract: We have advices from Europe two days later, by the arrival at this port on Saturday of the steamship Asia. The dates are to the 15th inst. The news is important. The diplomatic correspondence, called for by Parliament, in reference to the war in America, had been issued.
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Europe two days later, by the arrival at this port on Saturday of the steamship Asia. The dates are to the 15th inst. The news is important. The diplomatic correspondence, called for by Parliament, in reference to the war in America, had been issued. Mr. MASON's latest letters urge the English Government to declare the blockade of the Southern ports a nullity, or not to respect it, because it can be shown that the North has not been able to render a complete and total. The refusal of this application is cause of dissatisfaction to the South. The latest cause of dissatisfaction on the part of the North is that England has done too little to satisfy the National Government in the case of the Alabama. The London Times, in an editorial on this correspondence, says the irritation that may be traced in nearly an equal degree in both divisions -- North and South -- is of itself a proof that England has not unduly inclined to either side. The latest dates of correspondence leave both with no grounds for more than remonstrances, and both have much less to say against anything England has done than in favor of something they assert she ought to do. The Times reiterates its arguments in defence of the position of England in the matter of the Alabama. The Union and Emancipation Society of Manchester having sent a protest to Earl RUSSELL against fitting out vessels for the Confederates in England, Earl RUSSELL replies by pointing out that the act of Parliament requires evidence on oath to enable proceedings to be taken against parties suspected of contravening the law. It is asserted that irritation among the operatives in Lancashire was becoming very strong. They complain of the behavior of the Relief Committees, the administration of the Poor law, the enormous reduction in wages, and that the workman is sinking more and more deeply into the power of his employer by running into debt for rent. The rebel loan of 3,000,000 was expected to be introduced in London and Paris soon after the sailing of the Asia. The accounts from Poland, although vague, show conclusively that the revolution is assuming the most formidable proportions. The Revolutionary forces are said to have reached, already some 50,000 men. The latest telegrams via Queenstown state that the Russians have suffered another defeat near Myserzowo, losing 100 killed. The attitude of the French Government continued to be decidedly in favor of the Poles. An advance of 1/2d. per pound had taken place in Cotton in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were quiet. Consols, 92 1/8 for money.

abstract: -- Admiral DUPONT is doing most excellent work in reducing the rebel navy -- not to speak of the large number of prizes taken by his blockading squadron. On the 29th of January he captured the Princess Royal, an iron screw-steamer, of tolerable speed, which was intended, after discharging her cargo, to be joined to the rebel privateer fleet in the West India waters. On the 28th of February the iron-clads of his fleet destroyed the famous Nashville, which was all ready for a piratical cruise, and was literally in the act of running out on her errand. Now we have confirmation of the news that vessels of his fleet have destroyed off the South Carolina coast the rebel steamer Georgiana.
lead_paragraph: -- Admiral DUPONT is doing most excellent work in reducing the rebel navy -- not to speak of the large number of prizes taken by his blockading squadron. abstract: Four performances were given at the Academy, last week, including a matinee on Saturday. The weather was unfavorable on the last-mentioned occasion, and the house suffered in consequence. An accident of this kind ought to be a slight matter, but where the balance between profit and loss is so finely adjusted, it is apt to be a very serious affair.
lead_paragraph: Four performances were given at the Academy, last week, including a matinee on Saturday. The weather was unfavorable on the last-mentioned occasion, and the house suffered in consequence. An accident of this kind ought to be a slight matter, but where the balance between profit and loss is so finely adjusted, it is apt to be a very serious affair. It is probable that owing to it Mr. MARETZEK has lost all the profits of his week's labor. The conditions of operatic management are indeed hard, and no wonder that failure is so often the reward of those who undertake it. At our low prices of admission a single night of bad weather leaves a deficit that can hardly be recovered in a couple of crowded performances, and yet whilst we clamor for a good company, such as we now have; and grumble at any necessary economy that may be imposed on the management, we hesitate to acknowledge that it is essential to the maintenance of an art institution that the prices should be raised to an approximation of the European standard. How Mr. MARETZEK will contrive when be brings out new operas -- and two are already in preparation, one by PETRELLA, called the "Last Days of Pompeii," and the other by Mr. W.H. FRY, called "Esmeralda" -- is more than we can imagine.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, a bill to provide a bounty for conscripts was reported favorably. A majority report was made in favor of allowing soldiers in the service of the United States to vote.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, on Saturday, a bill to provide a bounty for conscripts was reported favorably. A majority report was made in favor of allowing soldiers in the service of the United States to vote. The Broadway Railroad bill was considered. A motion prohieiting the operation of the road on Sundays was adopted. The amendment proposed by Mr. PRUYN, that the Governor and Senate appoint five Commissioners to build the road, and that the surplus profits be devoted to the Central Park and Croton Water Departments, was lost.

Natives of United States, 107; Ireland, 18; Scotland, 5; England, 4; Germany, 3; Spain, 1; Wales, 1.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 139, mainly from the following causes: Consumption, 16; scarlet fever, heart disease, convulsions, (infantile,) 9 each; inflammation of lungs, 11; diphtheria, 8; marasmus, infantile debility, 6 each; croup, congestion of lungs, and inflammation of bowels, 5 each; bronchitis, 4; disease of kidneys, apoplexy, delirium tremens, [???] each; remittent fever, burns, cancer, 2 each, &c. Natives of United States, 107; Ireland, 18; Scotland, 5; England, 4; Germany, 3; Spain, 1; Wales, 1.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Quarantine bill introduced by Mr. MURPHY was reported from Committee, with an amendment providing that the approval of the Commissioner of the Land Office must be obtained, so far as regards the location and cost of buildings. A bill repealing the Militia law of last year was introduced. The bill providing for the acknowledgment of instruments in writing by persons in foreign countries was passed. During the evening session a communication was received from the Governor relating to the State Hospital Fund. He states that the fund of $30,000 is half expended; that the system is imperfect, and recommends a change and larger appropriations.

abstract: Interview with Lord Lyons
snippet: Interview with Lord Lyons
lead_paragraph: It is well remembered with what displeasure the Copperhead organs received the high-toned and emphatic response of Secretary SEWARD to the mediatory propositions of the French Emperor. So far as they dared, they denounced its spirit and its tenor, and in terms that made it morally certain that they were really in favor of foreign intervention as a means of terminating the war. Difficult as it was to believe that men who called themselves American citizens could be so lost to American spirit as to favor European interference, yet the tone of the complaints toward Secretary SEWARD, we felt at the time, could have no other animus; and we stigmatized it accordingly. An effort was made by these recreants to deny all such feeling; but it satisfied no fair mind.
headline: {'main': 'The Copperheads Before the British Minister.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Copperheads Before the British Minister.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "Semiramide," last evening, was all that a lover of mere vocalism could desire. Signer BIACHI, as Assur, rollicked in the roulades of his part as blithely as an infant in its nurse's arms; Mlle. SULZER, in her tremendous scena of the first act, displayed an excellent executive ability; Mme. GUERRABELLA, as Semiramide, expressed her emotions in the most accurate of periods, and Signor MINETTI demonstrated that he is a good pupil of the school of ROSSINI. We think in vain of a part that was not well interpreted; and yet the performance lacked spirit. The opera has never been a successful one here, although one of the best the maestro ever wrote. To explain this we must look at the libretto, and here we find a lamentable lack of action. The first act (subdivided into two acts last evening) might be played in a concert-room, so little does the scene add to the illusion. This defect is a radical one, and becomes in the end a bore -- especially with a public not thoroughly familiar with the music. And so, although the artists we have named were excellent, the performance dragged, and failed to elicit that warm response which we excellence of the singing really deserved. Of the Assur of Signer BIACHI, we have no hesitation in saying it is the best vocally we have ever heard. In mere facility of execution, nothing better could be desired; but apart from an insufficient profundity of voice, it seemed to us that he lacked ease and repose in the part, and hence the breadth which comes of those two qualities. Signor MINETTI sang with exquisite taste; and the two ladles were good, but deficient in volume of voice. The orchestra and chorus -- strange to say -- were not up to the usual standard, although Signor NUNO, a most able and excellent conductor, presided in the conductor's chair.

abstract: Object of the Movement on
snippet: Object of the Movement on
lead_paragraph: The contradictory rumors which we have been receiving for a fortnight past, through rebel and other sources, from Port Hudson and the Lower Mississippi, are cleared up this morning by the very interesting and lucid letters we publish from the scene of action. The movements of Gen. BANKS' army and FARRAGUT's navy, first in the direction of Port Hudson, and afterward back to Baton Rouge, are set forth as being the carrying out of a plan to push part of our navy beyond Port Hudson up the Mississippi, with the view of gaining control of that part of the river not previously in our hands, as well as of the Red River and the region from which the rebel armies in the Mississippi Valley obtain their supplies. Gen BANKS' flank movement by land was not, it seems, intended to prelude a direct assault upon the enemy's works, but to divide and divert their attention while FARRAGUT was effecting his part of the plan. As soon as news reached Gen. BANKS that the Hartford and Albatross had passed Port Hudson, he telegraphed to the officer in immediate command of the land force that the object of the expedition was accomplished, and ordered him to return leisurely to Baton Rouge. The idea seems to have been comprehended in the fleet itself, as will appear from the letter of a clergyman written on board the sloop-of-war Richmond. This is not exactly what the public had been led to anticipate. A combined assault in force on the rebel works had been generally advertised as about to come off, and a victorious reduction of the rebel stronghold was expected. For that, it seems, we must wait a little longer. But, as it is, we met with a gratifying success, and one whose results may be as great and wide-reaching as would have come from a storming of the rebel fortifications. With fleets above and below Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, the whole river, excepting those points, is now in our hands.

abstract: Sunday Liquor Sales and the Police
snippet: Sunday Liquor Sales and the Police
lead_paragraph: -- The Superintendent of Police claims just honors for his Department for "the good order in this City and Brooklyn on the Sabbath day," since the laws against the Sunday Liquor traffic have been enforced -- "making an era in the history of both these cities." "It is desirable that the same good order should be preserved in time to come," says the Superintendent; and what citizen who does not profit by rum-selling will question the fact? There have been too many demonstrations of unity of sentiment in this matter to doubt that decent men of all parties and creeds desire and are determined to have an orderly Sunday in New-York.

abstract: Yesterday was another grand gala day with the Army of the Potomac. The lowering clouds that hung ominously over us the night before, threatening alternately both rain and snow, were dispelled early in the morning by a bracing wind; the sun shone forth in all the majesty of its power, making all nature smile. It was just such a day as revives the hopes of the misanthropist and elevates the spirits of the hypochondriac; makes the old forget their age, the middle-aged the cares of life, and exhilarates even the buoyancy of youth. The special attraction was near the grounds of the Second Army Corps, where races and other sports incident to such an occasion were upon the programme. The main stand was graced by the presence of a number of women, and there were also officers of all grades, and Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, and his suite. The stand (200 feet long) was quite a feature in itself, having been made from the materials of a pontoon train -- the running gear being used for supports, and the planks for flooring. Three bands furnished music. The race commenced with a sweepstake, followed by a hurdle race, steeple chase, scrub race, foot race, race in sacks, climbing a greased pole, foot race, walking the wheel of fortune, and a fight between men tied in sacks. The attendance was very large, and, as there were the usual number of mishaps incident to such performances -- none of a serious nature -- the whole affair was hugely enjoyed by all present. The gay season, which has lasted for several weeks, may now be considered as about closed. The near approach of better weather warns all of the vital work to be performed. But of this more anon.

abstract: Millbank vs. Denniston; Violation of Orders
snippet: Millbank vs. Denniston; Violation of Orders
lead_paragraph: Isaac M. Millbank et al. vs. Alexander Denniston et al. -- This action was brought in 1847, to recover damages of the defendants for an alleged violation of orders, and other misconduct, as factors for the sale of five thousand barrels of flour for the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs did business in New-Orleans and New-York, and the defendants were a Liverpool firm.

abstract: Free Speech and Disloyalty
snippet: Free Speech and Disloyalty
lead_paragraph: There could hardly be a stronger or better testimony to the strength and vigor of our political system than is afforded just now by the sayings and doings of the faction, who claim for themselves the status and honors of a lawful "opposition." They have, at least, this use, if they have no other. There is not one of their journals or orators that is not a standing proof of the moderation of the people, of the supremacy of the laws, and of the solidity of the Government. If we wanted to give a foreigner a fair notion of our good sense, or our patriotism, or our clear-headedness, or our discretion, we certainly should take good care not to put the newspapers that sympathize with secession into his hands, and not to let him hear "a lecture" at either Mozart Hall, or the other "Democratic Union Association." But if we wanted to prove to him how free we were, how patient and magnanimous we were, how well the laws and the Constitution were maintained and respected, we should certainly administer to him, night and morning, as large doses as he could be got to swallow of WOOD's theories and BROOKS' jurisprudence. He must have the stomach of an ostrich and the brains of an ass, who, after having even once digested a mixture of this sort, could refuse to acknowledge the health and vigor of a system which can absorb a greater or less quantity of this same "stuff" every day all the year round.

abstract: To-night, before the Young Men of the City of Brooklyn, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER will deliver his great lecture on "What shall be done with New-England?" Maj.-Gens. FREMONT and WOOL have positively accepted invitations to be present, and win be there. Every preparation for a grand time -- a refreshing season of the style of 1856 -- has been made, and doubtless the walls of the Academy will ring to-night for Union and for Liberty as they have never rang before.

abstract: The statement of a person who camp by the prize steamer Peterhoff, relative to the movements of our iron-clad fleet now in Southern waters, were of so suggestive a character that our reporter yesterday endeavored to discover the exact state of the case. It seems that on Friday, the 20th inst., the commanding officers of the Montauk, Nahant, Potapsco and Nantucket, received orders to "prepare for action," from the flagship, and that subsequently the Catskill and another craft not named were honored with similar instructions. Shot and powder were immediately so disposed as to be available at a moment's notice, final drills were inaugurated, and the general fighting trim put on. On Saturday, the 21st, orders considered of considerable significance, were received, and on Sunday the brief command "to sail" was passed from vessel to vessel. The cheers of the sailors as they left harbor our informant describes as perfectly deafening. He states, too, that some of the mailed vessels remained behind -- one or two, he thinks. Probably the Wechawken delayed, as she needed some repairs.
lead_paragraph: The statement of a person who camp by the prize steamer Peterhoff, relative to the movements of our iron-clad fleet now in Southern waters, were of so suggestive a character that our reporter yesterday endeavored to discover the exact state of the case. It seems that on Friday, the 20th inst., the commanding officers of the Montauk, Nahant, Potapsco and Nantucket, received orders to "prepare for action," from the flagship, and that subsequently the Catskill and another craft not named were honored with similar instructions. Shot and powder were immediately so disposed as to be available at a moment's notice, final drills were inaugurated, and the general fighting trim put on. On Saturday, the 21st, orders considered of considerable significance, were received, and on Sunday the brief command "to sail" was passed from vessel to vessel. The cheers of the sailors as they left harbor our informant describes as perfectly deafening. He states, too, that some of the mailed vessels remained behind -- one or two, he thinks. Probably the Wechawken delayed, as she needed some repairs.

abstract: About 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Mr. EMERY PURDY, a well-known merchant of this City, and the senior member of the firm of PURDY & TYSON, dealers in leather findings at No. 36 Bowery, was found dead in his office, in the rear of the store, under the following circumstances: For some days past Mr. PURDY has been complaining of illness, and upon two or three occasions his friends had noticed that he appeared to be slightly wandering in his mind. He daily attended to his business, however, and no serious consequences were anticipated. Yesterday afternoon he appeared unusually depressed in spirits, and about 1 o'clock he announced to his partner, Mr. TYSON, who is also his brother-in-law, that he was unable to attend to business, and would lie down in the office, adjoining the store, and take a little rest. He remained there undisturbed for over an hour, when Mr. TYSON, thinking he might need aid, entered the office. To his astonishment, he found Mr. PURDY was dead. A pool of blood upon the floor, a small wound in his throat, and a small pen-knife lying near, afforded strong evidence as to the cause of his death. Physicians were at once called in, but life was found to be entirely extinct. An examination of the body was made, when it became evident that he had terminated his life by severing the jugular vein with the knife which was found near him covered with blood. Coroner WILDEY was notified, and will hold an inquest upon the body this morning. The deceased was a well-known merchant of this City, aged about 66 years. He was a native of White Plains, Westchester County, N.Y., but at the time of his death he resided with his wife and one or two grown children, at No. 274 East Broadway.

abstract: The steamship New-Brunswick, from New-Orleans on the 22d inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning, and was followed last evening by the McClellan, which left New-Orleans on the same day. By these arrivals we have full details, from our Special Correspondent, of the movement against Port Hudson by the land and naval forces, and the passage of the rebel batteries by two of Admiral FARRAGUT's vessels -- the Hartford and the Albatross -- not the Monongahela, as before reported. The passage of the batteries, as already stated, took place on the night of Saturday, the 14th inst. Taking the lead with the Hartford and Alabatross, followed by the Richmond and Kineo, the Monongahela and Genesee, and lastly the Mississippi. Admiral FARRAGUT essayed the passage, while the Essex and Sachem in the rear, with six mortar-boats, kept up a constant fire. The Hartford and Albatross passed the upper batteries in safety. The Richmond, after reaching the upper battery, was temporarily disabled and had to fall back. So was the Monongahela. The Mississippi ran aground at the bend Opposite the central battery, receiving the concentrated fire of the entire fort for an hour, and fighting most desperately. Finding it impossible to save her, Capt. SMITH gave orders to fire her. She afterward floated down the river till she reached a point a few miles above Baton Rouge, where her magazine exploded. Some sixty of the crew are either killed or missing. The remainder of the fleet are safe and ready for action. The army, under Major-Gen. BANKS, proceeded by land, simply to make a diversion; but after the Hartford had passed, and the experiment of passing the forts was ended, returned to Baton Rouge. They approached to within five or six miles of Port Hudson, and met portions of the enemy, who retreated to the forts. There had been no other military or naval movements. The steamship Bio Bio, which arrived at New-Orleans on the morning of the 22d, was burnt at her wharf immediately after her arrival.
